description: In this series we will dive into the second exam that is required for a viewer to achieve an MCSA in Windows 10. The topics will range from installation of Windows 10, post-installation configurations, applying images, various deployment tools as well as monitoring and servicing Windows 10 and more. Exam candidates are encouraged to watch both Windows 10 series for the MCSA exams.

Exam candidates are encouraged to watch both Windows 10 series for the MCSA exams.
name: MCSA Windows 10 - 70-698
subtitle: Installing and Configuring Windows 10

episodes.description: In this series we will dive into the second exam that is required for a viewer to achieve an MCSA in Windows 10. The topics will range from installation of Windows 10, post-installation configurations, applying images, various deployment tools as well as monitoring and servicing Windows 10 and more. Exam candidates are encouraged to watch both Windows 10 series for the MCSA exams.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes describe how to prepare to implement Windows 10. They start by determining hardware requirements and compatibility. Then they help you choose between an upgrade or clean installation. Finally, they explain the difference between the Windows 10 editions, look at requirements for particular features, and create/use the appropriate installation media.
episodes.title: Implement Windows
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.104 --> 00:00:15.671
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.671 --> 00:00:17.390
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and

4
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:22.040
in today's episode we are continuing
on with more of our Windows 10 series.

5
00:00:22.040 --> 00:00:26.070
Joining us back in the studio again today
to lend his expertise on that very topic

6
00:00:26.070 --> 00:00:28.320
is the man, the myth,
the legend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:28.320 --> 00:00:29.570
Wes, welcome back to the show.

8
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:30.503
How's it going today?

9
00:00:30.503 --> 00:00:31.220
>> Man, it's going great Dan.

10
00:00:31.220 --> 00:00:32.190
It's always great to be here.

11
00:00:32.190 --> 00:00:33.320
Thank you for having me.

12
00:00:33.320 --> 00:00:36.262
That's right we're at
the fork in the road.

13
00:00:36.262 --> 00:00:37.680
All right, what is the fork in the road?

14
00:00:37.680 --> 00:00:40.960
That means, well we gotta determine
if we're gonna implement Windows, and

15
00:00:40.960 --> 00:00:42.960
if, well we can implement Windows.

16
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:48.480
Because how we implement Windows inside
of our work environment will really

17
00:00:48.480 --> 00:00:52.530
be determined by, do we have
previous installations of Windows?

18
00:00:52.530 --> 00:00:55.980
Do we have bare metal hardware?

19
00:00:55.980 --> 00:00:57.480
Are we deploying new machines?

20
00:00:57.480 --> 00:01:01.980
A lot of times we try to re-purpose old
machines cuz companies can't just afford

21
00:01:01.980 --> 00:01:05.790
to go out on a whim just because a new
operating system comes out every

22
00:01:05.790 --> 00:01:07.120
couple of months or so.

23
00:01:07.120 --> 00:01:08.890
Not couple of months,
[LAUGH] every couple of years.

24
00:01:08.890 --> 00:01:10.260
Well it came out every couple of months.

25
00:01:10.260 --> 00:01:11.965
We'd really be in trouble there.

26
00:01:11.965 --> 00:01:14.090
And that's what we're gonna look at today.

27
00:01:14.090 --> 00:01:16.080
We're gonna look at implementing Windows.

28
00:01:16.080 --> 00:01:18.810
It's one of the things that
you're gonna have to know if you

29
00:01:18.810 --> 00:01:23.410
are attempting the 7698 exam which is
installing and configuring Windows.

30
00:01:23.410 --> 00:01:26.990
So, why don't we say we
just jump right in then.

31
00:01:26.990 --> 00:01:31.910
I've got a website pulled up on my screen
here, and this is Microsoft's website.

32
00:01:31.910 --> 00:01:34.810
And it shows you some of the system
requirements that you're gonna need

33
00:01:34.810 --> 00:01:37.440
to know for installing Windows.

34
00:01:37.440 --> 00:01:41.240
And the other thing that I would say is,
if you're in an exam environment,

35
00:01:41.240 --> 00:01:45.740
some of the things that they like to do is
present you with scenario-based questions,

36
00:01:45.740 --> 00:01:47.800
and they need you to figure out.

37
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:49.490
Well, what they're trying to figure is,

38
00:01:49.490 --> 00:01:54.200
do you know what those requirements
are to install Windows on your machine?

39
00:01:54.200 --> 00:01:57.950
So it is important that you do
understand these requirements.

40
00:01:57.950 --> 00:02:03.390
Now, if you are familiar with Windows 7,

41
00:02:03.390 --> 00:02:05.700
been really going back to Vista,
but maybe not quite Vista.

42
00:02:05.700 --> 00:02:07.120
Vista was a resource hog.

43
00:02:07.120 --> 00:02:11.070
But Windows 8 and 8.1,
a lot of the requirements were the same.

44
00:02:11.070 --> 00:02:17.060
So, a long line of operating systems,
editions I should say.

45
00:02:17.060 --> 00:02:19.275
Windows Editions that all have
about the same requirements.

46
00:02:19.275 --> 00:02:24.035
However, keep in mind that what
is the minimum recommendation

47
00:02:24.035 --> 00:02:26.935
is a lot different than will

48
00:02:28.015 --> 00:02:31.980
it support the processing power you need
for maybe a line of business application.

49
00:02:31.980 --> 00:02:34.640
So please keep in mind that
when we say requirements,

50
00:02:34.640 --> 00:02:36.840
these really are the minimum requirements.

51
00:02:36.840 --> 00:02:41.380
And in some of our other episodes, you
might've seen some of the other hosts say,

52
00:02:41.380 --> 00:02:43.710
these could be the painful requirements.

53
00:02:43.710 --> 00:02:45.690
So, do keep that in mind.

54
00:02:45.690 --> 00:02:47.780
For instance, you see the processor here.

55
00:02:47.780 --> 00:02:49.190
When we look at it, well, what do we need?

56
00:02:49.190 --> 00:02:50.270
Gigahertz processor.

57
00:02:50.270 --> 00:02:54.990
Well, gigahertz processor, we've had
gigahertz processors for a while.

58
00:02:54.990 --> 00:02:57.620
If you're running a gigahertz
processor and that's all it is,

59
00:02:57.620 --> 00:03:00.500
chances are you probably need
to upgrade that machine.

60
00:03:00.500 --> 00:03:04.614
But this really isn't a lecture on [LAUGH]
staying up to date with the latest and

61
00:03:04.614 --> 00:03:05.670
greatest.

62
00:03:05.670 --> 00:03:08.270
>> You don't like clicking on
things then waiting six hours for

63
00:03:08.270 --> 00:03:09.830
what you wanted to do, to do?

64
00:03:09.830 --> 00:03:10.374
>> That's right.

65
00:03:10.374 --> 00:03:12.218
>> [LAUGH]
>> You launched up that Windows 95

66
00:03:12.218 --> 00:03:12.770
machine.

67
00:03:12.770 --> 00:03:16.730
You come back two days later and half of
the screen is rendered, so very good.

68
00:03:16.730 --> 00:03:17.490
We don't want that.

69
00:03:17.490 --> 00:03:18.340
That's right.

70
00:03:18.340 --> 00:03:22.250
Here's something that's kind of new to
the Windows environment in general,

71
00:03:22.250 --> 00:03:25.890
if you'll notice that this
processor right here say SoC.

72
00:03:25.890 --> 00:03:28.730
Well what, oops,
>> Southern California right?

73
00:03:28.730 --> 00:03:32.100
>> Apparently it's going off
the screen here, and I change it,

74
00:03:32.100 --> 00:03:33.640
let's try that again there.

75
00:03:33.640 --> 00:03:35.670
>> That's the lovely Mac trackpad.

76
00:03:35.670 --> 00:03:36.430
>> Yes, exactly.

77
00:03:36.430 --> 00:03:36.950
>> Hard at work.

78
00:03:36.950 --> 00:03:38.870
>> Jiminy Clickets everywhere, here.

79
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:41.776
And I'll try not to say that
too many times in this episode,

80
00:03:41.776 --> 00:03:43.240
cuz you'll probably say it.

81
00:03:43.240 --> 00:03:46.100
But it's the SoC, so all kidding aside,
SoC, what is that for us?

82
00:03:46.100 --> 00:03:47.660
That's System on a Chip.

83
00:03:47.660 --> 00:03:49.450
And this is something new to Windows.

84
00:03:49.450 --> 00:03:52.280
You'll probably be familiar other
operating systems out there,

85
00:03:52.280 --> 00:03:53.670
like the RasPi, right?

86
00:03:53.670 --> 00:03:57.250
We've got the RasPi that's been around for
awhile right?

87
00:03:57.250 --> 00:04:01.990
Armed based architecture, a small board
and it'ssystem on a chip everything's

88
00:04:01.990 --> 00:04:07.320
built in and that is a requirement for
the Windows 10 IoT core.

89
00:04:07.320 --> 00:04:11.240
The Internet of things
another acronym we're not,

90
00:04:11.240 --> 00:04:15.310
how should I say,
we're not lacks on our acronyms here.

91
00:04:15.310 --> 00:04:19.960
And there will be something that you'll
just probably have to be aware of.

92
00:04:19.960 --> 00:04:21.510
So, we've got system on a chip.

93
00:04:21.510 --> 00:04:23.310
The other thing is a gigabyte of ram.

94
00:04:23.310 --> 00:04:26.930
If you think about a gigabyte ram,
most of our systems takes 64 bits,

95
00:04:26.930 --> 00:04:30.830
we like 64 bit,
it'd be a lot more than just 1GB of RAM.

96
00:04:30.830 --> 00:04:34.300
So the other things which we need to
be aware of are the hard drive space.

97
00:04:34.300 --> 00:04:39.269
16 gigs of free space for 32 bit and
you'll see a little bit more,

98
00:04:39.269 --> 00:04:40.990
20 gigs for 64 bit.

99
00:04:40.990 --> 00:04:42.690
Keep in mind that when you have 64 bit,

100
00:04:42.690 --> 00:04:44.880
you have two different
program files location.

101
00:04:44.880 --> 00:04:46.490
You've got an x86 program files, and

102
00:04:46.490 --> 00:04:50.290
then you've got regular program files
which is your 64 bit applications.

103
00:04:50.290 --> 00:04:51.920
And the graphics card here,

104
00:04:51.920 --> 00:04:55.730
looking at the graphics card when we look,
we need support for DirectX 9,

105
00:04:55.730 --> 00:04:59.290
I believe they're up to 11 or
12 by now so this is the very minimum.

106
00:04:59.290 --> 00:05:03.810
And they talk about WDDM,
there we go again more of those acronyms.

107
00:05:03.810 --> 00:05:06.220
What does that mean, that's
the Windows Display Driver Model and

108
00:05:06.220 --> 00:05:08.980
this is something that goes all
the way back to the days of this.

109
00:05:08.980 --> 00:05:13.060
There was a different model than the XPDM
that they had back in the days of

110
00:05:13.060 --> 00:05:14.896
XP that was the XP Driver Model.

111
00:05:14.896 --> 00:05:19.418
And problem with some of those display
drivers is they could get down there and

112
00:05:19.418 --> 00:05:24.011
the kernel and we know a lot of the blue
screens happen because of video adapters

113
00:05:24.011 --> 00:05:25.220
back in the XP days.

114
00:05:25.220 --> 00:05:27.670
Basically keeps it out of kernel
mode puts it in user mode.

115
00:05:27.670 --> 00:05:30.080
It's a little bit better for your system.

116
00:05:30.080 --> 00:05:30.700

Now, when we talk about pro

With a Pro Edition I can take this

Here's the other thing,

when you get the ability to connect

So that if Dan says, you know what Wes?

I'm sorry man, you're sneakernet,

he's still sitting at his desk in some

00:29:06.500 --> 00:29:09.010
You don't get that in the Home edition

that's in a basic Home edition, mom and

So it is a more featuresque as

business class feature.

Enterprise Now Enterprise has all
the features, right, applocker,

00:29:30.970 --> 00:29:36.030
direct access, right, other stuff as well.

I can't think of some of them

00:29:38.670 --> 00:29:41.262

direct access.

00:29:41.262 --> 00:29:46.563
The ability to control what applications

You have to go to Windows,

00:30:12.620 --> 00:30:14.628

All right, now, there's one that Dan

00:30:21.910 --> 00:30:23.770
And I want you to keep this in mind.

They stopped that in Windows 8 and 8.1.

All right, the reason is actually,

00:30:33.341 --> 00:30:37.962

>> [LAUGH] That's right.

00:30:42.135 --> 00:30:44.501
And ultimate was a way
that if somebody needed or

00:30:44.501 --> 00:30:47.225
thought they needed
the enterprise level features and

00:30:47.225 --> 00:30:50.880
functionality that they can go ahead and

00:30:50.880 --> 00:30:54.660
Apparently, I would say maybe popularity

we'll just leave that with
volume licensed customers.

00:30:56.510 --> 00:31:00.590
So, there isn't a business edition

00:31:00.590 --> 00:31:03.170
and there's no longer an ultimate edition.

00:31:03.170 --> 00:31:05.270
However, we do have some
different mobile editions,

you have the basic Windows Mobile, and
then you have Enterprise Mobile, and that,

00:31:09.650 --> 00:31:14.902
with the trend B-Y-O-D that allows you

00:31:14.902 --> 00:31:18.800
And a new thing in Windows in general,
the Windows family,

00:31:18.800 --> 00:31:22.650
is arm based architecture
that is not just Windows RT.

00:31:22.650 --> 00:31:26.961
All the arm based architecture that we've

00:31:26.961 --> 00:31:30.616
has been centered around the Windows RT

00:31:30.616 --> 00:31:35.320
Well that's not really the case anymore

00:31:38.106 --> 00:31:40.120
All right, so
we got some of those editions.

00:31:40.120 --> 00:31:45.997
I would be aware of

Be aware of some of the features.

We're gonna talk about some of those

00:31:51.588 --> 00:31:55.100

634
00:31:55.100 --> 00:32:00.099
Now, there are just a few more features
that they call out on the exam

00:32:00.099 --> 00:32:03.183
that I really want you
guys to be aware of.

636
00:32:03.183 --> 00:32:06.905
Again, because they call
them out by objective.

637
00:32:06.905 --> 00:32:10.486
All right, and that is Cortana,
Miracast and Secure Boot.

638
00:32:10.486 --> 00:32:13.172
All right,
I'm gonna do these kind of our order.

639
00:32:13.172 --> 00:32:16.595
Secure Boot, if you've been around
Windows, you've probably seen this before.

640
00:32:16.595 --> 00:32:18.785
It's not a Windows-centric technology.

641
00:32:18.785 --> 00:32:19.525
Keep that in mind.

642
00:32:19.525 --> 00:32:23.825
This is an industry-wide standard for
keeping your firmware or

643
00:32:23.825 --> 00:32:26.955
protecting your operating
system at a very low level

644
00:32:26.955 --> 00:32:29.840
before the operating system
even comes online, right?

645
00:32:29.840 --> 00:32:33.430
It does have some requirements
in order to support it.

646
00:32:33.430 --> 00:32:37.270
First of all, you need what is known as
the Unified Extensible Firmware Interface.

647
00:32:37.270 --> 00:32:42.430
Yes, UEFI, don't try to say that
ten times fast, firmware platform.

648
00:32:42.430 --> 00:32:48.740
And that is version 2.3.1 that you need,
and you also need a Windows,

649
00:32:48.740 --> 00:32:53.950
what is it, the certification authority
stored in that signature database.

650
00:32:53.950 --> 00:32:58.180
So there are some requirements and the
benefit of the Secure Boot is rootkits,

651
00:32:58.180 --> 00:33:01.930
they like to install themselves low
portions of the operating system,

652
00:33:01.930 --> 00:33:04.940
right before the operating system's
anti-virus even comes online.

653
00:33:04.940 --> 00:33:07.870
This gives you a way in combination
with something like ELAM,

654
00:33:07.870 --> 00:33:10.591
the Early Launch Anti-Malware drivers,

655
00:33:10.591 --> 00:33:14.190
that makes sure that your boot
code hasn't been modified.

656
00:33:14.190 --> 00:33:18.210
The low-level system drivers,
your critical kernel boot start drivers,

657
00:33:18.210 --> 00:33:19.590
almost said boot strap drivers.

658
00:33:19.590 --> 00:33:21.050
>> [LAUGH]
>> Boot start drivers

659
00:33:21.050 --> 00:33:22.090
haven't been modified.

660
00:33:22.090 --> 00:33:27.700
Again, that's why you'd
want something like this.

661
00:33:28.970 --> 00:33:32.562
Miracast, some of you guys are probably
familiar with Wi-Fi Direct.

662
00:33:32.562 --> 00:33:35.280
Wi-Fi Direct is another
industry-wide standard.

663
00:33:35.280 --> 00:33:39.590
This is Microsoft's flavor,
if you will, of Wi-Fi Direct.

664
00:33:39.590 --> 00:33:41.610
It's based off of Wi-Fi Direct.

665
00:33:41.610 --> 00:33:44.190
The ability to take for
instance, your phone, and

666
00:33:44.190 --> 00:33:47.960
just transfer that screen

667
00:33:47.960 --> 00:33:50.097
Now, that does have something specific.

668
00:33:50.097 --> 00:33:54.147
Remember we talked about
the basics requirements for

669
00:33:54.147 --> 00:33:56.763
Windows and that was WDDM 1.0.

670
00:33:56.763 --> 00:33:58.843
In Miracast, it's 1.3.

671
00:33:58.843 --> 00:34:01.600
So, do keep that in mind in
case they ask you on the exam.

672
00:34:01.600 --> 00:34:05.530
That's the Windows Display Driver Model
1.3 and a Wi-Fi adapter.

673
00:34:05.530 --> 00:34:08.260
Again, that supports Wi-Fi Direct because

674
00:34:08.260 --> 00:34:10.900
this is basically Microsoft's
flavor of Wi-Fi Direct.

675
00:34:10.900 --> 00:34:11.920
It's what it's piggy backing,

676
00:34:11.920 --> 00:34:17.860
it's what it's using, you probably seen
that in other applications out there.

677
00:34:17.860 --> 00:34:20.529
Last but not least, Cortana, right?

678
00:34:20.529 --> 00:34:22.866
We've gotta know a little
bit about about Cortana.

679
00:34:22.866 --> 00:34:25.445
I know that if all the Halo
fans are sleeping.

680
00:34:25.445 --> 00:34:26.080
>> Great, Halo.

00:34:26.080 --> 00:34:29.357
>> I was gonna say, if all the Halo fans

00:34:29.357 --> 00:34:31.294

00:34:31.294 --> 00:34:35.926
[LAUGH] Cortana, again, is another one

00:34:35.926 --> 00:34:38.620

And this requires something that

We always hear about Wi-Fi.

00:34:43.180 --> 00:34:44.850
High fidelity microphone, and

it also needs a driver that supports

00:34:48.960 --> 00:34:50.050
So keep that in mind.

690
00:34:50.050 --> 00:34:53.880
And again, it's just a requirement that

All right, if you wanna disable Cortana,

00:34:59.160 --> 00:35:02.975
But if you wanna get the benefits of

694
00:35:02.975 --> 00:35:06.351
a question on the exam,
I would know a little bit about these.

695
00:35:06.351 --> 00:35:10.324
But all in all, I think the only thing

696
00:35:10.324 --> 00:35:14.437

697
00:35:14.437 --> 00:35:19.796
Or you can install from a DVD,

00:35:19.796 --> 00:35:23.936

699
00:35:23.936 --> 00:35:27.239
So, just keep in mind how you're

700
00:35:27.239 --> 00:35:30.810
If you're gonna use a deployment,

00:35:30.810 --> 00:35:35.830
It's gonna be an image file,
if you're gonna use your optical drive,

702
00:35:35.830 --> 00:35:37.680
it's gonna be DVD, and
then finally the USB.

703
00:35:38.850 --> 00:35:43.282
On the USB side of that, remember,
make sure that your BIOS supports, or

704

705
00:35:45.216 --> 00:35:48.720
They've supported that for a long time,

706
00:35:48.720 --> 00:35:52.064
But just make sure you turn it on,
because sometimes boot to USB might be

707

turned off in your boot order and
you throw that USB drive in there.

708
00:35:55.205 --> 00:35:57.783
You try to boot to it and
unfortunately it doesn't boot and

709

it goes to the hard drive,
so keep that in mind.

710
00:35:59.895 --> 00:36:03.618
But we will see more of

711
00:36:03.618 --> 00:36:07.879
>> All right, Wes, well, we thank you for

need to know about getting ready to, and

713
00:36:12.204 --> 00:36:14.642
installing Windows 10 operating system.

714
00:36:14.642 --> 00:36:16.865
That being said, we do thank you,
again, for dropping by.

715
00:36:16.865 --> 00:36:18.806
We look forward to seeing

716
00:36:18.806 --> 00:36:20.428
Hopefully we'll see you there as well.

717
00:36:20.428 --> 00:36:22.180
As for this one,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

718
00:36:22.180 --> 00:36:24.627
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie

719
00:36:24.627 --> 00:36:25.578
>> And I'm Wes Brian.

720
00:36:25.578 --> 00:36:27.659
>> And we'll see you next time.

721
00:36:27.659 --> 00:36:36.140
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain and demonstrate the steps necessary to install and configure Windows 10. They begin with a standard, clean installation. They show you how to prepare an old or new PC for receiving the Windows 10 operating system through backing up files (when applicable), determining the installation media type (DVD,USB,Network), configuring the hard disk, and then the actual OS install. They also begin their demonstration of a migration from previous versions of Windows.
episodes.title: Install Windows

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes demonstrate how to use Microsoft's Native Boot feature for Windows 10. They start by explaining what Native Boot is and some of the scenarios where it might be implemented. Then they show you how to create and install the Virtual Hard Drive(VHD). This includes creating the VHDx file and applying an Image File to the VHD.
episodes.title: VHDs and Native Boot

Windows.

Both of these drives when p is

Right now what it's

And, when this is all said and done, we're

us to add another operating system

We've got the USB drives.

With native boot it works whether you

643
00:34:20.950 --> 00:34:22.540

Maybe you're troubleshooting and

Test beds, you name it,
always great cool stuff for

650
00:34:41.270 --> 00:34:45.340
I know viruses, they love to infest

651

would be perfect for trying to
troubleshoot those nasty little buggers.

652

That being said Wes, it looks like we have

At least I thought it was really cool.

And Wes did a great job of explaining

That being said we're gonna go ahead and

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes expound on configuring devices, drivers, and post-installation options. They start by diving into the topic of signed and unsigned drivers. Then they move into downloading and/or importing driver packages. Finally, they discuss driver package management.
episodes.title: Devices and Drivers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue to expound on configuring devices, drivers, and post-installation options. Here they demonstrate how to use the Deployment Image and Service Management(DISM) tool to add packages.

Some of the things that they do call out
on the exam is configuring accessibility

504
00:27:01.931 --> 00:27:06.074
options, because there's times when we're
gonna have to support people that might

505
00:27:06.074 --> 00:27:10.000
have a hearing impairment,
might have some kind of visual impairment.

506
00:27:10.000 --> 00:27:12.250
And we need to help assist them as well.

507
00:27:12.250 --> 00:27:13.980
So they do call that out on the exam,

508
00:27:13.980 --> 00:27:17.645
but I can see that Dan's telling me we
might have to save that for part two.

509
00:27:17.645 --> 00:27:19.090
[LAUGH] That's right.

510
00:27:19.090 --> 00:27:23.200
>> [LAUGH] I was trying to do this to him
over here, the clock is running down.

511
00:27:23.200 --> 00:27:26.820
But he does have a lot, great more
information that we need to cover.

512
00:27:26.820 --> 00:27:28.890
So, looks like a part
two in our future Wes,

513
00:27:28.890 --> 00:27:30.550
I'm looking forward to seeing you there.

514
00:27:30.550 --> 00:27:32.470
Looking forward to seeing
you there as well.

515
00:27:32.470 --> 00:27:33.990
As for this episode,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

516
00:27:33.990 --> 00:27:36.440
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

517
00:27:36.440 --> 00:27:37.034
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

518
00:27:37.034 --> 00:27:39.050
>> We'll see you next time.

519
00:27:39.050 --> 00:27:46.730
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue examining the cornucopia of post installation features and options in Windows 10. Here they look at configuring the Accessibility Features. They also dive into setting up Cortana as the personal assistant. Finally, they take you through configuring both the Edge and Internet Explorer 11 web browsers.
episodes.title: Post Installation Options Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.848 --> 00:00:16.224
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTv.

3
00:00:16.224 --> 00:00:18.680
I am your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode.

4
00:00:18.680 --> 00:00:19.781
Well, you know what it is.

5
00:00:19.781 --> 00:00:21.071
It's more Windows 10.

6
00:00:21.071 --> 00:00:25.516
And joining us back in the studio for
a part two on post-installation

7
00:00:25.516 --> 00:00:29.380
configurations and set-ups that is
our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:30.631
Wes, welcome back to the show.

9
00:00:30.631 --> 00:00:32.260
We're so glad to have you back.

10
00:00:32.260 --> 00:00:33.039
How's it going today?

11
00:00:33.039 --> 00:00:34.352
>> It's going great thanks for
having me here.

12
00:00:34.352 --> 00:00:37.519
That's right a part two on post
installation configurations.

13
00:00:37.519 --> 00:00:40.646
In the first episode we
looked at the start menu and

14
00:00:40.646 --> 00:00:44.680
some things that are new about that and
we looked at the task bar.

15
00:00:44.680 --> 00:00:48.431
Now continuing on in some of the
objectives that you'll have to know for

16
00:00:48.431 --> 00:00:51.756
the 76, 98 exam are configuring
accessibility options.

17
00:00:51.756 --> 00:00:55.433
Now, this is also good to know just for
a non-examined environment as well.

18
00:00:55.433 --> 00:00:58.740
Because you might work with somebody
that maybe has a vision impairment.

19
00:00:58.740 --> 00:01:00.680
Maybe somebody's got a hearing impairment.

20
00:01:00.680 --> 00:01:05.290
And these things can come in handy
when it comes to assisting people that

21
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:09.130
might need accessibility options,
which is where we're going.

22
00:01:09.130 --> 00:01:11.920
It says configure accessibility options.

23
00:01:11.920 --> 00:01:13.700
So let's go ahead and
we won't waste any time.

24
00:01:13.700 --> 00:01:17.690
Let's dive right in here and
let's show you on how to configure those.

25
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:19.900
Now, couple of different
ways that you can do this.

26
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:22.120
I know my head's covering
up the first way there.

27
00:01:22.120 --> 00:01:26.660
That little icon, that little notification
area there that brings up our action

28
00:01:26.660 --> 00:01:30.140
center side pane, panel if you will.

29
00:01:30.140 --> 00:01:31.259
Then we go to All Settings.

30
00:01:32.790 --> 00:01:35.470
All right, and
we have this Ease of Access.

31
00:01:35.470 --> 00:01:37.220
Well, that's one way that you can do that.

32
00:01:37.220 --> 00:01:41.120
We're gonna look at it from this
aspect here in a second, but

33
00:01:41.120 --> 00:01:45.680
I want you to also know that we have the
traditional Control Panel just by using

34
00:01:45.680 --> 00:01:48.850
those Administrative quick links that
we talked about on the first episode.

35
00:01:48.850 --> 00:01:51.130
We can also choose Control Panel here and

36
00:01:51.130 --> 00:01:53.390
you'll have well,
Ease of Access right there.

37
00:01:53.390 --> 00:01:56.100
So, couple different ways and
you're gonna see that some of the links.

38
00:01:56.100 --> 00:01:58.567
Even in the new interface,
take us right back here.

39
00:01:58.567 --> 00:02:03.146
So, wanted you to do both ways in
case they ask you on the exam.

40
00:02:03.146 --> 00:02:04.190
You're gonna be ready for it.

41
00:02:04.190 --> 00:02:08.990
So, I'm gonna go ahead and
close down the traditional Control Panel.

42
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:10.830
If I could say that right, and

43
00:02:10.830 --> 00:02:14.820
we'll get into the Ease of Access here and
launch this up.

44
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:18.610
Now, one of the first things
you'll see is the Narrator.

45
00:02:18.610 --> 00:02:21.029
The Narrator is exactly
what it sounds like.

46
00:02:21.029 --> 00:02:24.459
If somebody has a vision impairment and
maybe they need,

47
00:02:24.459 --> 00:02:29.189
as you hover over certain sections of
the interface you can have it read to you.

48
00:02:29.189 --> 00:02:33.960
So that you're audibly aware on the,

49
00:02:33.960 --> 00:02:37.845
where the mouse is if you will.

50
00:02:37.845 --> 00:02:41.000
Where the cursor is, and the different
elements that are on the screen.

51
00:02:41.000 --> 00:02:42.060
Now if I turn this on.

52
00:02:42.060 --> 00:02:45.830
I'm gonna be careful here and
hopefully it won't blur us out here.

53
00:02:45.830 --> 00:02:49.970
Notice that it kinda
highlights where you're at.

54
00:02:49.970 --> 00:02:50.600
All right.

55
00:02:50.600 --> 00:02:53.380
And you can see the speed and
the pitch and the sounds you hear.

56
00:02:53.380 --> 00:02:57.410
You can start to modify some of
these individual settings as well.

57
00:02:57.410 --> 00:02:58.610
Characters when you type them.

58
00:02:58.610 --> 00:03:00.920
You can see the various cursors and keys.

59
00:03:00.920 --> 00:03:03.920
So that's a little bit about the Narrator.

60
00:03:03.920 --> 00:03:07.600
The next thing that we have and I'm gonna
go ahead and turn the narrator off.

61
00:03:07.600 --> 00:03:09.101
Again if you turned it on,

62
00:03:09.101 --> 00:03:13.830
you might want to turn the setting on that
says start the narrator automatically.

63
00:03:13.830 --> 00:03:14.937
And this would be for

64
00:03:14.937 --> 00:03:18.522
somebody that you need to help
assist them in their computer, and

65
00:03:18.522 --> 00:03:22.640
you certainly can't be there every time
they need to turn on the narrator.

66
00:03:22.640 --> 00:03:27.662
So you could also make it start
automatically if you wanted to, all right?

67
00:03:27.662 --> 00:03:30.598
Now, for
people that maybe have vision impairment.

68
00:03:30.598 --> 00:03:32.650
You also have the magnifier, all right.

69
00:03:32.650 --> 00:03:35.750
When you turn the magnifier on, you can
see different options here as well.

70
00:03:35.750 --> 00:03:37.266
I'm gonna go and turn that off for

71
00:03:37.266 --> 00:03:40.364
now because we can always magnify
if we need to, but I tell you what?

72
00:03:40.364 --> 00:03:42.389
We'll go ahead and
leave it on just for a second here.

73
00:03:42.389 --> 00:03:47.269
And you can see right here that we have
things like Tracking, Follow the keyboard

74
00:03:47.269 --> 00:03:51.800
focus, Follow the mouse cursor,
and we can turn that on and off.

75
00:03:51.800 --> 00:03:56.100
Again, I'm gonna go ahead and just kinda
move up and turn the magnifier off and

76
00:03:56.100 --> 00:03:57.770
as you can see it does that.

77
00:03:57.770 --> 00:04:01.690
It brings a specific part of
your desktop into focus and

78
00:04:01.690 --> 00:04:05.410
you can see that the default
was to magnify it by 200%.

79
00:04:05.410 --> 00:04:11.170
And again for somebody that maybe
has a deteriorating vision,

80
00:04:11.170 --> 00:04:12.650
glaucoma if you will.

81
00:04:12.650 --> 00:04:15.280
And some of these impairments
that affect their vision.

82
00:04:15.280 --> 00:04:18.040
This might help them when it
comes to using their computer.

83
00:04:18.040 --> 00:04:19.807
>> That's right we don't
to leave them out right.

84
00:04:19.807 --> 00:04:22.116
They enjoy using their computers
as much as anybody else.

85
00:04:22.116 --> 00:04:23.485
And that will just make it
a little easier for them.

86
00:04:23.485 --> 00:04:25.120
So they can have that full experience.

87
00:04:25.120 --> 00:04:25.910
>> Absolutely.

88
00:04:25.910 --> 00:04:29.910
Everybody deserves the right, if they're
gonna use their computer to use it

89
00:04:29.910 --> 00:04:33.190
more efficiently in a manner
that makes them comfortable.

90
00:04:33.190 --> 00:04:35.160
So we do have those options.

91
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:39.987
Now, if you have somebody that maybe
doesn't see colors the right way.

92
00:04:39.987 --> 00:04:44.770
You have the ability that if you want
you can change it to high contrast.

93
00:04:44.770 --> 00:04:45.840
If I do change it.

94
00:04:45.840 --> 00:04:49.860
Then I get the ability to modify what the
text looks like, and the hyperlinks, and

95
00:04:49.860 --> 00:04:53.140
the background, button text and
stuff like that.

96
00:04:53.140 --> 00:04:55.830
And we'll go and turn that off, but
you also have the high contrast.

97
00:04:55.830 --> 00:04:59.270
Closed caption options, again you
have exactly what it sounds like.

98
00:04:59.270 --> 00:05:01.864
I'm sure some of you probably
watched a movie before right?

99
00:05:01.864 --> 00:05:03.004
And the closed captions there.

100
00:05:03.004 --> 00:05:07.154
So, if I can't hear what they're saying
and I'm not an expert lip reader.

101
00:05:07.154 --> 00:05:09.512
Then I can just read the captions
there and we can do that.

102
00:05:09.512 --> 00:05:12.211
We could do things like transparency and
stuff, the style.

103
00:05:12.211 --> 00:05:16.806
So you can have the different fonts
that you want, caption size, effects.

104
00:05:16.806 --> 00:05:19.736
And then again,
just different aspects of background and

105
00:05:19.736 --> 00:05:22.684
window and the various options
that you can change there.

106
00:05:22.684 --> 00:05:25.487
Now, how about making the keyboard
a little bit easier to use.

107
00:05:25.487 --> 00:05:31.039
If you have somebody that has maybe
problems you know, what is it.

108
00:05:31.039 --> 00:05:32.681
>> Dexterity.
>> Muscular dystrophy,

109
00:05:32.681 --> 00:05:35.910
rheumatoid arthritis,
things like that you know.

110
00:05:35.910 --> 00:05:38.600
>> Maybe somebody is
suffering from that and

111
00:05:38.600 --> 00:05:41.430
it might help using
the on-screen keyboard.

112
00:05:41.430 --> 00:05:44.590
This makes it to where if I
can't type on the keyboard, and

113
00:05:44.590 --> 00:05:47.670
I do have the ability to maybe
push a mouse around the keyboard.

114
00:05:47.670 --> 00:05:48.820
I can do that.

115
00:05:48.820 --> 00:05:51.270
So we have the ability to
use that on screen keyboard.

116
00:05:51.270 --> 00:05:52.390
It's kind of interesting.

117
00:05:52.390 --> 00:05:55.110
I've actually used this from
a completely different reason.

118
00:05:55.110 --> 00:05:57.870
The hyper visor,
I lost communication with a hyper visor.

119
00:05:57.870 --> 00:06:00.990
So the keyboard wasn't working in
the virtual machine that I was using and

120
00:06:00.990 --> 00:06:04.250
I was like I've still got this
virtualized keyboard in here, and

121
00:06:04.250 --> 00:06:06.600
it isn't going through hyper visor.

122
00:06:06.600 --> 00:06:08.510
It's talking directly to
the operating system.

123
00:06:08.510 --> 00:06:12.380
So when I lost the ability in the hyper
visor to communicate between the guest

124
00:06:12.380 --> 00:06:14.800
operating system and the machine itself.

125
00:06:14.800 --> 00:06:17.440
I just turned the on screen
keyboard on and I got around that.

126
00:06:17.440 --> 00:06:19.187
And I was able to reboot the machine and

127
00:06:19.187 --> 00:06:21.590
we know in Windows reboots fix well,
just about everything.

128
00:06:21.590 --> 00:06:23.260
>> That's out thinking
the problem right there Wes.

129
00:06:23.260 --> 00:06:24.000
>> That's right.

130
00:06:24.000 --> 00:06:24.730
That's right.

131
00:06:24.730 --> 00:06:29.550
So, I gave more than just the use for
the on-screen keyboard as it

132
00:06:29.550 --> 00:06:33.130
pertains to accessibility options
>> Sticky keys.

133
00:06:33.130 --> 00:06:36.930
Again, do you wanna press
a key at a time for shortcuts?

134
00:06:36.930 --> 00:06:39.130
Toggle keys,
you could see some filter keys.

135
00:06:39.130 --> 00:06:42.660
If you're like me, when I have a little
bit too much coffee in the morning,

136
00:06:42.660 --> 00:06:44.070
a little bit of shakes.

137
00:06:44.070 --> 00:06:49.040
But if you're somebody that has a nervous
disorder with your nervous system.

138
00:06:49.040 --> 00:06:53.280
It can ignore things like repeated
keystrokes and can help out a lot.

139
00:06:53.280 --> 00:06:59.260
And then they give you some, just various
other settings that you can configure.

140
00:06:59.260 --> 00:07:03.530
Warning message when things
are turning on and stuff.

141
00:07:03.530 --> 00:07:06.550
And also audible sounds when you're
turning the setting on and off.

142
00:07:06.550 --> 00:07:08.483
I don't know if you ever hit
the Shift key five times and

143
00:07:08.483 --> 00:07:09.503
you here this little [SOUND].

144
00:07:09.503 --> 00:07:13.490
And it gives you a little warning that
says, do you wanna enable sticky keys?

145
00:07:13.490 --> 00:07:14.500
So stuff like that.

146
00:07:14.500 --> 00:07:15.840
So you could be aware of it.

147
00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:19.800
Why are these dialog boxes
randomly appearing on my desktop?

148
00:07:19.800 --> 00:07:21.250
Hopefully I don't have malware.

149
00:07:21.250 --> 00:07:21.830
Don't worry about it.

150
00:07:21.830 --> 00:07:26.120
It's just Windows warning you that
these things are being turned on.

151
00:07:26.120 --> 00:07:27.524
The mouse, same thing.

152
00:07:27.524 --> 00:07:31.368
Mouse cursor speed and stuff,
numeric keyboard, keypad.

153
00:07:31.368 --> 00:07:35.884
Again, if you're on a laptop [LAUGH]
just not might be too beneficial.

154
00:07:35.884 --> 00:07:38.657
Cuz then you're gonna have to
find your function keys and

155
00:07:38.657 --> 00:07:40.230
find out where the numbers are.

156
00:07:40.230 --> 00:07:45.590
So, you can do that too holding down
the Ctrl key to speed your shift up and

157
00:07:45.590 --> 00:07:47.400
down or slow it down.

158
00:07:47.400 --> 00:07:50.638
And then some just visual options,
play animations in the windows.

159
00:07:50.638 --> 00:07:55.663
You can see show the windows background,
notifications and the thickness

160
00:07:55.663 --> 00:08:00.782
of the cursor depending on you know how
visually impaired a person might be.

161
00:08:00.782 --> 00:08:04.525
Now, that's walking
through the new settings.

162
00:08:04.525 --> 00:08:05.344
All right.

163
00:08:05.344 --> 00:08:07.429
Let's go back to the control panel.

164
00:08:07.429 --> 00:08:12.130
Let's go to the traditional control
panel cuz that was a lot of information.

165
00:08:12.130 --> 00:08:15.830
When it comes to Ease of Access Center,
but we also have,

166
00:08:15.830 --> 00:08:23.200
in the traditional control panel, we have
the Ease of Access Center, as it's called.

167
00:08:23.200 --> 00:08:25.070
And I wanna show you
something kind of cool.

168
00:08:25.070 --> 00:08:29.110
Maybe you don't really know what
settings you want to modify.

169
00:08:29.110 --> 00:08:31.060
Well, they make it kind of easy for you.

170
00:08:31.060 --> 00:08:32.590
And let me show you this.

171
00:08:32.590 --> 00:08:36.108
You can actually let Windows
make the suggestions for you.

172
00:08:36.108 --> 00:08:38.950
So, notice, we're in Control Panel,
I know, it did that kind of quick there,

173
00:08:38.950 --> 00:08:40.440
Dan, so
let me slow down here a little bit.

174
00:08:40.440 --> 00:08:43.480
In Control Panel, then Ease of Access.

175
00:08:43.480 --> 00:08:45.368
Now, you might say, well,
Wes, we've seen you do that.

176
00:08:45.368 --> 00:08:47.210
Why are you slowing down on the path?

177
00:08:47.210 --> 00:08:50.380
Remember text based answers on
the question don't show you any

178
00:08:50.380 --> 00:08:55.520
kind of exhibit and if you haven't
memorized these paths, you know, Start,

179
00:08:55.520 --> 00:09:00.630
Control Panel, Ease of Access, and
then whatever the hyperlink might be,

180
00:09:00.630 --> 00:09:03.590
you'll get that answer wrong on the exam,
and it's been known to happen.

181
00:09:03.590 --> 00:09:05.230
But I really like this little task link.

182
00:09:05.230 --> 00:09:08.010
It says, let Windows suggest the settings.

183
00:09:08.010 --> 00:09:09.680
Why not?
I'll let Windows do the work for

184
00:09:09.680 --> 00:09:11.190
us if they are, all right?

185
00:09:11.190 --> 00:09:14.470
So now it gives you a five step option.

186
00:09:14.470 --> 00:09:20.310
Basically, the Major categories here are,
eye sight, dexterity, hearing, and speech.

187
00:09:20.310 --> 00:09:24.140
So, you could see eye sight right here,
is first, it says images on the text.

188
00:09:24.140 --> 00:09:28.590
And text on TV are difficult to see
even when I'm wearing glasses, right.

189
00:09:28.590 --> 00:09:30.520
And I could always go, Next.

190
00:09:30.520 --> 00:09:33.100
And then dexterity, pens and
pencils are difficult to use.

191
00:09:33.100 --> 00:09:36.090
And, again, remember I told you,
wrists and arms and stuff like that.

192
00:09:36.090 --> 00:09:38.540
I've got a friend that's got
rheumatoid arthritis and

193
00:09:38.540 --> 00:09:40.020
I think maybe even tendonitis.

194
00:09:40.020 --> 00:09:42.130
I mean,
his hands aren't doing really well.

195
00:09:42.130 --> 00:09:47.350
So this does come in handy, and coupled
with the vision as well, all right.

196
00:09:47.350 --> 00:09:49.770
I do not use my keyboard, again.

197
00:09:49.770 --> 00:09:52.760
And, then, the third,
hearing, like I said.

198
00:09:52.760 --> 00:09:55.490
Again, conversations can
be difficult to hear.

199
00:09:55.490 --> 00:09:59.660
And they're kinda probing you with this
little, almost like a survey, right..

200
00:09:59.660 --> 00:10:02.997
They kinda wanna gather some information,
so, they're going through it and

201
00:10:02.997 --> 00:10:05.660
they'll adjust the settings
in the background.

202
00:10:05.660 --> 00:10:07.990
All right, I might say hey I'm deaf,
if I will.

203
00:10:07.990 --> 00:10:10.460
My wife would definitely
agree with that one.

204
00:10:10.460 --> 00:10:12.310
>> You listen to way too much metal Wes.

205
00:10:12.310 --> 00:10:13.714
It's done its damage.

206
00:10:13.714 --> 00:10:15.842
[LAUGH]
>> I was gonna say,

207
00:10:15.842 --> 00:10:20.503
ears up to the full stacks doesn't
do really good to your hearing.

208
00:10:20.503 --> 00:10:21.360
>> What?
>> [LAUGH]

209
00:10:21.360 --> 00:10:23.310
>> So, the last one is Speech.

210
00:10:23.310 --> 00:10:27.930
And, again,

You might find that websites don't
really work as you expected.

670
00:33:42.110 --> 00:33:47.470
So that's up to you whether
you turn that up or down.

671
00:33:47.470 --> 00:33:51.512
This Protected Mode, I know, Dan,
you work with other operating systems.

672
00:33:51.512 --> 00:33:54.810
You probably heard of that,
no execute bit, where basically,

673
00:33:54.810 --> 00:33:56.360
just a quarantined portion of memory,

674
00:33:56.360 --> 00:33:59.520
we say, go ahead, software, put your code
in there, but you're not gonna execute.

675
00:33:59.520 --> 00:34:00.970
So that's one of the things that,

676
00:34:00.970 --> 00:34:04.550
I think that came out in Window, or
Internet Explorer 7 where they said, okay,

677
00:34:04.550 --> 00:34:08.420
we're gonna use that data execution
protection, is what Microsoft calls it.

678
00:34:08.420 --> 00:34:10.591
It's all based on the no execute bit.

679
00:34:10.591 --> 00:34:16.080
And then we can always just customize
these and get very granular, if you want.

680
00:34:16.080 --> 00:34:18.420
Local Internet,
Local Internet is typically for

681
00:34:18.420 --> 00:34:23.470
business websites and
your company's website where you trust it.

682
00:34:23.470 --> 00:34:26.720
You can see that for this it's medium-low.

683
00:34:26.720 --> 00:34:29.000
Be careful with trusted sites, right?

684
00:34:29.000 --> 00:34:32.900
Because trusted sites are ones that you're

685
00:34:32.900 --> 00:34:36.840
absolutely sure are not gonna
cause damage to your computers.

686
00:34:36.840 --> 00:34:42.340
I know we had, for a company that I worked
for, we had about 10 to 15 employees

687
00:34:42.340 --> 00:34:48.190
coming in, and they were doing training
via a US government website and

688
00:34:48.190 --> 00:34:51.020
they needed to be able to access
that website without any problems.

689
00:34:51.020 --> 00:34:53.270
So we went ahead and
we put it in the Trusted Site, and

690
00:34:53.270 --> 00:34:56.100
they were able to use the full
functionality of the website, not having

691
00:34:56.100 --> 00:35:00.530
to worry about different aspects of their
user experience being restrictive, and

692
00:35:00.530 --> 00:35:02.130
they couldn't do what they wanted to do.

693
00:35:02.130 --> 00:35:06.700
However, make sure that if you put
a site in here, you truly trust it, and

694
00:35:06.700 --> 00:35:08.780
when you add a site and
click this button, and

695
00:35:08.780 --> 00:35:14.850
by default it wants to add the HTTPS
extension until you uncheck that.

696
00:35:14.850 --> 00:35:19.680
So you can add websites to the trusted
location that don’t necessarily have

697
00:35:19.680 --> 00:35:24.360
an SSL certificate attached to them,
and I've had to do that a bunch.

698
00:35:24.360 --> 00:35:28.820
All right, last one is probably
pretty self-explanatory.

699
00:35:28.820 --> 00:35:31.000
This is the Restricted sites.

700
00:35:31.000 --> 00:35:34.430
Basically, there's an easier
way with the Restricted sites.

701
00:35:34.430 --> 00:35:35.282
Don't visit them.

702
00:35:35.282 --> 00:35:36.844
>> [LAUGH] Just don't go there.

703
00:35:36.844 --> 00:35:42.660
>> I mean, just don't visit them,
but there might be maybe a reason.

704
00:35:42.660 --> 00:35:44.037
I can't think of one
off the top of my head,

705
00:35:44.037 --> 00:35:46.047
that you might want to put
something in the Restricted sites.

706
00:35:46.047 --> 00:35:50.258
But understand that it is really gonna
reduce the functionality of the website

707
00:35:50.258 --> 00:35:53.590
because we consider that it might
be harmful to our computer.

708
00:35:55.020 --> 00:36:00.310
All right, last one here that I kinda
wanna talk about are the privacy settings.

709
00:36:00.310 --> 00:36:05.120
This is really how cookies
are gonna be handled, right?

710
00:36:05.120 --> 00:36:07.320
Third party cookies,
do we wanna allow them?

711
00:36:07.320 --> 00:36:08.750
Do we not wanna allow them?

712
00:36:08.750 --> 00:36:12.549
Again, we can go into the Advanced here
and we can say, okay, First-party Cookies,

713
00:36:12.549 --> 00:36:13.300
we'll Accept.

714
00:36:13.300 --> 00:36:17.051
Maybe Third-party Cookies we'll Block.

715
00:36:17.051 --> 00:36:19.404
Or maybe we're not real restrictive and
we just say hey,

716
00:36:19.404 --> 00:36:22.720
I just want to be aware of it when
a third party cookie is being used.

717
00:36:22.720 --> 00:36:26.150
All right, and
we can say always allow session, right?

718
00:36:26.150 --> 00:36:29.360
The other thing here,
location, location, location.

719
00:36:29.360 --> 00:36:33.230
It says, never allow websites to
request your physical location.

720
00:36:33.230 --> 00:36:37.015
That's good from a security standpoint
when you talk about a managed environment.

721
00:36:37.015 --> 00:36:39.130
Pop-up Blocker, guys,
you guys are smart out there,

722
00:36:39.130 --> 00:36:41.368
that's as simple as turning
the Pop-up Blocker on and off.

723
00:36:41.368 --> 00:36:43.500
And then In-Private browsing,

724
00:36:43.500 --> 00:36:48.320
this is more of a little bit more
security when you're in private browsing.

725
00:36:48.320 --> 00:36:51.930
It says don't even allow the toolbars or
extensions like your search providers or

726
00:36:51.930 --> 00:36:56.000
anything to run inside of
the in-private browser.

727
00:36:56.000 --> 00:37:00.950
All right, and Dan, I'm gonna kinda
go off the beaten path here just talk

728
00:37:00.950 --> 00:37:02.560
real briefly about these last ones.

729
00:37:02.560 --> 00:37:08.440
Content certificates, if you have them
stored, user certificates autocomplete.

730
00:37:08.440 --> 00:37:11.210
You have some of the different
various feeds and websites.

731
00:37:11.210 --> 00:37:13.080
I'll show you the autocomplete
here real quick.

732
00:37:13.080 --> 00:37:17.327
We could say what do we want
to use autocomplete for?

733
00:37:17.327 --> 00:37:18.271
Maybe in a security environment.

734
00:37:18.271 --> 00:37:20.018
I know I've had to uncheck
this one right here.

735
00:37:20.018 --> 00:37:21.350
We don't wanna store user names and

736
00:37:21.350 --> 00:37:24.490
passwords on forums and
ask me before saving.

737
00:37:24.490 --> 00:37:27.030
I could uncheck that and
then I could manage or

738
00:37:27.030 --> 00:37:31.140
I could even delete
the autocomplete settings.

739
00:37:31.140 --> 00:37:35.580
Connections, VPN communications,
we can set up VPNs here if we want.

740
00:37:35.580 --> 00:37:39.020
Programs, we can define how
programs interact with the browser.

741
00:37:39.020 --> 00:37:41.640
And last but not least,
like I was telling you,

742
00:37:41.640 --> 00:37:46.280
you can get very, very granular
control over the Advanced tab.

743
00:37:46.280 --> 00:37:50.197
And I will tell you, if you have somebody
that messes around with the browser and

744
00:37:50.197 --> 00:37:54.467
doesn't know exactly what they've changed
and they can't figure out how to change it

745
00:37:54.467 --> 00:37:57.294
back, well,
that's where the good old Reset comes in.

746
00:37:57.294 --> 00:38:00.581
And there's been times where I've
had malware get into the browser and

747
00:38:00.581 --> 00:38:04.510
start to configure it, and you can't
figure out why it's not working well.

748
00:38:04.510 --> 00:38:07.550
You hit the Reset button,
you can also delete the personal settings.

749
00:38:07.550 --> 00:38:11.960
You hit the Reset, it goes through its
process, and it tells you it requires

750
00:38:11.960 --> 00:38:15.470
a restart for Internet Explorer,
these settings to take effect.

751
00:38:15.470 --> 00:38:18.560
You shut the browser down, you relaunch
it, it's back to the default settings.

752
00:38:18.560 --> 00:38:22.100
And hopefully, with a little bit of
antivirus software, you can get the virus

753
00:38:22.100 --> 00:38:24.900
off of there and restore your
browser to the original state.

754
00:38:24.900 --> 00:38:26.340
But Dan, that, in a nutshell,

755
00:38:26.340 --> 00:38:28.580
helps us with some of our
post-installation options.

756
00:38:28.580 --> 00:38:29.850
>> Awesome stuff, Wes.

757
00:38:29.850 --> 00:38:34.290
We now have a better idea, right,
a better picture of what we're doing,

758
00:38:34.290 --> 00:38:36.990
getting us out of our browsers,
using all the different bells and

759
00:38:36.990 --> 00:38:39.810
whistles that we can turn and
tweak and have a lot of fun with.

760
00:38:39.810 --> 00:38:43.700
And if you're a knob turner, if you're
a button flipper like probably Wes and

761
00:38:43.700 --> 00:38:46.450
I are, you're gonna love this, cuz
there's plenty of stuff to go through and

762
00:38:46.450 --> 00:38:48.530
figure out what does this do,
how's that work.

763
00:38:48.530 --> 00:38:51.120
And Wes, you've done a great job
of walking us through a lot of

764
00:38:51.120 --> 00:38:52.040
those features.

765
00:38:52.040 --> 00:38:54.950
But there's definitely plenty more that
you guys can go through yourselves and

766
00:38:54.950 --> 00:38:57.040
figure out how they work on your own time.

767
00:38:57.040 --> 00:39:00.800
That being said, speaking of time, we
have fully run out of it on this episode.

768
00:39:00.800 --> 00:39:02.500
So we're gonna go ahead and shut her down.

769
00:39:02.500 --> 00:39:05.430
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

770
00:39:05.430 --> 00:39:06.280
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

771
00:39:06.280 --> 00:39:08.261
>> But we'll see you next time.

772
00:39:08.261 --> 00:39:14.408
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes begin their demonstration of provisioning packages with the Imaging Configuration Designer(ICD). They begin by taking you through each necessary step to provision a package. From downloading the the ADK, building the package, and then configuring the provisioned package.
episodes.title: Provisioning Packages with ICD
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.011 --> 00:00:10.011
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.108 --> 00:00:16.288
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.288 --> 00:00:18.331
I am your host, Mr. Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:18.331 --> 00:00:21.861
In today's episode,
we are continuing on with more Windows 10.

5
00:00:21.861 --> 00:00:24.724
And joining us back in the studio again,
our mentor,

6
00:00:24.724 --> 00:00:27.670
our guiding star on this journey,
our Mr. Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:27.670 --> 00:00:28.520
Wes, welcome to the show.

8
00:00:28.520 --> 00:00:29.347
Sir, how's it going today?

9
00:00:29.347 --> 00:00:30.198
>> Man, it's going great.

10
00:00:30.198 --> 00:00:34.552
That's right, we get to dive in to some
more of the enterprise level stuff today,

11
00:00:34.552 --> 00:00:37.139
and we're moving through our Windows 10,
and

12
00:00:37.139 --> 00:00:40.566
that is the second Windows 10
exam unit for the MCSA 7698.

13
00:00:40.566 --> 00:00:43.600
And today we're going to be
looking at provisioning packages.

14
00:00:43.600 --> 00:00:46.990
That's one of the things that they
call out as far as the objectives go.

15
00:00:46.990 --> 00:00:50.987
But the way that they want you to
provision packages is with a newer

16
00:00:50.987 --> 00:00:55.390
technology called
the Windows Image Configuration Designer.

17
00:00:55.390 --> 00:00:57.840
And this one is new to Windows 10,

18
00:00:57.840 --> 00:01:01.500
so you can probably expect to see
something on the exam about it.

19
00:01:01.500 --> 00:01:05.120
So we wanna try and make sure that you're
aware of what you can do with it, and

20
00:01:05.120 --> 00:01:08.680
as well,
show you little bit about how to use it.

21
00:01:08.680 --> 00:01:12.450
Now, and from here on out,
guys, image, configuration,

22
00:01:12.450 --> 00:01:15.010
designer, I'm just gonna call it ICD,
guys.

23
00:01:15.010 --> 00:01:17.700
So I'm gonna hit you with an acronym for
the rest of this episode, so

24
00:01:17.700 --> 00:01:20.300
just be aware of that.

25
00:01:20.300 --> 00:01:22.310
It's part of what's known as
the Windows Assessment and

26
00:01:22.310 --> 00:01:25.270
Deployment Kit, Windows ADK.

27
00:01:25.270 --> 00:01:29.530
So let's kinda talk a little bit
about what this allows us to do.

28
00:01:29.530 --> 00:01:32.293
This allows us to prepare images.

29
00:01:32.293 --> 00:01:35.521
You might have remembered in
earlier editions of Windows,

30
00:01:35.521 --> 00:01:39.210
you would use something known as
the Windows System Image Manager.

31
00:01:39.210 --> 00:01:40.150
And what was WinSIM?

32
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:42.350
WinSIM was a way to
create an answer file so

33
00:01:42.350 --> 00:01:45.950
that if you are doing image deployment,
you could automate the process, and

34
00:01:45.950 --> 00:01:50.350
then we wouldn't have to sit down at the
computer here and answer these questions.

35
00:01:50.350 --> 00:01:52.050
What is the first user?

36
00:01:52.050 --> 00:01:55.350
Type in the username and the password,
all the keyboard arrangement.

37
00:01:55.350 --> 00:01:57.752
Even for that matter, join the domain.

38
00:01:57.752 --> 00:01:59.519
We could just create an answer file,

39
00:01:59.519 --> 00:02:02.780
which like we talked about when we
mentioned in a previous episode.

40
00:02:02.780 --> 00:02:06.370
Like for instance, USMT,
it uses XML-based configuration.

41
00:02:06.370 --> 00:02:10.880
So what would happen is when you
connect to the deployment server,

42
00:02:10.880 --> 00:02:13.320
first thing you do is you pull down WinPE,
and

43
00:02:13.320 --> 00:02:15.050
the next thing you would do
is you pull down your image.

44
00:02:15.050 --> 00:02:18.691
Now, as a part of the image, as these
configuration passes go, it would also

45
00:02:18.691 --> 00:02:22.052
look back to the deployment server and
would pull down the answer file,

46
00:02:22.052 --> 00:02:26.197
typically called an unattended file,and it
would answer all these questions for you,

47
00:02:26.197 --> 00:02:27.490
automating the process.

48
00:02:27.490 --> 00:02:29.089
Well, with the Windows 10,

49
00:02:29.089 --> 00:02:32.717
we have something that allows us to
do pretty much that same thing, but

50
00:02:32.717 --> 00:02:36.110
we can also baking things like
what they call deployment assets.

51
00:02:36.110 --> 00:02:40.070
So, if I have drivers that I wanna go
a little bit further and not just entering

52
00:02:40.070 --> 00:02:44.230
the runtime configuration, but we wanna
bake in things like Windows updates and

53
00:02:44.230 --> 00:02:48.120
drivers and language packages,
we can do that.

54
00:02:48.120 --> 00:02:49.610
And what we can do is turn around and

55
00:02:49.610 --> 00:02:52.670
bundle the whole thing
up into one package.

56
00:02:52.670 --> 00:02:55.200
And then like we've shown you with
the Deployment Image Servicing Manager,

57
00:02:55.200 --> 00:02:58.030
if I've got that image
sitting up on the server, and

58
00:02:58.030 --> 00:03:01.240
I need to to do offline servicing,
no problem.

59
00:03:01.240 --> 00:03:04.370
We can mount that image, slipstream the
package in, and then when we deploy it out

60
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:07.590
to our computers, well,
we've got the configurations that we need.

61
00:03:07.590 --> 00:03:11.412
So that's a little bit about
what the Windows, or ICD is,

62
00:03:11.412 --> 00:03:14.230
I'm gonna get that wrong if I keep trying.

63
00:03:14.230 --> 00:03:14.880
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

64
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:18.970
>> ICD does for us, so let's go ahead,
and let's jump right in here.

65
00:03:18.970 --> 00:03:22.890
I've got a Windows machine here
already ready to go for us, and

66
00:03:22.890 --> 00:03:26.095
this is in the same location.

67
00:03:26.095 --> 00:03:28.470
Just look at some of these
deployment tools again, so

68
00:03:28.470 --> 00:03:30.760
you're aware of where they are.

69
00:03:30.760 --> 00:03:34.308
We're gonna dive down in
here to our C: here, and

70
00:03:34.308 --> 00:03:40.407
then we'll jump into Program Files x86,
then we're gonna be in the Windows Kits.

71
00:03:40.407 --> 00:03:43.484
And for me,
Windows Kits are only gonna be 10.

72
00:03:43.484 --> 00:03:44.912
You could see 8.1 here.

73
00:03:44.912 --> 00:03:48.147
You could, if you're still
maybe doing configurations for

74
00:03:48.147 --> 00:03:50.693
8.1, you can have more
than one kit in here.

75
00:03:50.693 --> 00:03:54.362
So you wanna go with the one that says 10,
because hence, Windows 10.

76
00:03:54.362 --> 00:03:57.825
And then on top of that, we're gonna dive
down in here into the assessment and

77
00:03:57.825 --> 00:03:58.855
deployment toolkit.

78
00:03:58.855 --> 00:04:01.736
Remember, this is ADK, and a part of ADK,

79
00:04:01.736 --> 00:04:06.882
you could see here is the Imaging and
Configuration Designer, right?

80
00:04:06.882 --> 00:04:11.670
So just know where that path is
just in case they ask you about it.

81
00:04:11.670 --> 00:04:16.490
Now, to launch this, we don't launch
it from inside of this location.

82
00:04:16.490 --> 00:04:21.300
Thank goodness, we've got our start
menu that, yes, has returned.

83
00:04:21.300 --> 00:04:23.110
We're gonna go ahead and
go to our start menu.

84
00:04:23.110 --> 00:04:27.970
We'll go to the all apps option and
scroll all the way down, and

85
00:04:27.970 --> 00:04:31.310
around the area of our Windows accessories
and administrative functionality,

86
00:04:31.310 --> 00:04:34.630
if you happen to have RSAT installed,
you will see Windows Kits.

87
00:04:34.630 --> 00:04:38.140
And in Windows Kits, you'll notice,

88
00:04:38.140 --> 00:04:42.200
don't worry about these new options,
it just means recently installed.

89
00:04:42.200 --> 00:04:45.340
You could see that the Windows
System Image Manager, it's still

90
00:04:45.340 --> 00:04:49.460
part of the deployment kits where we
could create those unattend files,

91
00:04:49.460 --> 00:04:51.300
but again, new to Windows 10,

92
00:04:51.300 --> 00:04:56.030
we now have the Windows Imaging and
Configuration Designer, or ICD.

93
00:04:57.350 --> 00:05:02.540
Notice that this does
require local administrative

94
00:05:02.540 --> 00:05:07.290
privileges in order to run it,
hence the UAC triggering, all right?

95
00:05:07.290 --> 00:05:10.690
And man, I tell you, looks like a lot
of stuff here, doesn't it, Dan?

96
00:05:10.690 --> 00:05:12.315
>> Yeah, very, very overwhelming.

97
00:05:12.315 --> 00:05:12.988
That's right.

98
00:05:12.988 --> 00:05:13.742
>> [LAUGH].

99
00:05:13.742 --> 00:05:15.738
They've made it a little
bit more simplistic.

100
00:05:15.738 --> 00:05:20.110
And the one reason that I say that is that
by comparison, if you were to start to

101
00:05:20.110 --> 00:05:24.885
open up, like for instance, the Windows
System Image Manager, when it opened up,

102
00:05:24.885 --> 00:05:28.115
and you would load in your
image to start the answer file,

103
00:05:28.115 --> 00:05:30.234
you'd have a lot of confusing text.

104
00:05:30.234 --> 00:05:33.822
So they've actually made this interface
simplistic and more tile-based,

105
00:05:33.822 --> 00:05:36.912
like pretty much everything else,
as in Windows products today,

106
00:05:36.912 --> 00:05:40.290
whether it's server or
whether that's the client side.

107
00:05:40.290 --> 00:05:41.560
Now, the first thing that we have to do,

108
00:05:41.560 --> 00:05:42.770
we'll look at a couple
of different things.

109
00:05:42.770 --> 00:05:46.040
If I've already got a project ready to go,
I can open it, and

110
00:05:46.040 --> 00:05:47.170
I can modify it from here.

111
00:05:47.170 --> 00:05:50.580
So that's a good thing, so you can always,
If you already got your package created,

112
00:05:50.580 --> 00:05:54.740
you just point this to that, or
point this software to that package, and

113
00:05:54.740 --> 00:05:59.300
then you could make further modifications,
which is nice, and which is really nice.

114
00:05:59.300 --> 00:06:02.462
Here's that Windows image
customization as well, but again,

115
00:06:02.462 --> 00:06:05.987
what they call out on the exam is
provisioning packages there with ICD.

116
00:06:05.987 --> 00:06:08.692
So we're gonna go ahead,
and we're gonna create.

117
00:06:08.692 --> 00:06:12.430
Here you can see a new
