00:13:51.600 --> 00:13:55.760
Let me go ahead real quick and
show you this log while I'm at it here.

252
00:13:55.760 --> 00:13:58.280
And then we'll get back and
we'll troubleshoot that error real quick.

253
00:13:59.390 --> 00:14:03.520
All right so we got Windows and then logs

254
00:14:05.410 --> 00:14:08.680
all right, and we got this one in here,
and if we wanted to.

255
00:14:08.680 --> 00:14:12.820
If we were really, really had the time,
we could go through this log and

256
00:14:12.820 --> 00:14:14.305
try to find the failure.

257
00:14:14.305 --> 00:14:17.420
Tthe good thing is it gives
us a little bit of an idea.

258
00:14:19.280 --> 00:14:25.470
It says cannot find the file specified.

259
00:14:25.470 --> 00:14:32.210
So let me just double-check my
spelling here, project cat.

260
00:14:32.210 --> 00:14:37.500
Gonna do a little troubleshooting
here right on camera, ICD.

261
00:14:37.500 --> 00:14:39.100
>> No pressure, Wes.

262
00:14:39.100 --> 00:14:40.600
>> No pressure, no pressure at all.

263
00:14:40.600 --> 00:14:43.888
Project underscore one.

264
00:14:43.888 --> 00:14:50.590
So, you can usually find
a little bit of a typo.

265
00:14:52.770 --> 00:14:55.650
And sure enough I find
that error right there.

266
00:14:55.650 --> 00:15:01.260
Notice I'm saying Project_01,
0 seems to be the problem.

267
00:15:01.260 --> 00:15:06.770
So let's go ahead and what we'll do is and
we'll take the zero out, right?

268
00:15:06.770 --> 00:15:07.530
>> Just one.

269
00:15:07.530 --> 00:15:08.980
>> Just one, right.

270
00:15:08.980 --> 00:15:10.640
So, we'll take that zero out.

271
00:15:10.640 --> 00:15:13.170
And we'll, go ahead,
and try to rerun this.

272
00:15:13.170 --> 00:15:15.520
And we'll see if the imaging and
there it goes.

273
00:15:15.520 --> 00:15:17.770
And notice how fast that was.

274
00:15:17.770 --> 00:15:20.380
The package, itself,
isn't that big, right?

275
00:15:20.380 --> 00:15:24.920
So it took longer to mount the image,
actually provision

276
00:15:24.920 --> 00:15:29.510
the package inside of this image so
last thing that we needed to do.

277
00:15:29.510 --> 00:15:33.860
Now that we've got that package provision
that we need to actually go ahead and

278
00:15:33.860 --> 00:15:35.500
we're gonna unmount the image.

279
00:15:35.500 --> 00:15:40.504
Now, when we unmount the image again it's
gonna be just another this uncommand here.

280
00:15:40.504 --> 00:15:43.960
This could take a little bit though,
you can see it certainly isn't going

281
00:15:43.960 --> 00:15:47.545
to be as long as how long it took to
provision the package in the image itself.

282
00:15:47.545 --> 00:15:48.995
So we're going to go ahead, and

283
00:15:48.995 --> 00:15:52.059
what we'll do is we'll show you
exactly how to unmount the image and

284
00:15:52.059 --> 00:15:55.034
commit the changes to that image so
that they're not discarded.

285
00:15:55.034 --> 00:15:56.635
And then once that's done,

286
00:15:56.635 --> 00:16:00.850
we'll come back once the image has
been finished saving and unmounting.

287
00:16:00.850 --> 00:16:03.470
So what is our command?

288
00:16:03.470 --> 00:16:08.592
It's gonna be dism /unmount-image

289
00:16:08.592 --> 00:16:13.876
/MountDir:c:\offline, that's

290
00:16:13.876 --> 00:16:19.637
where we put that and we'll do a /commit,

291
00:16:19.637 --> 00:16:24.590
and we'll go ahead and run that.

292
00:16:24.590 --> 00:16:30.960
Now, again, usually what does happen
here is it happens in two stages.

293
00:16:30.960 --> 00:16:36.930
First it goes through the 0 to 100%
on saving the changes to the image,

294
00:16:36.930 --> 00:16:38.480
so committing the changes.

295
00:16:38.480 --> 00:16:41.470
And then the last thing that it does

296
00:16:41.470 --> 00:16:44.470
is it unmounts the image after
it's committed those changes.

297
00:16:44.470 --> 00:16:48.080
So you can see, it takes a little bit
here, cuz it is going through a process of

298
00:16:48.080 --> 00:16:50.290
looking at that image,
inspecting the metadata.

299
00:16:50.290 --> 00:16:51.144
And you could see here,

300
00:16:51.144 --> 00:16:54.240
actually saving the image is going
pretty pretty fairly quickly.

301
00:16:54.240 --> 00:16:56.520
So, we might be able to keep this in here.

302
00:16:56.520 --> 00:16:59.927
I tell you, though, I really think,
once we get to the unmounting process.

303
00:16:59.927 --> 00:17:03.760
You're going to see,
it's certainly not going to move so fast.

304
00:17:03.760 --> 00:17:07.970
So what we'll go ahead and do,
is we'll use the magic of TV and

305
00:17:07.970 --> 00:17:10.180
we'll come back when this is finished.

306
00:17:10.180 --> 00:17:12.250
And you'll see those two
progress bars complete.

307
00:17:12.250 --> 00:17:16.330
So 30% of all your IT career won't be
sitting waiting on a progress bar.

308
00:17:18.260 --> 00:17:19.830
So it looks like it has finished.

309
00:17:19.830 --> 00:17:23.240
You can see we've got here on the desktop,
we've got a couple of progress bars.

310
00:17:23.240 --> 00:17:25.390
First thing it did was it saved the image.

311
00:17:25.390 --> 00:17:27.300
The next thing it did was
it unmounted the image.

312
00:17:27.300 --> 00:17:32.380
So now, we have an image that has not
only had in some of the past episodes,

313
00:17:32.380 --> 00:17:33.750
drivers added to it.

314
00:17:33.750 --> 00:17:39.080
It has also had a package provision to it
with settings, runtime settings included.

315
00:17:39.080 --> 00:17:42.130
Deployment assets like we could have
slip streamed some drivers in there if

316
00:17:42.130 --> 00:17:42.630
we needed to.

317
00:17:42.630 --> 00:17:46.090
In this case, we just took a stand
alone hot fix or a Windows update, and

318
00:17:46.090 --> 00:17:47.660
we slip streamed it into that image.

319
00:17:47.660 --> 00:17:48.740
And we committed the changes,

320
00:17:48.740 --> 00:17:53.000
which is the first progress, saving those
changes to the image then it unmounts it.

321
00:17:53.000 --> 00:17:55.910
Now at this point, if we wanted, we could
turn around and take that WIM file.

322
00:17:55.910 --> 00:17:58.920
Put it on our WDS server,
Windows Deployment Server.

323
00:17:58.920 --> 00:18:00.690
And we could deploy it
out to the computers.

324
00:18:00.690 --> 00:18:02.690
And it would have that
package already installed.

325
00:18:02.690 --> 00:18:06.290
So for the most part the image
configuration designer,

326
00:18:06.290 --> 00:18:09.130
Dan's got a decent interface,
it's not too complex,

327
00:18:09.130 --> 00:18:12.510
once you know some of the commands in
the background it makes it a lot easier.

328
00:18:12.510 --> 00:18:16.020
And you can deploy this to many computers
rather than having a sneaker net in

329
00:18:16.020 --> 00:18:17.510
a decentralized method.

330
00:18:17.510 --> 00:18:18.480
>> Yeah, pretty straight forward.

331
00:18:18.480 --> 00:18:21.480
There's a few commands you got
to know in the PowerShell or

332
00:18:21.480 --> 00:18:23.230
the command prompt as it were.

333
00:18:23.230 --> 00:18:26.885
But you get those things down and of
course you type them correctly right Wes?

334
00:18:26.885 --> 00:18:28.840
[LAUGH] If you learn
anything from Wes Bryan,

335
00:18:28.840 --> 00:18:30.800
it's always check your typing, rIght?

336
00:18:30.800 --> 00:18:32.118
Because that's what get's us every time.

337
00:18:32.118 --> 00:18:33.630
You're like, what, this isn't working?

338
00:18:33.630 --> 00:18:37.629
And it's just the stupid little zero that
you added when you're going through these

339
00:18:37.629 --> 00:18:38.200
commands.

340
00:18:38.200 --> 00:18:42.120
So be very specific,
especially when you're in the exam booth.

341
00:18:42.120 --> 00:18:45.380
They'll probably, they might even try
to hammer you with something like that.

342
00:18:45.380 --> 00:18:49.480
Where the command is just off, even
though it looks right from first glance.

343
00:18:49.480 --> 00:18:51.297
Wes, anything else we need to know
about this before we close her down?

344
00:18:51.297 --> 00:18:53.554
>> No, watch your command syntax or

345
00:18:53.554 --> 00:18:58.452
you could go from hero to zero real quick,
and the zero's do matter.

346
00:18:58.452 --> 00:19:01.290
>> All right well you're a hero to us and
we appreciate you stopping by.

347
00:19:01.290 --> 00:19:04.596
Show us how we can implement the ICD for
our own environment.

348
00:19:04.596 --> 00:19:07.464
So with that being said, we're gonna
go ahead a close down the show,

349
00:19:07.464 --> 00:19:08.680
signing off for ITPro.TV.

350
00:19:08.680 --> 00:19:10.210
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

351
00:19:10.210 --> 00:19:11.200
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

352
00:19:11.200 --> 00:19:12.001
>> We'll see you next time.

353
00:19:12.001 --> 00:19:19.072
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes introduce you to volume activation for Windows 10 clients in an Active Directory domain using the Microsoft Key Management System(KMS). They also show you how to configure and optimize the User Account Control(UAC) using Group Policy.
episodes.title: Windows in an Enterprise Environment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.942 --> 00:00:15.851
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.851 --> 00:00:18.280
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:18.280 --> 00:00:20.390
we continue on with more Windows 10.

5
00:00:20.390 --> 00:00:25.150
And in that series, the guy that's joining
us today in this here studio to lend

6
00:00:25.150 --> 00:00:27.780
the way, is our good friend Mr. Wes Brian.

7
00:00:27.780 --> 00:00:29.010
Wes, welcome back to the show, sir.

8
00:00:29.010 --> 00:00:29.690
How's it going today?

9
00:00:29.690 --> 00:00:31.090
>> Man, it's going great as always.

10
00:00:31.090 --> 00:00:32.410
Great to be here with ITProTV.

11
00:00:32.410 --> 00:00:36.560
That's right, we're jumping back in
more of that Windows 10, the 7698 exam.

12
00:00:36.560 --> 00:00:40.000
And the next topic that we are going
to demonstrating is one that, well,

13
00:00:40.000 --> 00:00:41.735
hey, we really can't demonstrate.

14
00:00:41.735 --> 00:00:45.040
[LAUGH] And that is something
known as volume activation.

15
00:00:45.040 --> 00:00:48.040
It's something that you are going to have
to do inside of an enterprise environment.

16
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:49.680
And I have to tell you guys,
going out the gate,

17
00:00:49.680 --> 00:00:53.810
I would love to show you guys step
by step how to implement this,

18
00:00:53.810 --> 00:00:59.090
implement volume activation service
within your servers and implement KMS.

19
00:00:59.090 --> 00:01:03.680
Unfortunately though, to get things like
what we'll talk about, the KMS host key,

20
00:01:03.680 --> 00:01:09.850
you do have to be a volume licensed
subscriber, if you will, to a Microsoft

21
00:01:09.850 --> 00:01:14.790
contract or you can't really get access
to a key in order to implement this.

22
00:01:14.790 --> 00:01:16.755
>> So is it a hard thing to do Wes,
come on.

23
00:01:16.755 --> 00:01:18.430
[LAUGH]
>> It only takes several

24
00:01:18.430 --> 00:01:22.010
hundreds of thousands of dollars I'm sure
because remember one of the things you

25
00:01:22.010 --> 00:01:25.610
have to prove in volume licensing
is that you have for instance,

26
00:01:25.610 --> 00:01:27.770
there is a few different technologies.

27
00:01:27.770 --> 00:01:29.730
Let's go ahead and
break them down real quick.

28
00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:31.620
There's a couple of them
that are oldies but goodies.

29
00:01:31.620 --> 00:01:34.900
They've been around as a volume
licensing model for a while now.

30
00:01:34.900 --> 00:01:39.090
And the first one is called a multiple
activation key, MAK, all right?

31
00:01:39.090 --> 00:01:41.700
Now we're not gonna spend too
much time on the MAK key,

32
00:01:41.700 --> 00:01:43.770
because it's a very simplistic process.

33
00:01:43.770 --> 00:01:47.760
And if you've ever done an installation
and then an activation of Windows,

34
00:01:47.760 --> 00:01:50.790
it's really no different than what
you would do in the consumer side.

35
00:01:50.790 --> 00:01:53.102
What is it?
Well it's a 25 character if you will

36
00:01:53.102 --> 00:01:56.981
product key just like you would find
on the optical media if you went and

37
00:01:56.981 --> 00:01:59.840
purchased one from a third party reseller.

38
00:01:59.840 --> 00:02:04.260
But the difference here is that
key doesn't typically come

39
00:02:04.260 --> 00:02:07.330
on an individual if you will
installation of Windows.

40
00:02:07.330 --> 00:02:10.960
It's called a multiple application key
because when you join into a volume

41
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:14.310
license subscription with Microsoft, they
give you this key, and they say, okay,

42
00:02:14.310 --> 00:02:18.955
according to your subscription,
you purchased 250 activations.

43
00:02:18.955 --> 00:02:21.080
All right, so you use that key,
that one key,

44
00:02:21.080 --> 00:02:26.290
and it activates 250 instances of
Windows 10 inside your environment.

45
00:02:26.290 --> 00:02:28.290
Or more,
depending on how big a company you are.

46
00:02:28.290 --> 00:02:29.010
Simplistic.

47
00:02:29.010 --> 00:02:30.190
That one's easy to understand.

48
00:02:30.190 --> 00:02:33.694
The other one that's been around for a
while is maybe not so easy to understand,

49
00:02:33.694 --> 00:02:34.488
and that's KMS.

50
00:02:34.488 --> 00:02:38.638
And this is the one, again, where you need
is a certain key in order to demonstrate

51
00:02:38.638 --> 00:02:41.340
it but, KMS is the key management service.

52
00:02:41.340 --> 00:02:44.270
Now, key management service is
different in MAK in the fact that

53
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:46.870
you have a centrally managed host.

54
00:02:46.870 --> 00:02:53.240
That host like a proxy does the
activations on behalf of all the clients.

55
00:02:53.240 --> 00:02:56.130
Now you might say, well why would I use
this over something light that seems

56
00:02:56.130 --> 00:02:58.500
simplistic like the multiple
activation key?

57
00:02:58.500 --> 00:03:02.310
Well, in an environment where you're
completely managed and controlled and

58
00:03:02.310 --> 00:03:05.780
you don't want your clients
reaching out to Windows update.

59
00:03:05.780 --> 00:03:09.660
Well, you don't wanna use a MAK
because KMS, the KMS host internally,

60
00:03:09.660 --> 00:03:15.490
can activate on behalf of all
the internal KMS clients,

61
00:03:15.490 --> 00:03:17.810
and the KMS hosts only
needs to activate once.

62
00:03:17.810 --> 00:03:19.820
Right.
When you install the KMS host key,

63
00:03:19.820 --> 00:03:23.162
which is the key we can't get access to
really, unless you had that subscription,

64
00:03:23.162 --> 00:03:28.830
is installed in the KMS host and then it
goes out to Microsoft, activates one side.

65
00:03:28.830 --> 00:03:32.800
And then from there on out, your machines
internally will just talk to the host, and

66
00:03:32.800 --> 00:03:35.790
there's no more internet connection,
communication really needed.

67
00:03:35.790 --> 00:03:39.190
So that's why you might
implement something like KMS.

68
00:03:39.190 --> 00:03:42.460
Now, some of the facts that you might
need to know about KMS on the exam, and

69
00:03:42.460 --> 00:03:44.210
that's one of the reasons
we want to go into this,

70
00:03:44.210 --> 00:03:48.180
because we want you to be prepared for
the certification exam.

71
00:03:48.180 --> 00:03:50.340
When you go and sit down and
you're in that hot seat,

72
00:03:50.340 --> 00:03:52.760
we want you to get some
of those questions right.

73
00:03:52.760 --> 00:03:55.920
So let's go ahead and,
I've got a diagram here on my desktop, and

74
00:03:55.920 --> 00:03:57.510
we can kinda run through
some of the facts and

75
00:03:57.510 --> 00:03:59.530
then we can talk a little bit
more about how this works.

76
00:03:59.530 --> 00:04:03.680
All right, a KMS host is
the centrally managed server,

77
00:04:03.680 --> 00:04:05.210
it doesn't really have to be a server.

78
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:07.260
It can actually be a work
station if you want.

79
00:04:07.260 --> 00:04:11.230
But it's the centrally managed
device that all of the clients,

80
00:04:11.230 --> 00:04:15.780
KMS clients are these Windows 10
machines that need activation.

81
00:04:15.780 --> 00:04:18.830
All right,
well what they do is contact the KMS host.

82
00:04:18.830 --> 00:04:21.850
All right, now the KMS host will return

83
00:04:21.850 --> 00:04:25.030
an answer back to the kms client
with an activation count.

84
00:04:25.030 --> 00:04:29.100
So there's an activation threshold
that needs to be met before

85
00:04:29.100 --> 00:04:30.210
these machines will even activate.

86
00:04:30.210 --> 00:04:31.530
And that's kind of Count of 25.

87
00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:32.520
All right.

88
00:04:32.520 --> 00:04:36.080
So if my first computer connects,
it's gonna receive an activation count.

89
00:04:36.080 --> 00:04:39.600
If it's the 25th computer or
above, activation occurs.

90
00:04:39.600 --> 00:04:44.540
All right now, the host activates,
we talked about the 25 computer threshold.

91
00:04:44.540 --> 00:04:45.780
That's for Windows clients.

92
00:04:45.780 --> 00:04:50.620
I'm not sure that on the client exam, the
MCSA, they're gonna ask you this question.

93
00:04:50.620 --> 00:04:53.730
But we're gonna throw that here just for
you, just in case.

94
00:04:53.730 --> 00:04:56.090
If it's a server,
it's a little bit different.

95
00:04:56.090 --> 00:04:57.890
The threshold is a lot lower, it's five.

96
00:04:57.890 --> 00:05:01.860
It waits till five serves have
requested activation internally and

97
00:05:01.860 --> 00:05:02.720
then it activates.

98
00:05:02.720 --> 00:05:04.610
Again, I'm not sure if that one's
going to be on the test but

99
00:05:04.610 --> 00:05:07.480
if it is,
you'll have your bases covered for it.

100
00:05:07.480 --> 00:05:13.130
Now, so the client sends an activation
request to the KMS host for validation.

101
00:05:13.130 --> 00:05:18.740
All right, if the threshold counter,
that count comes back to the client and

102
00:05:18.740 --> 00:05:21.890
it's not the 25th computer
It's not gonna activate.

103
00:05:21.890 --> 00:05:24.880
And then it's gonna retry every two hours.

104
00:05:24.880 --> 00:05:26.430
It's gonna try to contact that host.

105
00:05:26.430 --> 00:05:31.720
And then finally when the activation count
is met, all of the computers activate.

106
00:05:31.720 --> 00:05:32.400
All right.

107
00:05:32.400 --> 00:05:36.360
Now, this next one here that
I want to kind of look at

108
00:05:36.360 --> 00:05:39.090
is the activation is valid for 180 days.

109
00:05:39.090 --> 00:05:42.510
So if, let's say Dan's got a KMS Host and

110
00:05:42.510 --> 00:05:46.890
my client connects to it, receives
its validation, and it's activated.

111
00:05:46.890 --> 00:05:47.590
All right?

112
00:05:47.590 --> 00:05:51.940
Then let's say for whatever reason I lose
connectivity to the network for 180 days,

113
00:05:51.940 --> 00:05:55.590
or maybe the KMS host goes offline for
whatever reason.

114
00:05:55.590 --> 00:06:00.330
That 181st day, my activation is stripped,
it's removed and I'm no longer activated.

115
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:04.760
So, you have to maintain a communication
with the KMS host in order to stay

116
00:06:04.760 --> 00:06:05.770
activated.

117
00:06:05.770 --> 00:06:07.450
Now, the reason I want
to stop there just for

118
00:06:07.450 --> 00:06:12.020
a second is because that is the same thing
in Active Directory based activation.

119
00:06:12.020 --> 00:06:13.020
Now you say, well, wait a second.

120
00:06:13.020 --> 00:06:14.870
What is Active Directory based activation?

121
00:06:14.870 --> 00:06:17.550
Well, we'll get to it,
Into that here in a second.

122
00:06:17.550 --> 00:06:20.940
But that's the third multiple
activation of volume activation,

123
00:06:20.940 --> 00:06:23.500
and it's relatively new to
the Windows environment.

124
00:06:23.500 --> 00:06:25.870
This means that if a computer
is joined to your domain,

125
00:06:25.870 --> 00:06:29.380
you have the volume activation services
installed within the domain, it could

126
00:06:29.380 --> 00:06:32.720
reach out to the domain controller and
it could say, hey, here I am.

127
00:06:32.720 --> 00:06:34.550
And the activation remains.

128
00:06:34.550 --> 00:06:36.130
Now, in active directory,

129
00:06:36.130 --> 00:06:39.830
if your computer doesn't talk to
the domain controller within 180 days,

130
00:06:39.830 --> 00:06:43.410
it loses that trust relationship and
it's kicked off the domain.

131
00:06:43.410 --> 00:06:46.080
When it's kicked off the domain
cuz it can't contact the domain

132
00:06:46.080 --> 00:06:46.920
controller, guess what.

133
00:06:46.920 --> 00:06:49.170
Not only does it lose
its trust relationship,

134
00:06:49.170 --> 00:06:51.630
activation is stripped
off the machine as well.

135
00:06:51.630 --> 00:06:55.980
So these numbers kind of
coincide with each other and

136
00:06:55.980 --> 00:06:58.020
might help you out on
the exam to remember them.

137
00:06:58.020 --> 00:06:59.140
KMS Host is no different.

138
00:06:59.140 --> 00:07:03.715
After 180 days, if I don't communicate
with it, activation is removed.

139
00:07:03.715 --> 00:07:06.835
Now, you're going to say wait a second,
it waits every 180 days?

140
00:07:06.835 --> 00:07:07.665
No, it does not.

141
00:07:07.665 --> 00:07:10.815
It tries every week,
just to say hey, I'm still here.

142
00:07:10.815 --> 00:07:11.665
That's all it needs to do.

143
00:07:11.665 --> 00:07:13.919
If it talks to the KMS host,
says hey, I'm still here,

144
00:07:13.919 --> 00:07:17.327
it maintains it's activation and
then that account renews itself.

145
00:07:17.327 --> 00:07:19.097
So it's constantly trying
to renew this account.

146
00:07:19.097 --> 00:07:22.647
I don't want you to think it's
inefficient in any way, but

147
00:07:22.647 --> 00:07:23.815
that's the maximum threshold.

148
00:07:23.815 --> 00:07:27.440
Now, firewall issues, all right.

149
00:07:27.440 --> 00:07:31.730
The next one I'd like to bring up
is the fact of this KMS traffic.

150
00:07:31.730 --> 00:07:33.180
All right there's
a service on your machine.

151
00:07:33.180 --> 00:07:35.240
It's called a KMS traffic service.

152
00:07:35.240 --> 00:07:38.158
All right, if the firewall is set
that service with an exception then

153
00:07:38.158 --> 00:07:40.310
a communication is going to happen.

154
00:07:40.310 --> 00:07:45.174
All right but remember we're not always
just talking directly to another machine

155
00:07:45.174 --> 00:07:47.158
that might be on the same subnet.

156
00:07:47.158 --> 00:07:49.443
What if this KMS host is
on another subnet, and

157
00:07:49.443 --> 00:07:53.020
we typically are implementing some
kind of ACL between the two subnets,

158
00:07:53.020 --> 00:07:55.672
maybe with a firewall,
maybe with a rule on a router.

159
00:07:55.672 --> 00:07:57.247
We have to make an exemption.

160
00:07:57.247 --> 00:08:02.455
To make sure that that traffic happens,
that traffic traverses over port 1688.

161
00:08:02.455 --> 00:08:03.773
Remember that for the exam.

162
00:08:03.773 --> 00:08:07.849
If they give you a diagram or something
and they say, you're not communicating on

163
00:08:07.849 --> 00:08:11.110
this subnet with a KMS host,
what could possibly be the problem?

164
00:08:12.130 --> 00:08:15.390
If there's a firewall exemption
on the list and it's 1688,

165
00:08:15.390 --> 00:08:18.030
it's probably gonna be the right answer.

166
00:08:18.030 --> 00:08:20.970
Now, one of the other things
I'd like to talk about

167
00:08:20.970 --> 00:08:26.090
is an event viewer error that
might come up on the exam as well.

168
00:08:26.090 --> 00:08:29.420
Because it's common to kms, and
that's when their network goes down.

169
00:08:29.420 --> 00:08:30.882
This is a error, what is it?

170
00:08:30.882 --> 00:08:34.938
It's 12,289,
I know that's kind of a weird number here,

171
00:08:34.938 --> 00:08:37.530
but I want you to remember it for
the exam.

172
00:08:38.830 --> 00:08:41.270
What is it about that error
that's gonna cause problems?

173
00:08:41.270 --> 00:08:44.880
With a client, if you go in and
you check the event in your logs, and

174
00:08:44.880 --> 00:08:46.633
you got 12,2089 there.

175
00:08:46.633 --> 00:08:50.395
Then what happens is, your network
is down, DNS can't resolve names or

176
00:08:50.395 --> 00:08:52.808
you have some kind of
communication problem.

177
00:08:52.808 --> 00:08:56.099
Maybe a firewall,
it kind of blends itself all together.

178
00:08:56.099 --> 00:09:00.679
That's why keeping in mind
with the TCP 1688 port.

179
00:09:00.679 --> 00:09:03.973
You should be good with some
troubleshooting that they might ask you

180
00:09:03.973 --> 00:09:04.968
for KMS on the exam.

181
00:09:04.968 --> 00:09:07.180
That's one of the reasons we
want to touch base with that.

182
00:09:07.180 --> 00:09:10.887
Now that being said,
let's look at the process.

183
00:09:10.887 --> 00:09:13.747
So on my diagram here,
I've got kind of a process,

184
00:09:13.747 --> 00:09:18.350
when the KMS client goes to activate,
there's a four step process that happens.

185
00:09:18.350 --> 00:09:22.664
And you might say maybe a pseudo fifth
step if it doesn't actually activate, but

186
00:09:22.664 --> 00:09:24.660
let's look what's going on here.

187
00:09:24.660 --> 00:09:27.800
In the first step,
what's gonna happen here is

188
00:09:27.800 --> 00:09:33.210
the client is going to check with DNS.

189
00:09:33.210 --> 00:09:37.704
So many services that we have
inside of a corporate environment

190
00:09:37.704 --> 00:09:41.369
are reliant upon DNS to be
able to find the machine.

191
00:09:41.369 --> 00:09:42.575
Look at your domain controller.

192
00:09:42.575 --> 00:09:44.950
When the computer needs to find
a domain controller what does it do?

193
00:09:44.950 --> 00:09:47.841
It queries DNS and says,
I need an SRV record,

194
00:09:47.841 --> 00:09:51.937
service locator record to find
where's the domain controller.

195
00:09:51.937 --> 00:09:54.180
Well that's really no different here.

196
00:09:54.180 --> 00:09:58.660
We need to find the KMS host and
the client doesn't know where the host is.

197
00:09:58.660 --> 00:10:02.490
So the first thing it does
is it checks in with DNS.

198
00:10:02.490 --> 00:10:03.690
It says hey, DNS server,

199
00:10:04.990 --> 00:10:09.370
do you own where this KMS host is that
they're telling me I need to contact?

200
00:10:09.370 --> 00:10:11.350
And DNS looks at its little zone file,

201
00:10:11.350 --> 00:10:16.000
little database with all those entries in
it and says, yeah, here is the KMS host.

202
00:10:16.000 --> 00:10:18.010
So that response there is the second step.

203
00:10:18.010 --> 00:10:20.090
The DNS server responds
back to the client and

204
00:10:20.090 --> 00:10:23.510
says, you can find the KMS
server with this IP address.

205
00:10:23.510 --> 00:10:25.297
The whole name resolution process.

206
00:10:25.297 --> 00:10:30.040
In this case that's a service to
an IP address and it says third step.

207
00:10:30.040 --> 00:10:33.537
Let me send an activation
request over to the KMSO.

208
00:10:33.537 --> 00:10:38.320
So the client's now talking to the KMSOs
and saying, I need to activate.

209
00:10:38.320 --> 00:10:42.870
Now on the fourth step, the KMS host,
who's doing the activation on behalf of

210
00:10:42.870 --> 00:10:47.890
the client, contacts the KMS c lient and
says okay, here's the activation count.

211
00:10:47.890 --> 00:10:53.180
Now, if this is the first KMS client
to communicate with the KMS host,

212
00:10:53.180 --> 00:10:55.850
then there's gonna be that pseudo fifth
step that I was telling you about.

213
00:10:55.850 --> 00:10:59.876
Because what's gonna happen is the KMS
host talks back to the client and

214
00:10:59.876 --> 00:11:01.027
says computer one.

215
00:11:01.027 --> 00:11:05.570
Well computer one isn't the 25th computer,
so there's not gonna be an activation.

216
00:11:05.570 --> 00:11:10.490
Now if I was to throw maybe a client
II in here, what would happen?

217
00:11:10.490 --> 00:11:13.128
Well the client II would go without
redrawing all these errors.

218
00:11:13.128 --> 00:11:15.801
The client II would go
through the same process and

219
00:11:15.801 --> 00:11:19.108
when it decide it was gonna do
it activation with the KMS host,

220
00:11:19.108 --> 00:11:23.518
it's gonna see the activation count comes
back and says, you're computer two.

221
00:11:23.518 --> 00:11:28.671
And then this just cyclic process keeps
happening up until they check every

222
00:11:28.671 --> 00:11:33.738
two hours and the KMS host finally says,
okay, computer 1 or client 1 or

223
00:11:33.738 --> 00:11:39.510
client 2, you are now the 25th
computer then all clients activate.

224
00:11:39.510 --> 00:11:43.120
So in a nutshell that's essentially
what the key management service is

225
00:11:43.120 --> 00:11:43.880
doing for us.

226
00:11:43.880 --> 00:11:48.370
Understand, it does require
a volume license contract.

227
00:11:48.370 --> 00:11:53.314
Now that being said, there's another
one that we wanna talk about,

228
00:11:53.314 --> 00:11:54.859
and we'll go ahead.

229
00:11:54.859 --> 00:11:58.226
Let's talk about some Active Directory,
I don't see it in my notes here.

00:11:58.226 --> 00:12:01.570
Let's talk a little bit about
some Active Directory activation.

231
00:12:01.570 --> 00:12:07.570
Now with Active Directory activation it
relies, a lot like KMS on having that key

232
00:12:07.570 --> 00:12:11.900
available, which you could only basically

233
00:12:11.900 --> 00:12:16.410
You install that on your domain control
and then what happens is the computers

234
00:12:16.410 --> 00:12:20.320
talk to the domain controllers and
they say, hey, I'm a domain member.

235
00:12:20.320 --> 00:12:23.150
You're a domain member,
well when we installed that volume

236
00:12:23.150 --> 00:12:26.240
activation key it created an object

237
00:12:26.240 --> 00:12:28.710
And says, hey, let me apply that to you,

238
00:12:29.990 --> 00:12:34.053
Now this process happens pretty close to
the same way that KMS does in the fact

239
00:12:34.053 --> 00:12:38.074
that it's gonna contact every seven
days just to try to keep that updated.

240
00:12:38.074 --> 00:12:41.244
And every time it communicates with

00:12:41.244 --> 00:12:41.790
GP updates.

00:12:41.790 --> 00:12:43.972
So if I'm doing a group policy update,

00:12:43.972 --> 00:12:46.756
that might actually
trigger the communication.

244
00:12:46.756 --> 00:12:52.010
So the computer maintains its activation
while it's a part of the domain.

245
00:12:52.010 --> 00:12:53.340
When it's kicked off of the domain or

246
00:12:53.340 --> 00:12:55.650
when it loses its trust relationship,
guess what?

247
00:12:55.650 --> 00:12:58.540
Just like I said before,
that activation is removed.

248
00:12:58.540 --> 00:13:03.370
So this is a good way to manage
the activation on multiple machines in

249
00:13:03.370 --> 00:13:07.690
an environment that you're already gonna
have existing within your Enterprise,

250
00:13:07.690 --> 00:13:11.710
like domain controllers and
with just a couple extra steps.

Well the ActivationID is what Microsoft

00:17:52.250 --> 00:17:53.580
Now, boy isn't that confusing?

00:17:53.580 --> 00:17:54.596
So what does that mean?

339
00:17:54.596 --> 00:17:57.330
All right [LAUGH] well

340
00:17:57.330 --> 00:18:00.110
tell you what's going on when
you activate, all right?

341
00:18:00.110 --> 00:18:04.210
When you install your operating system,
it creates and stores in the registry,

342
00:18:04.210 --> 00:18:08.800
the H-Key local machine, something
known as a hardware identifier, right.

343
00:18:08.800 --> 00:18:13.510
And then with your product
key you get that, excuse me,

344
00:18:13.510 --> 00:18:18.560
with your media, you get a product key
that license the installation, all right?

345
00:18:18.560 --> 00:18:24.450
When you activate, you're setting the
hardware identifier and the product ID,

346
00:18:24.450 --> 00:18:29.080
which is basically made
from your product key.

347
00:18:29.080 --> 00:18:33.110
You're sending both of them over
to Microsoft's activation servers.

348
00:18:33.110 --> 00:18:36.965

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike talk about configuring networking and how to troubleshoot network connections. They examine command line utilities like ipconfig, ping, netstat, tracert, and route print. They also demonstrate some PowerShell cmdlets like Get-NetIPAddress, Get-NetRoute, and Test-Connection.

00:25:37.019 --> 00:25:40.082
So, I can do a test connection and
I can do the same thing.

487
00:25:40.082 --> 00:25:45.160
I can do, for instance,
we'll go ahead and skip right out.

488
00:25:45.160 --> 00:25:49.510
Notice that I do have communication here,
is returning replies.

489
00:25:49.510 --> 00:25:54.532
And notice over on the right-hand side
that I have a fairly low latency.

490
00:25:54.532 --> 00:25:59.076
So that's the equivalent
inside the PowerShell,

491
00:25:59.076 --> 00:26:02.569
if you want to do a ping type of command.

492
00:26:02.569 --> 00:26:05.160
All right,
now we've got a couple other ones.

493
00:26:05.160 --> 00:26:06.750
And I'll tell you, Mike,
I'm gonna go ahead and

494
00:26:06.750 --> 00:26:09.710
I'm gonna switch it up just a little
bit here because I know that

495
00:26:09.710 --> 00:26:12.590
the next thing I wanted to talk
about are the wireless interface.

496
00:26:12.590 --> 00:26:14.660
I think I'm gonna go ahead and just
stick with some of these utilities and

497
00:26:14.660 --> 00:26:17.190
then we'll come back to
the wireless interface here.

498
00:26:17.190 --> 00:26:19.090
The next one is trace RT, right?

499
00:26:19.090 --> 00:26:22.150
You might have heard it called trace
route in other operating systems.

500
00:26:22.150 --> 00:26:24.600
Sometimes even in Windows
we call it trace route.

501
00:26:24.600 --> 00:26:28.670
Trace RT, like ping that we've seen and
test connection,

502
00:26:28.670 --> 00:26:33.750
are using ICMP in order
to discover the various

503
00:26:33.750 --> 00:26:38.170
hops that a packet takes as it
makes its way across the Internet.

504
00:26:38.170 --> 00:26:41.530
So to go ahead and use maybe an IP
address that we've already used here,

505
00:26:41.530 --> 00:26:43.839
let me go ahead and
do a trace here on my computer.

506
00:26:43.839 --> 00:26:47.618
I'll do a tracert, and
maybe we'll do a 4.2.2.1.

507
00:26:47.618 --> 00:26:49.850
And we'll go ahead and we'll let this run.

508
00:26:49.850 --> 00:26:54.680
Now you can see, and yeah, that is
a top level Internet backbone provider.

509
00:26:54.680 --> 00:26:57.400
Root hit server there, you could see that.

510
00:26:57.400 --> 00:26:59.670
Mike's over here shaking my head,
he really knows dying.

511
00:26:59.670 --> 00:27:01.380
He's like, yeah,
I've seen that one before.

512
00:27:01.380 --> 00:27:02.760
But notice what's going on here.

513
00:27:02.760 --> 00:27:07.360
Notice that what I can see here
are the routers, the connectivity

514
00:27:07.360 --> 00:27:11.950
devices that this passes through as
it makes its way to its destination.

515
00:27:11.950 --> 00:27:14.570
You'd say, well, Wes,
can you control any of those?

516
00:27:14.570 --> 00:27:16.100
Absolutely not.

517
00:27:16.100 --> 00:27:21.990
Maybe this first one we might have control
over, right, 10.1.230.11 or .1, excuse me.

518
00:27:21.990 --> 00:27:26.398
That's our internal router, if you will,
that's our default gateway.

519
00:27:26.398 --> 00:27:29.050
But where this information
does come in handy is

520
00:27:29.050 --> 00:27:32.210
all businesses have a local
ISP that they use, right?

521
00:27:32.210 --> 00:27:36.180
And I could see that this information is
going across grucom, right, that's our

522
00:27:36.180 --> 00:27:40.610
GRU, Gainesville Regional Utility company
here and that's who our local ISP is.

523
00:27:40.610 --> 00:27:43.450
If I see timeouts in this
location then what I know is that

524
00:27:43.450 --> 00:27:45.880
they're having a problem on their network,
then I could call them.

525
00:27:45.880 --> 00:27:48.610
I could say you guys have any outages,
we might need a plan for that?

526
00:27:48.610 --> 00:27:51.060
And they can tell me, no sir,
we don't have any outages,

527
00:27:51.060 --> 00:27:53.369
even though you might be able to see it,
just kidding.

528
00:27:53.369 --> 00:27:55.942
>> [LAUGH] And
then two in some corporate environments,

529
00:27:55.942 --> 00:27:59.861
they're heavily routed where you've got
many different subnets and it's not

530
00:27:59.861 --> 00:28:03.912
as small and easy as our little network
here, one hop and we're out to the public.

531
00:28:03.912 --> 00:28:06.753
But what if you've got
a company where there's four or

532
00:28:06.753 --> 00:28:10.040
five hops to get through before
you make it out to the Internet?

533
00:28:10.040 --> 00:28:13.394
If one of those routers is holding up
packets or dropping packets, beneficial to

534
00:28:13.394 --> 00:28:16.880
know cuz now I can talk to somebody and
see if we can get that straightened out.

535
00:28:16.880 --> 00:28:17.650
>> That's right.

536
00:28:17.650 --> 00:28:20.440
And that last one, though,
you start getting down here towards those

537
00:28:20.440 --> 00:28:24.700
lower ones and sometimes you end up with
the IBPs, the Internet Backbone Providers.

538
00:28:24.700 --> 00:28:26.220
You could see right here
this is level three.

539
00:28:26.220 --> 00:28:29.280
It's one of those, you guys really
can't call them and say, hey,

540
00:28:29.280 --> 00:28:30.300
what wrong with your network?

541
00:28:30.300 --> 00:28:33.419
They have some of the best network
engineers in the world that are trained to

542
00:28:33.419 --> 00:28:34.966
respond to these things in seconds.

543
00:28:34.966 --> 00:28:36.486
So if you're aware of the problem,

544
00:28:36.486 --> 00:28:39.642
I can almost guarantee you they were
aware of it before you ever got there.

545
00:28:39.642 --> 00:28:40.442
>> All right, yeah.

546
00:28:40.442 --> 00:28:42.313
>> So good thing to have.

547
00:28:42.313 --> 00:28:45.631
>> There's a couple of options
you can hand this as well, so for

548
00:28:45.631 --> 00:28:48.510
instance notice that it's
doing name resolution.

549
00:28:48.510 --> 00:28:51.210
If I want to speed it up but
I just want to kind of see the hops,

550
00:28:51.210 --> 00:28:55.590
I can just add a D here, -D.

551
00:28:55.590 --> 00:28:56.480
Did I do that right?

552
00:28:57.660 --> 00:29:00.460
Maybe got to put that on the inside here.

553
00:29:00.460 --> 00:29:03.520
Trace RT, try that there.

554
00:29:04.910 --> 00:29:06.550
Yep, there we go.

555
00:29:06.550 --> 00:29:08.160
Didn't like the position
of the switch there.

556
00:29:08.160 --> 00:29:10.690
Put the switch before the IP address.

557
00:29:10.690 --> 00:29:14.380
And notice that I don't have
any of those names here.

558
00:29:14.380 --> 00:29:18.540
And again, if I'm looking at just
a quick way to get some information and

559
00:29:18.540 --> 00:29:22.360
just want to find out if it can
connect and if there's a breakdown in

560
00:29:22.360 --> 00:29:25.600
communication between the source and
destination, I can find it out here.

561
00:29:25.600 --> 00:29:27.990
And I certainly don't have
to resolve the names.

562
00:29:27.990 --> 00:29:31.693
Couple of other options that you can do if
you use the dash h, you could tell it how

563
00:29:31.693 --> 00:29:35.470
many hops you wanna go and, in fact,
I wouldn't even really maybe change this.

564
00:29:35.470 --> 00:29:37.820
By default, it does a maximum of 30 hops.

565
00:29:37.820 --> 00:29:42.530
If you're getting close to 30 hops,
you might say, well, I only want five.

566
00:29:42.530 --> 00:29:45.050
So if you wanna throttle that back,
you can too.

567
00:29:45.050 --> 00:29:49.590
You can also force it to do IPv4 or
force it to do IPv6, all right.

568
00:29:49.590 --> 00:29:55.780
Now with the dash four option or the dash
six option, in case you are testing those.

569
00:29:55.780 --> 00:29:56.630
All right.

570
00:29:56.630 --> 00:30:00.090
So that's one of the things
that you can use as well.

571
00:30:00.090 --> 00:30:05.660
The other one that I might want to look at
is going to be the route print command,

572
00:30:05.660 --> 00:30:06.960
route in general.

573
00:30:06.960 --> 00:30:11.270
If you need to see the routing table, for
whatever reason you might need to see

574
00:30:11.270 --> 00:30:14.480
the routing table inside of your computer,
you can do that.

575
00:30:14.480 --> 00:30:15.900
You can do it inside
of the command prompt.

576
00:30:15.900 --> 00:30:17.530
Let me show you what I mean here.

577
00:30:17.530 --> 00:30:22.060
So for instance, let me go ahead and
clear the screen and if I do a route and

578
00:30:22.060 --> 00:30:26.230
I do print, all right,
it shows me the local routing table.

579
00:30:26.230 --> 00:30:29.772
And I can see that up top
here I have the interfaces,

580
00:30:29.772 --> 00:30:31.970
all right, the list of interfaces,

581
00:30:31.970 --> 00:30:37.930
I can see the IPv4 routing table as
well as the IPv6 routing table, as well.

582
00:30:37.930 --> 00:30:40.420
Well, maybe you're not really looking for
the IPv6 routing table.

583
00:30:40.420 --> 00:30:41.930
Maybe that's not what you're looking for.

584
00:30:41.930 --> 00:30:44.650
Maybe you're just looking for
the IPv4 routing table.

585
00:30:44.650 --> 00:30:48.550
Well, you can filter this down
too by just putting a -4 there.

586
00:30:49.620 --> 00:30:51.554
Notice IPv6 is filtered out.

587
00:30:51.554 --> 00:30:56.981
Likewise, I could put a -6 there if
I need to, and it just gives me IPv6.

588
00:30:56.981 --> 00:30:59.676
Couple of the options I would know, add,

589
00:30:59.676 --> 00:31:03.260
route-add adds a route
to the routing table.

590
00:31:03.260 --> 00:31:05.910
Route print we've looked at,
shows you the output of the routing table,

591
00:31:05.910 --> 00:31:07.670
what's currently in the routing table.

592
00:31:07.670 --> 00:31:09.980
I can also do a route delete.

593
00:31:09.980 --> 00:31:14.781
And then, whatever the route is,
you can delete it out of there, too.

594
00:31:14.781 --> 00:31:17.828
And then change makes modifications,
likewise.

595
00:31:17.828 --> 00:31:20.230
Now, there's also a PowerShell
equivalent to this, too.

596
00:31:20.230 --> 00:31:24.940
I can do a get-netroute, and
I believe, if I remember right,

597
00:31:24.940 --> 00:31:27.880
Mike, I might want to
format this into a list.

598
00:31:27.880 --> 00:31:29.524
That's definitely not any easier.

599
00:31:29.524 --> 00:31:31.156
[LAUGH] Let's try the table.

600
00:31:31.156 --> 00:31:31.900
Yeah, there we go.

601
00:31:31.900 --> 00:31:32.990
[LAUGH] The table.

602
00:31:32.990 --> 00:31:34.600
You can filter the output and

603
00:31:34.600 --> 00:31:37.490
what you're seeing here is you're
seeing the PowerShell equivalent to

604
00:31:37.490 --> 00:31:41.235
the routing table that we see with the
route print option so keep that in mind.

605
00:31:41.235 --> 00:31:45.092
Get-netroute and all I did is I piped
it out to the formats, I say that here,

606
00:31:45.092 --> 00:31:50.010
that format table, yeah, [LAUGH] cuz the
list certainly didn't do anything for us.

607
00:31:50.010 --> 00:31:53.596
>> All right, Wes, great discussion and
great look at some of those utilities and

608
00:31:53.596 --> 00:31:56.540
commands that we can use when
we're troubleshooting network and

609
00:31:56.540 --> 00:31:58.120
connectivity in Windows.

610
00:31:58.120 --> 00:31:59.250
So, we thank you for that, Wes.

611
00:31:59.250 --> 00:32:01.467
We hope everybody out
there enjoyed watching.

612
00:32:01.467 --> 00:32:04.570
Signing off for ITPro TV,
I've been your host, Mike Roderick.

613
00:32:04.570 --> 00:32:05.363
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

614
00:32:05.363 --> 00:32:07.703
>> And we'll see you next time.

615
00:32:07.703 --> 00:32:12.435
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike continue their discussion on establishing and troubleshooting network connections. They start with some utilities like netsh, nslookup, and Resolve-DNSName. Then they look at VPN connections and demonstrate setting up App-triggering VPN connections.
episodes.title: Configure Networking Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.275 --> 00:00:10.275
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.408 --> 00:00:15.049
Hello.
Welcome to another exciting episode here

3
00:00:15.049 --> 00:00:15.768
at ITProTV.

4
00:00:15.768 --> 00:00:18.606
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing installing and

5
00:00:18.606 --> 00:00:19.800
configuring Windows.

6
00:00:19.800 --> 00:00:23.350
Specifically in this episode we're
actually continuing our look

7
00:00:23.350 --> 00:00:24.420
at configuring networking.

8
00:00:24.420 --> 00:00:25.220
So this is a part two.

9
00:00:25.220 --> 00:00:28.810
If you missed the first part,
make sure you go back and check that out.

10
00:00:28.810 --> 00:00:31.950
And here to help us continue our
journey with configuring networking

11
00:00:31.950 --> 00:00:32.780
is Mr. Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:32.780 --> 00:00:33.720
How you doing, Wes?

13
00:00:33.720 --> 00:00:37.900
>> Doing okay, before I get done with this
one, it might be another mini series or

14
00:00:37.900 --> 00:00:39.420
a novel there, for sure.

15
00:00:39.420 --> 00:00:41.290
But there are some
things we wanna go over.

16
00:00:41.290 --> 00:00:42.550
Keep in mind, in the first episode,

17
00:00:42.550 --> 00:00:46.470
we looked at some of the things you can do
inside of the graphical user interface.

18
00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:49.510
We'll take a look at a couple
of those options, as well.

19
00:00:49.510 --> 00:00:50.770
And we looked at some of the commands.

20
00:00:50.770 --> 00:00:55.970
Now I'm going to go ahead and continue on
in the commands where we left off because,

21
00:00:55.970 --> 00:00:57.552
I talked too much in the first episode.

22
00:00:57.552 --> 00:01:00.120
So, coming back at you here
were going to dive right

23
00:01:00.120 --> 00:01:02.700
back into our command prompt here.

24
00:01:02.700 --> 00:01:07.060
Power shell again, one of the last
things we looked at in the last episode.

25
00:01:07.060 --> 00:01:09.150
We looked at the routing table and

26
00:01:09.150 --> 00:01:12.790
a couple of different ways that
you can view that routing table.

27
00:01:12.790 --> 00:01:15.590
One of the things that we didn't
really talk about too much was

28
00:01:15.590 --> 00:01:16.980
name resolution, right?

29
00:01:16.980 --> 00:01:21.190
We talked a little bit about DNS,
but not really too much.

30
00:01:21.190 --> 00:01:25.180
So let's talk about some commands that
you can use in order to troubleshoot DNS.

31
00:01:25.180 --> 00:01:27.210
Well you've got an oldie but
goodie, right.

32
00:01:27.210 --> 00:01:28.920
You've got NS lookup and

33
00:01:28.920 --> 00:01:31.680
I want you to remember,
NS lookup comes in a couple of flavors and

34
00:01:31.680 --> 00:01:36.920
it really depends on how much you need to
do when you're talking to a DNS server.

35
00:01:36.920 --> 00:01:37.980
Most of us for basic and

36
00:01:37.980 --> 00:01:40.600
the clients, we're gonna use
what's known as interactive mode.

37
00:01:40.600 --> 00:01:44.080
Interactive mode right,
like you can see here is just saying,

38
00:01:44.080 --> 00:01:49.048
NS lookup when I say
something like www.bing and,

39
00:01:49.048 --> 00:01:51.870
.com, right.

40
00:01:51.870 --> 00:01:53.310
Takes a second and what does it do?

41
00:01:53.310 --> 00:01:56.810
It looks at the interface
assign DNS server, right.

42
00:01:56.810 --> 00:02:01.700
It's IP address and it says, okay let me
send a request out to that DNS server,

43
00:02:01.700 --> 00:02:03.270
let's see if it can resolve it for me.

44
00:02:03.270 --> 00:02:07.470
In this case,
I can see that any.edge.bing.com

45
00:02:07.470 --> 00:02:12.430
there resolves to this IP address so, you
can see that we do have name resolution.

46
00:02:12.430 --> 00:02:15.210
Maybe I wanna test a specific DNS server,
right?

47
00:02:15.210 --> 00:02:19.750
Maybe I'm wondering if my internal DNS
server is actually doing the resolution.

48
00:02:19.750 --> 00:02:20.810
Well, guess what?

49
00:02:20.810 --> 00:02:23.236
You can always bounce these
off of other DNS servers,

50
00:02:23.236 --> 00:02:24.880
rather than one that is
assigned to the interface.

51
00:02:24.880 --> 00:02:28.810
So for instance, if I redo this and
I decide that I'm going to put another

52
00:02:28.810 --> 00:02:33.920
server address out here, if I can type it
all right, I can do nslookup www.bing.com

53
00:02:33.920 --> 00:02:38.030
and now I'm going to put an address beside
it and what it has done it has actually

54
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:43.920
sent this request out to the IP address
the DDS server IP address if you will.

55
00:02:43.920 --> 00:02:46.660
Of the same server that we were
looking at in the first episode.

56
00:02:46.660 --> 00:02:48.390
So notice that all I did is said,
you know what?

57
00:02:48.390 --> 00:02:50.990
I wanna bounce this off
another DNS server.

58
00:02:50.990 --> 00:02:52.420
And so what does this do for me?

59
00:02:52.420 --> 00:02:56.650
This lets me know that
this machine can resolve

60
00:02:56.650 --> 00:03:00.350
an IP address if it hits a DNS
server that can respond back to it.

61
00:03:00.350 --> 00:03:02.010
All right, so again we can use this.

62
00:03:02.010 --> 00:03:06.230
The other flavor of nslookup,
a little bit more detailed.

63
00:03:06.230 --> 00:03:09.210
And again, I'm not so sure you have to
worry about this on the client exam,

64
00:03:09.210 --> 00:03:10.710
but I do just want to make mention of it.

65
00:03:10.710 --> 00:03:13.900
And if you hit nslookup and you dive in
there, notice it's a little bit different.

66
00:03:13.900 --> 00:03:16.650
Notice it's a little bit,
my cursor's changed a little bit.

67
00:03:16.650 --> 00:03:19.580
And if I do a question mark here,
I've got a lot of options.

68
00:03:19.580 --> 00:03:23.120
Now whether you get any
of this information back.

69
00:03:23.120 --> 00:03:25.690
Chances are you're not gonna get some
of this information back because,

70
00:03:25.690 --> 00:03:29.570
it's very sensitive and they certainly
don't want you to ask a DNS server for

71
00:03:29.570 --> 00:03:31.810
more information than you
really should have access to.

72
00:03:31.810 --> 00:03:35.860
But it does give you the option that
you can expand on the questions or

73
00:03:35.860 --> 00:03:38.820
the requests that you send to
the DNS server if you're doing

74
00:03:38.820 --> 00:03:40.970
name resolution testing.

75
00:03:40.970 --> 00:03:45.420
All right, so let me go ahead and,
I believe it's just exit, there we go.

76
00:03:45.420 --> 00:03:50.280
And let me clear the screen out here,
provided I can spell clear.

77
00:03:50.280 --> 00:03:53.170
Right, and well, do we have
a PowerShell equivalent to this?

78
00:03:53.170 --> 00:03:55.120
Well, the answer is yes, yes we do.

79
00:03:55.120 --> 00:04:00.960
We've got the resolve and
here's where I absolutely love PowerShell.

80
00:04:00.960 --> 00:04:03.220
I don't have to type the whole thing out.

81
00:04:03.220 --> 00:04:05.260
I just have to know,
close to the commandlet.

82
00:04:05.260 --> 00:04:08.420
Now, you might get a text-based
answer on the exam.

83
00:04:08.420 --> 00:04:11.470
It might not have any kind of simulation,
or

84
00:04:11.470 --> 00:04:13.470
like they say,
performance-based questions.

85
00:04:13.470 --> 00:04:15.520
So, don't just rely on
the tabbing feature.

86
00:04:15.520 --> 00:04:18.340
As you practice it,
definitely use that tab functionality,

87
00:04:18.340 --> 00:04:20.550
because if you don't quite
know the commandlet, but

88
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:23.930
you're wanting to memorize it, the tab
functionality can fill it in for you.

89
00:04:23.930 --> 00:04:26.990
Notice we have resolve-dns name.

90
00:04:26.990 --> 00:04:30.590
All right and
I can put a name parameter on this and

91
00:04:30.590 --> 00:04:35.460
I can do the same thing www.bing.com.

92
00:04:35.460 --> 00:04:36.635
Right, I run this and

93
00:04:36.635 --> 00:04:40.500

Especially with these modern applications

Well now we can set it up to where when

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike wrap up their look at configuring networking with a look at DirectAccess. They discuss all of the components that make up a DirectAccess solution, explaining where they are deployed on the network and their function. They explain how DirectAccess works, determining the users location and building the tunnels.

Now, one of the things that also happens,

Well, the one good thing about

First of all,

With Windows, if you're implementing

57
00:02:47.080 --> 00:02:50.930
The other benefit to
Direct Access is the fact that,

00:02:50.930 --> 00:02:53.810
not only does it allow you to

00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:56.710

That's CIA triad, right?

00:03:14.330 --> 00:03:19.270

00:11:30.980 --> 00:11:33.250

00:11:33.250 --> 00:11:34.520

Back to group policy.

00:11:35.550 --> 00:11:40.070
When you deploy Direct Access, it

00:11:40.070 --> 00:11:44.800

00:11:44.800 --> 00:11:47.290

00:11:50.830 --> 00:11:55.820

00:11:59.300 --> 00:12:04.370

00:12:04.370 --> 00:12:05.910
And it says, if you're looking for

00:12:05.910 --> 00:12:11.040

It says, if you're looking for

00:12:47.730 --> 00:12:51.860

00:13:07.860 --> 00:13:09.900

00:13:15.990 --> 00:13:17.405
All right, so what happens from there?

00:13:19.309 --> 00:13:22.530
It ends up building two tunnels, right?

00:13:22.530 --> 00:13:23.840
Two IPsec tunnels.

You might say, well,

00:13:26.700 --> 00:13:29.870
In part of deploying

00:13:29.870 --> 00:13:33.950

00:13:37.960 --> 00:13:40.830
The first tunnel that it's gonna do,

00:13:40.830 --> 00:13:43.680

00:13:43.680 --> 00:13:44.690

00:13:44.690 --> 00:13:48.200

00:13:48.200 --> 00:13:51.940

00:13:51.940 --> 00:13:53.030

00:13:57.370 --> 00:14:02.020

00:14:02.020 --> 00:14:04.710

00:14:04.710 --> 00:14:07.090

275
00:14:07.090 --> 00:14:10.550
So, keep in mind that the NRPT is

00:14:10.550 --> 00:14:13.040
something that's deployed
through group policy.

277
00:14:13.040 --> 00:14:15.950
It alters the way we normally implement,
or

00:14:15.950 --> 00:14:19.220
the computer,
normally implements DNS, right?

00:14:19.220 --> 00:14:23.390
It's what's gonna help you to locate
not only the resources on your internal

280
00:14:23.390 --> 00:14:28.560

00:14:28.560 --> 00:14:31.040
But then,

00:14:35.035 --> 00:14:37.840
And when you can't resolve it,
that's what helps to turn around and

284
00:14:37.840 --> 00:14:42.140
look at these connection's security rules,

285
00:14:42.140 --> 00:14:45.100

286
00:14:45.100 --> 00:14:48.740

287
00:14:48.740 --> 00:14:51.360
And once you've done that,

288
00:14:51.360 --> 00:14:53.740
And your internet tunnel allows
you to communicate back and

289
00:14:53.740 --> 00:14:55.910

290
00:14:55.910 --> 00:14:59.630
Now, one of the great things is even
though we're talking about all this,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain and demonstrate how to configure storage devices in a Windows 10 environment. They begin by configuring both Basic and Extended disk partitions; then jumping into Dynamic disks all the while explaining their differences and limitations.
episodes.title: Configure Storage

00:24:30.010 --> 00:24:32.860
a little over 2 terabytes but 2 terabytes.

00:24:32.860 --> 00:24:37.160
The other thing that it includes now when

422
00:24:37.160 --> 00:24:40.320

423
00:24:40.320 --> 00:24:42.540

00:24:42.540 --> 00:24:45.494

00:24:45.494 --> 00:24:50.155
a Cyclic Redundancy Check in it that says,

426
00:24:50.155 --> 00:24:54.647
the boot record and if it's failed,

00:24:54.647 --> 00:24:57.240

00:24:57.240 --> 00:25:00.980
So because of that we can read off

00:25:00.980 --> 00:25:05.640

00:25:19.520 --> 00:25:21.373

00:25:21.373 --> 00:25:24.196

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue their discussion on storage management in Windows 10. They jump back into Dynamic Disks, using PowerShell to create, convert, and configure disk partitions and volumes. They also explain the differences between the Simple/Striped/Spanned/Mirrored volume types.
episodes.title: Configure Storage Part 2

00:19:01.890 --> 00:19:03.600

00:19:03.600 --> 00:19:05.860

00:19:05.860 --> 00:19:07.010

So that's why I'm gonna tell you, don't

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show how to implement and configure storage in Windows 10.  In this third part, they focus in on how to format volumes and manipulate file attributes via the command line interpreters, respectively.  The guys talk about Storage Spaces.  This feature, Wes explains, gives Windows users the ability to aggregate diverse and multiple disparate storage devices, in bulk or incrementally, depending on how it’s configured. They also show some of the different configurations possible when configuring “Storage Spaces”.

Make sure you do know what that attrib

the difference between the minus and the
pluses with those different letters that

622

you have to have available for you for
the exam.That is also gonna be helpful.

623

And then lastly, West also showed us

to be able to aggregate our
storage devices together,

625
00:35:06.170 --> 00:35:10.280
so that we can chop it up and divide it up

626

way we can effectively use our storage the
way that we need to inside of Windows 10.

627
00:35:13.910 --> 00:35:17.270
Well that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

00:35:17.270 --> 00:35:20.540
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

00:35:20.540 --> 00:35:21.380
>> And I'm Wes Brian.

630
00:35:21.380 --> 00:35:25.015
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Windows 10 shows to come.

631
00:35:25.015 --> 00:35:28.048
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look at how to implement apps from the Command Line Interpreter.  They demonstrate some of the options an enterprise support should know when installing or uninstalling apps.  These command line options are needed when deciding to create installation scripts for deploying apps across an enterprise, according to the guys.  Wes also introduces some of the different options that can be configured to startup the Windows 10 computer for troubleshooting.
episodes.title: Implement Apps

431
00:25:23.310 --> 00:25:26.360
And so wait a second,
you gotta wait till the first one stops.

432
00:25:26.360 --> 00:25:30.740
All you have to do is just close the
application down and then open it back up.

433
00:25:30.740 --> 00:25:31.240
All right?

434
00:25:31.240 --> 00:25:34.410
And I could do a quick
repair if I wanted to and

435
00:25:34.410 --> 00:25:39.160
notice it shouldn't take a long time.

436
00:25:39.160 --> 00:25:42.120
This application is fine so I'm not
gonna run this I just want you to know

437
00:25:42.120 --> 00:25:47.300
that depending on the application itself
will tell what options are available.

438
00:25:47.300 --> 00:25:52.090
Just know that the common ones
are Organize, Uninstall, and then Change.

439
00:25:52.090 --> 00:25:56.100
Again, for instance, 2013,
if you wanted to change your product key,

440
00:25:56.100 --> 00:25:59.850
Office 2013 will allow you to do
it right here in this location.

441
00:25:59.850 --> 00:26:02.410
It looks like it's a little
different with Office 2016, and

442
00:26:02.410 --> 00:26:03.390
everything going to the cloud.

443
00:26:03.390 --> 00:26:06.200
So their licensing model might be
a little bit different for that.

444
00:26:06.200 --> 00:26:07.760
But you do have the ability.

445
00:26:07.760 --> 00:26:11.630
For instance I have 80k here,
I could always change that if I wanted to,

446
00:26:11.630 --> 00:26:15.350
and this is gonna open up
the entire installer here and

447
00:26:15.350 --> 00:26:16.610
I'm not gonna change anything here.

448
00:26:16.610 --> 00:26:20.005
But notice that I do get
a different set of options so

449
00:26:20.005 --> 00:26:25.135
what options you get are really specific
to the programs that you have installed.

450
00:26:25.135 --> 00:26:29.085
So that really is one of
the ways that you can install,

451
00:26:29.085 --> 00:26:32.765
you can modify, you can repair software.

452
00:26:32.765 --> 00:26:34.405
If you're going through MSIexec,

453
00:26:34.405 --> 00:26:38.455
pay attention to some of those
parameters that you have.

454
00:26:38.455 --> 00:26:42.310
For instance, the install option,
the uninstall option and

455
00:26:42.310 --> 00:26:45.910
then you're logging and logging,
verbose logging as well.

456
00:26:45.910 --> 00:26:50.900
Now, one of the other things that
they call out on the exam is

457
00:26:50.900 --> 00:26:52.910
configuring your start up options.

458
00:26:52.910 --> 00:26:56.050
And we want to save some time here,
and kind of show you a little bit

459
00:26:56.050 --> 00:26:58.640
about the start up options
that we have available for us.

460
00:26:58.640 --> 00:27:00.190
So let's go ahead and do that.

461
00:27:00.190 --> 00:27:02.730
There's a couple of different
ways that you can do this.

462
00:27:02.730 --> 00:27:06.620
If you're in the command prompt or
if you're in the PowerShell.

463
00:27:06.620 --> 00:27:11.420
You can also always type sysdm.cpl and

464
00:27:11.420 --> 00:27:15.370
that launches your traditional
system properties.

465
00:27:15.370 --> 00:27:19.040
Some of you guys that have been in Windows
for a while will just recognize this as

466
00:27:19.040 --> 00:27:22.280
your traditional system properties
going back to like XP and stuff.

467
00:27:22.280 --> 00:27:26.010
Another place that you can get to this too
if you wanted to is just by right clicking

468
00:27:26.010 --> 00:27:29.020
our little Quick Links
administrative menu here and

469
00:27:29.020 --> 00:27:33.300
I could choose system and
then choose advanced system, right?

470
00:27:33.300 --> 00:27:37.450
And then we get just to, or actually
any one of these lower three links.

471
00:27:37.450 --> 00:27:42.620
But what I'm focused on Is this
option more specifically right here,

472
00:27:42.620 --> 00:27:43.690
Startup and Recovery.

473
00:27:43.690 --> 00:27:45.100
Notice that right there and

474
00:27:45.100 --> 00:27:48.150
what we wanna do is we wanna click
this little Settings button.

475
00:27:48.150 --> 00:27:50.570
So we'll click the Settings button and

476
00:27:50.570 --> 00:27:56.210
this does, as the name implies,
it does talk about recovery as well.

477
00:27:56.210 --> 00:28:01.260
On our 7697 course, they went in some good

478
00:28:01.260 --> 00:28:04.420
detail on data recovery and
recovering your system.

479
00:28:04.420 --> 00:28:08.740
If any of this is unfamiliar with you,
jump back over and definitely watch that.

480
00:28:08.740 --> 00:28:12.625
But what we want to look at for
this exam, more importantly and

481
00:28:12.625 --> 00:28:16.605
it's all important, but for
this one it's a system startup.

482
00:28:16.605 --> 00:28:19.080
Now what does this modify?

483
00:28:19.080 --> 00:28:23.120
All right, this modifies something known
as the BCD, the boot configuration data,

484
00:28:23.120 --> 00:28:26.110
and some of that information
stores what we see right here.

485
00:28:26.110 --> 00:28:29.300
For instance if you have more than one
Windows operating system you select

486
00:28:29.300 --> 00:28:29.920
the defaults.

487
00:28:29.920 --> 00:28:32.770
Well, what is the default
operating system in this case,

488
00:28:32.770 --> 00:28:35.270
I don't have a multi- boot system,
I only have one system.

489
00:28:35.270 --> 00:28:37.170
So, it's Windows 10 but

490
00:28:37.170 --> 00:28:42.260
if you've ever had multi-boot you've
probably seen that it says, well, how long

491
00:28:42.260 --> 00:28:48.480
do you want to want to display the
multi-operating system selection screen?

492
00:28:48.480 --> 00:28:51.280
Well you might be able to
optimize your start up time if

493
00:28:51.280 --> 00:28:53.010
you maybe put this down to 1.

494
00:28:53.010 --> 00:28:55.700
I don't have more than
one operating system so

495
00:28:55.700 --> 00:28:59.350
why do I need it to stay there for
30 seconds.

496
00:28:59.350 --> 00:29:04.710
The other one too is time to display
recovery options when needed.

497
00:29:04.710 --> 00:29:08.090
All right, this is something that's
I believe, if I remember right,

498
00:29:08.090 --> 00:29:10.290
Ronnie you might have to correct
me if I'm wrong on this one.

499
00:29:10.290 --> 00:29:14.800
I believe this is started in Windows 7 and
this is where they started to

500
00:29:14.800 --> 00:29:18.690
include recovery options when the it
seemed the machine couldn't boot.

501
00:29:18.690 --> 00:29:22.430
It would restart and it would say
Preparing automatic recovery, might've

502
00:29:22.430 --> 00:29:26.920
come out in Windows 8, but this says how
long do you want to display that screen.

503
00:29:26.920 --> 00:29:30.270
And again,
it's all a part of your startup.

504
00:29:30.270 --> 00:29:34.620
Now, that's only one location, we've got
another oldie but goodie that we've been

505
00:29:34.620 --> 00:29:40.360
using for a very long time,
in order to modify our startup options.

506
00:29:40.360 --> 00:29:41.330
Where is that?

507
00:29:41.330 --> 00:29:45.217
Well this can also be launched from
the command prompt if you want or

508
00:29:45.217 --> 00:29:46.870
the PowerShell.

509
00:29:46.870 --> 00:29:50.330
And this is good old MS config.

510
00:29:50.330 --> 00:29:53.450
All right this ones been around for
a while, we've been using this for

511
00:29:53.450 --> 00:29:54.820
a long time now.

512
00:29:54.820 --> 00:29:57.500
I will tell you one thing that's
a little bit different when it comes to

513
00:29:57.500 --> 00:30:00.660
configuring startup options
is this started in Windows 8.

514
00:30:00.660 --> 00:30:04.330
For the longest time, any files or
programs that would put their startup

515
00:30:04.330 --> 00:30:07.400
files right there just the moment
you would boot the machine,

516
00:30:07.400 --> 00:30:11.380
you could go to this location and
you could disable them if you needed to.

517
00:30:11.380 --> 00:30:13.180
Just wanna show you here real quick.

518
00:30:13.180 --> 00:30:16.740
If you open your Task Manager,
and choose More Details.

519
00:30:16.740 --> 00:30:19.090
That's where that option is today.

520
00:30:19.090 --> 00:30:24.020
So just keep that in mind, because that
is part of configuring startup options,

521
00:30:24.020 --> 00:30:25.840
and they might want you to know that.

522
00:30:25.840 --> 00:30:30.020
But what I really wanna look at
are some of these first couple of tabs.

523
00:30:30.020 --> 00:30:34.080
Notice you have what's
known as a normal Startup.

524
00:30:34.080 --> 00:30:37.830
All right, normal startup loads all third
party drivers, all of the services,

525
00:30:37.830 --> 00:30:42.700
even services it doesn't require Windows,
you know, for Windows to boot, right.

526
00:30:42.700 --> 00:30:44.720
And this is typically what we use.

527
00:30:44.720 --> 00:30:47.590
Diagnostic startup is much
like what we call safe mode,

528
00:30:47.590 --> 00:30:50.970
it only loads the basic devices and
services only.

529
00:30:50.970 --> 00:30:53.990
In this case, if you're going to be,
maybe troubleshooting

530
00:30:53.990 --> 00:30:57.920
a third party driver you certainly don't
want that third party driver booting up,

531
00:30:57.920 --> 00:31:01.820
if that's the driver that
you're trying to diagnose.

532
00:31:01.820 --> 00:31:03.610
And then you have a selective
startup as well and

533
00:31:03.610 --> 00:31:05.610
you can get a little more picky on this.

534
00:31:05.610 --> 00:31:08.200
I wanna go ahead and
go over to the Boot tab.

535
00:31:08.200 --> 00:31:10.680
Now the Boot tab,
you might have noticed something.

536
00:31:10.680 --> 00:31:14.210
Some of this looks like what
we just looked at, right?

537
00:31:14.210 --> 00:31:16.930
If I go back to my system properties here,
let me go ahead and

538
00:31:16.930 --> 00:31:18.380
launch that up real quick.

539
00:31:19.530 --> 00:31:22.190
And the good thing is you don't
need both of these open here.

540
00:31:22.190 --> 00:31:25.420
And we'll go back to that startup and
then settings.

541
00:31:25.420 --> 00:31:26.980
These look a lot the same.

542
00:31:26.980 --> 00:31:27.890
All right?

543
00:31:27.890 --> 00:31:29.270
They're modifying the same thing.

544
00:31:29.270 --> 00:31:32.880
They're modifying the BCD, and if I had
more than one operating system in here,

545
00:31:32.880 --> 00:31:36.170
I could select it,
which one I want, as the default.

546
00:31:36.170 --> 00:31:40.750
Now, when it comes to my boot options,
right, notice the Safe Boot, and

547
00:31:40.750 --> 00:31:42.070
Minimal, all right?

548
00:31:42.070 --> 00:31:46.950
Well, if I wanted to do a Safe Boot and
Minimal, we can boot into Safe Mode.

549
00:31:46.950 --> 00:31:49.690
I want you to [LAUGH] remember
this because I've actually made

550
00:31:49.690 --> 00:31:50.810
a mistake on this.

551
00:31:50.810 --> 00:31:54.110
When you set this here, it's not like
some of you that might remember that F8

552
00:31:54.110 --> 00:31:56.055
to continue, boots you into the safe mode.

553
00:31:56.055 --> 00:32:00.011
But the moment you restart the computer,
all of that information is discarded, and

554
00:32:00.011 --> 00:32:01.639
you boot to a normal boot process.

555
00:32:01.639 --> 00:32:05.597
If I do a Safe Boot with Minimal here, and
I choose OK, and it says hey, go ahead,

556
00:32:05.597 --> 00:32:09.117
you have to restart your operating
system in order to save the changes.

557
00:32:09.117 --> 00:32:11.539
I wanna take a second to
show you what happens.

558
00:32:11.539 --> 00:32:16.138
Now what it's gonna do Rather than keeping
you guys on the edge of your seats

559
00:32:16.138 --> 00:32:19.780
waiting, is it's gonna
boot in the safe mode.

560
00:32:19.780 --> 00:32:21.450
But here's the difference.

561
00:32:21.450 --> 00:32:26.540
When I set it from MSConfig,
it is not going to uncheck itself, so

562
00:32:26.540 --> 00:32:28.050
you have to be careful.

563
00:32:28.050 --> 00:32:31.670
When you reboot,
into safe mode from MSConfig and

564
00:32:31.670 --> 00:32:36.930
you are done configuring whatever it
is that you're troubleshooting, make

565
00:32:36.930 --> 00:32:41.200
sure you change it back, [LAUGH] because
it's gonna keep booting into safe mode and

566
00:32:41.200 --> 00:32:44.350
that might not be a good
day at the office.

567
00:32:44.350 --> 00:32:46.650
Now right away,
I can see something's going on here,

568
00:32:46.650 --> 00:32:50.200
because my screen is a very
low resolution, right.

569
00:32:50.200 --> 00:32:52.008
Well, there's a reason we
boot into safe mode, right.

570
00:32:52.008 --> 00:32:55.643
It takes all of that third-party
video drivers, and it says,

571
00:32:55.643 --> 00:32:58.454
let me just take a default,
generic VGA driver,

572
00:32:58.454 --> 00:33:03.220
just enough to get you into the operating
system so that you can work with it.

573
00:33:03.220 --> 00:33:07.385
And you can see up here, in the upper
right hand corner we are in safe mode and

574
00:33:07.385 --> 00:33:10.912
again it isn't loading the drivers,
third-party drivers.

575
00:33:10.912 --> 00:33:17.020
Now keeping that in mind, if I want
this to go away and we want to fix it.

576
00:33:17.020 --> 00:33:21.360
Well once we're done with
the driver testing that's going on,

577
00:33:21.360 --> 00:33:24.070
all we got to do is just
do another MSConfig.

578
00:33:24.070 --> 00:33:24.920
We launch that up.

579
00:33:24.920 --> 00:33:28.290
Notice that it automatically
changed me to a selective startup.

580
00:33:28.290 --> 00:33:31.912
Said load system services,
load up startup items,

581
00:33:31.912 --> 00:33:34.100
if it happen to be something with the BCD,

582
00:33:34.100 --> 00:33:39.360
the boot configuration data, well we can
say use original BCD, boot configuration.

583
00:33:39.360 --> 00:33:44.870
We're not gonna do that but we are gonna
change that back to a safe boot.

584
00:33:44.870 --> 00:33:48.490
We'll choose OK, it's gonna tell us that,
hey we've gotta restart.

585
00:33:48.490 --> 00:33:51.915
I'm gonna go ahead and exit this without
restarting really quick cuz I do wanna

586
00:33:51.915 --> 00:33:55.650
launch that back up one more time and
just talk about a couple of the other

587
00:33:55.650 --> 00:33:58.750
options here that we're really not gonna,
we're not gonna re boot here though.

588
00:33:58.750 --> 00:34:00.170
Alternate shell, what is that?

589
00:34:00.170 --> 00:34:03.070
Well maybe some of you remember
the advanced start up options that you set

590
00:34:03.070 --> 00:34:07.020
where it says start in safe
mode with command prompt.

591
00:34:07.020 --> 00:34:10.080
That's what that is, alternate shell
just means start up with command prompt.

592
00:34:10.080 --> 00:34:13.160
All right, active Directory repair,
we're not gonna worry about that.

593
00:34:13.160 --> 00:34:16.420
Network, this says go ahead and
start up in safe mode but

594
00:34:16.420 --> 00:34:18.650
initiate the network adapter.

595
00:34:18.650 --> 00:34:20.770
No GUI boot, well what does that mean?

596
00:34:20.770 --> 00:34:22.131
You say, well wait a second Wes,

597
00:34:22.131 --> 00:34:25.360
booting into command prompt
as the alternate shell.

598
00:34:25.360 --> 00:34:26.940
What does the GUI boot mean?

599
00:34:26.940 --> 00:34:30.620
That means just don't display the Windows
welcome screen, right, just pass that.

600
00:34:30.620 --> 00:34:33.800
And then again you got log in,
Base video, and

601
00:34:33.800 --> 00:34:39.120
OS boot information if you're doing for
instance debugging and stuff.

602
00:34:39.120 --> 00:34:42.249
Maybe you've got a piece of software
that's causing a problem, you can do that.

603
00:34:43.400 --> 00:34:47.120
Last but not least, making all of
these boot settings permanent and

604
00:34:47.120 --> 00:34:49.400
also adjusting that timeout screen.

605
00:34:49.400 --> 00:34:52.270
So not too difficult once you know.

606
00:34:52.270 --> 00:34:55.020
I'm gonna go ahead and choose OK to this.

607
00:34:55.020 --> 00:34:59.760
And let's go ahead and fix the computer
here real quick and just double check.

608
00:35:00.970 --> 00:35:04.990
Uncheck that, now we're out of safe mode,
and we can restart.

609
00:35:04.990 --> 00:35:08.140
And hopefully Ronnie,
now that we maybe fixed the driver

610
00:35:08.140 --> 00:35:11.622
when we restart the machine it is
gonna go into a normal boot process.

611
00:35:11.622 --> 00:35:16.040
So a fairly straight forward process once
you know, well, where the options are.

612
00:35:17.370 --> 00:35:19.156
>> All right Wes well thank you again for

613
00:35:19.156 --> 00:35:22.844
showing us at least the idea here of
working with different applications and

614
00:35:22.844 --> 00:35:26.280
also being able to configure
some of the options in startup.

615
00:35:26.280 --> 00:35:28.920
Usually, the startup options
are really there to help us,

616
00:35:28.920 --> 00:35:31.740
especially when we
are troubleshooting some few things.

617
00:35:31.740 --> 00:35:34.638
And it gives us this ability to understand
that there are multiple options for

618
00:35:34.638 --> 00:35:35.750
us to think about.

619
00:35:35.750 --> 00:35:37.970
So make sure you know where
those things are located.

620
00:35:37.970 --> 00:35:41.420
Make sure you understand those
options that are available to you.

621
00:35:41.420 --> 00:35:44.850
Also, in terms of implementing
the apps that we've talked about here.

622
00:35:44.850 --> 00:35:48.760
It's easy enough for you to double click
on an application that you've downloaded,

623
00:35:48.760 --> 00:35:53.210
but if you're gonna be an enterprise
level support technician, it means that

624
00:35:53.210 --> 00:35:56.760
you must be able to understand that
there is another way to do this,

625
00:35:56.760 --> 00:35:59.650
especially when you're working
with what multiple machines.

626
00:35:59.650 --> 00:36:02.060
This gives us a way to script
those things out and so

627
00:36:02.060 --> 00:36:04.990
you do want to make sure you go back and
take a look at the options that Wes has

628
00:36:04.990 --> 00:36:08.360
showed you of how to be able to
install as well as uninstall,

629
00:36:08.360 --> 00:36:13.420
do that silent install and even understand
the ability to be able to do the log in.

630
00:36:13.420 --> 00:36:16.960
All those come with what we call different
options that we add into that command line

631
00:36:16.960 --> 00:36:17.550
as well.

632
00:36:17.550 --> 00:36:22.000
So, these are all particular
types of tools and things

633
00:36:22.000 --> 00:36:26.400
that you should be very interested in, as
you not only go forward for the exam, but

634
00:36:26.400 --> 00:36:30.290
in your particular career as an enterprise
level support technician as well.

635
00:36:30.290 --> 00:36:34.110
So, that's a great place for
us also to end this episode then.

636
00:36:34.110 --> 00:36:37.400
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

637
00:36:37.400 --> 00:36:38.300
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

638
00:36:38.300 --> 00:36:40.654
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Windows 10 episodes.

639
00:36:40.654 --> 00:36:50.590
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look at how to create and build the Windows Store for our enterprise usage.  The Windows Store for business can be configured so that our enterprise can effectively deploy and control apps, according to the guys.  They show how to add an app or deploy an app to an user within the enterprise and how to assign different roles to administrate the enterprise’s Windows Store.
episodes.title: Windows Store for Business
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

And today we're actually moving into,

And what we're actually gonna be taking a

>> Thanks, Ronnie, for

It is good to be here with ITProTV,
and that's right,

we're looking at the Windows Store,
but not from the consumer side.

episodes.description: in this episode, Ronnie and Wes show how to configure remote management tools in Windows 10.  They demonstrate using the Windows Remote Management from PowerShell and options needed to enable the proper service as well as disable it.  The guys also show how to use the powerful PS REMOTING to run cmdlets on a remote machine too.  Wes shows how to use these tools to get information from the remote system accessed.
episodes.title: Configure Remote Management
