episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue to show the additional remote management using the microsoft management console to connect and manage operating system services and features on remote systems.  They briefly also mention the usage of Remote Desktop Connection and the use of Easy Connect.  With Easy Connect, they emphasize the requirements needed to make this feature work for the Windows 10 Enterprise Support Technician.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain configuring Updates in Windows 10. They start by looking at the classic servicing model and then compare that to the new update deployment model. Next they discuss Windows as a Service(WaaS) for managing updates. Finally, they show you how to use Group Policy to set Update policy.
episodes.title: Configure Updates

it's more Windows 10 for you.

>> That's right.
We're coming back at you with more of

We're gonna be looking at

Now, I know what you might be saying,

I know how to configure updates.

Well, that's great for

00:00:46.470 --> 00:00:49.090

But before we dive into

let's talk about where we've come from and

So let's go ahead.

00:01:00.490 --> 00:01:02.140
I've got a little diagram here made up,

00:01:02.140 --> 00:01:06.350
and let's talk a little bit about

That we really been using,

00:01:11.390 --> 00:01:14.700
The Classic Servicing Model,

27
00:01:14.700 --> 00:01:15.760
Windows Update.

28
00:01:15.760 --> 00:01:17.530
You can set it.

00:01:22.420 --> 00:01:26.570
Second Tuesday of every month

00:01:26.570 --> 00:01:28.730
We pulled down all of

00:01:28.730 --> 00:01:31.780
the patches that have been

34
00:01:31.780 --> 00:01:35.919
Now, you'll probably be aware that

35
00:01:35.919 --> 00:01:39.848
your operating systems go through
not quite enough new features to

36
00:01:39.848 --> 00:01:43.377

37
00:01:43.377 --> 00:01:46.604
A little bit smaller than a full and

38

00:01:48.347 --> 00:01:51.994
And you might have seen some operating

00:02:03.370 --> 00:02:05.558
Now, they're typically Internet based,

We connect out down to Microsoft servers,

Now, there's another model too, when

upgrading, and that model is the Upgrade

49
00:02:23.420 --> 00:02:27.308
Now, with the Upgrade and Deployment
Model, when you get new features, or

51
00:02:31.652 --> 00:02:35.556
And this Migration process can be very,

52
00:02:35.556 --> 00:02:40.045
So, for instance, let's kinda walk through
a couple steps of what we have to do

53
00:02:40.045 --> 00:02:43.605
if we are gonna go and
roll out a new edition of Windows, right?

54
00:02:43.605 --> 00:02:47.160
So let's take this computer right here and
if I decide, you know what?

55
00:02:47.160 --> 00:02:50.200
I think this computer is
going to be upgraded.

56
00:02:50.200 --> 00:02:51.504
Well, then, what do we do?

57
00:02:51.504 --> 00:02:53.167
Well, the first thing we
do is if we're doing,

58
00:02:53.167 --> 00:02:55.421
let's say we're doing something
like a Wipe and Load, right.

59
00:02:55.421 --> 00:02:59.998
We're gonna take an intermediate
File Server, or an intermediate share, and

60
00:02:59.998 --> 00:03:03.940
we're gonna take all of the users
settings off of it, right?

61
00:03:03.940 --> 00:03:07.450
Once we take all of those user
settings off, we're gonna go ahead and

62
00:03:07.450 --> 00:03:09.760
we're gonna format the hard drive, right?

63
00:03:09.760 --> 00:03:14.185
And we're gonna reinstall or
upgrade the new installation.

64
00:03:14.185 --> 00:03:15.305
But then, what do we have to do?

65
00:03:15.305 --> 00:03:17.703
Then we turn around,
we take from that File Server,

66
00:03:17.703 --> 00:03:19.669

67
00:03:19.669 --> 00:03:22.915
So, it's a fairly long,
drawn out process, right?

68
00:03:22.915 --> 00:03:25.235
That's what's known as a Wipe and
Load because a Wipe and

69
00:03:25.235 --> 00:03:26.451
Load takes a single machine.

70
00:03:26.451 --> 00:03:29.185
It says, let's back up,
not back up that data.

71
00:03:29.185 --> 00:03:31.120
Let's migrate the user data up.

72
00:03:31.120 --> 00:03:34.080
Lets go ahead and
format the operating system and

73
00:03:34.080 --> 00:03:39.140
then we'll bring that data back down, the
user settings back down to the machine.

74
00:03:39.140 --> 00:03:44.213
Well, you can also do the other one there
is a Side-by-Side Migration, right?

75
00:03:44.213 --> 00:03:48.327
Maybe this first computer that we have
right here is going to be, is the brand

76
00:03:48.327 --> 00:03:53.610
new computer, maybe this old one out here
is the computer that we're moving from.

77
00:03:53.610 --> 00:03:55.824
Well, in this case,
we still got the same process, right?

78
00:03:55.824 --> 00:04:01.430
We migrate the user data
to that File Server, right.

79
00:04:01.430 --> 00:04:07.000
And then, from there, we pull down
that user data to the new machine.

80
00:04:07.000 --> 00:04:08.081
So there's still work involved, right?

81
00:04:08.081 --> 00:04:10.110
We still have to back up the data.

82
00:04:10.110 --> 00:04:12.760
We still have to make sure
that we migrate the data.

83
00:04:12.760 --> 00:04:14.500
We gotta format the hard drive, and

84
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:17.940
we've gotta do the installation

85
00:04:17.940 --> 00:04:21.020
Now, when you're doing upgrades too,
you also have Clean Installations and

00:04:21.020 --> 00:04:22.320

87
00:04:22.320 --> 00:04:26.754
A Clean Installation is when maybe your

88
00:04:26.754 --> 00:04:30.994
maybe your operating system is too far
back, if you will, to do what's known as

89
00:04:30.994 --> 00:04:34.542
an In-place Upgrade, where you

91
00:04:38.191 --> 00:04:42.043
So in those situations, right,
you're gonna go ahead and

92
00:04:42.043 --> 00:04:44.585
you're gonna take the old hard drive,

93
00:04:44.585 --> 00:04:49.070
much like the Wipe and Load,
it's pretty much what that is, right?

94
00:04:49.070 --> 00:04:52.104
And you're gonna migrate the user
settings off of it, right?

95
00:04:52.104 --> 00:04:56.640
You're gonna format the hard drive and
you're gonna do a Clean Install.

96
00:04:56.640 --> 00:04:59.440
Now, it's close to the Clean Installation
but the difference is because you already

97
00:04:59.440 --> 00:05:05.150
had a prior licensed copy of Windows,
a lot of times you'll get a reduced price.

98
00:05:05.150 --> 00:05:08.440
Now, you also had the other one
where it's an In-place Upgrade.

99
00:05:08.440 --> 00:05:12.410
And your In-place Upgrade does
lead some remnants behind, right?

100
00:05:12.410 --> 00:05:16.571
So you have your old hard drive
with your old operating system.

101
00:05:16.571 --> 00:05:18.420
Let me see if I can grab that there.

102
00:05:18.420 --> 00:05:19.290
And then, what do you do?

103
00:05:19.290 --> 00:05:23.674
You take and you install the new
operating system on top of the old.

104
00:05:23.674 --> 00:05:27.060
Still leaves some remnants of
the old operating system behind.

105
00:05:27.060 --> 00:05:29.120
Some things that you have to deal with,
right?

106
00:05:29.120 --> 00:05:31.300
Now, it's very Time Consuming.

107
00:05:31.300 --> 00:05:32.950
A lot of research has to be done.

108
00:05:32.950 --> 00:05:36.230
A lot of compatibility
issues that might come in.

109
00:05:36.230 --> 00:05:40.850
And these compatibility issues a lot of

110
00:05:40.850 --> 00:05:44.590
And then, hopefully, once we get

00:05:44.590 --> 00:05:47.130
we can roll out the new operating system.

112
00:05:47.130 --> 00:05:49.568
The other thing is, for instant,

113
00:05:49.568 --> 00:05:53.892
When we look at your Deployment Services,
right, I have an image up there and

00:05:53.892 --> 00:05:57.960
if it goes through a series of updates,

00:05:57.960 --> 00:06:02.120
Well, it pretty much updates second

00:06:02.120 --> 00:06:04.775
So we're gonna do a lot of
Image Servicing, right?

117
00:06:04.775 --> 00:06:07.650
We got employees down here that are gonna

118
00:06:07.650 --> 00:06:10.820
They're gonna have to do all their
updates, all their upgrades, right?

00:06:10.820 --> 00:06:13.180
Then they're gonna have
to reimage the machine,

00:06:13.180 --> 00:06:15.710
recapture that image put it back up

121
00:06:15.710 --> 00:06:21.050
So these are some of the classic models
that we've had in the past, right?

122
00:06:21.050 --> 00:06:24.660
And we're still gonna use
deployment models but

00:06:24.660 --> 00:06:28.860
they do have a new way to maintain

Now, this is where something known as

I'm sitting here thinking it reminds me of

So what is Windows as a Service?

This is their new servicing model, right?

And what this does is it says, rather

132

We'll do these ongoing,
rolling updates, if you will.

And the updates can be deferred, too.

134
00:07:01.920 --> 00:07:02.820
We could say, you know what?

In a new system,
maybe you don't want those updates going

right out to your machines because

Gives your IT admins the time that they

So four months is the minimum for some,

00:07:19.640 --> 00:07:22.480
We also have machines out

Maybe you've got some kind of system

Well, these systems need to be

147
00:07:44.520 --> 00:07:47.521
Maybe you got ATM manufacturing

148
00:07:47.521 --> 00:07:50.637
That might be running

00:07:50.637 --> 00:07:53.703
And I certainly don't want them

00:07:53.703 --> 00:07:56.700

151
00:07:56.700 --> 00:07:59.370
Well, this is were this
Windows as a service comes in,

152
00:07:59.370 --> 00:08:03.440
because you can go with what
are known as servicing branches.

153
00:08:03.440 --> 00:08:07.340
And the servicing branches give you the
ability to defer the updates, all right.

154
00:08:07.340 --> 00:08:08.620
So lets go ahead and

155
00:08:08.620 --> 00:08:13.800
talk a little bit more about what

00:08:13.800 --> 00:08:16.270
It also introduces, and
I want to make mention of this too,

00:08:16.270 --> 00:08:18.710
something called Windows Update for
Business, all right.

158
00:08:18.710 --> 00:08:22.540
And again, this gives your IT staff,

00:08:22.540 --> 00:08:27.270

160

See, when we use WSUS it's an all or

161
00:08:30.690 --> 00:08:34.080
You download all the updates and
you either approve or deny them.

162
00:08:34.080 --> 00:08:36.890
This way, they're not going to be
released to you right away, and

163
00:08:36.890 --> 00:08:39.400
again, it gives your IT staff more time.

164
00:08:40.400 --> 00:08:42.880
Now, let's talk a little
bit about the media, and

00:08:42.880 --> 00:08:45.720
what they mean whey they talk

166
00:08:45.720 --> 00:08:48.240
All right, so we've got a computer
over here on the left hand side, and

167
00:08:48.240 --> 00:08:52.550
this computer has been marked as one
of the servicing branches that defers

168
00:08:52.550 --> 00:08:53.650
its updates.

169
00:08:53.650 --> 00:08:57.050
So what you do is you do the original
installation media, right?

170
00:08:57.050 --> 00:08:59.860
When the operating system first comes out.

171
00:08:59.860 --> 00:09:02.800
That grace period of about
four months deferment.

172
00:09:02.800 --> 00:09:05.780
You can defer depending on what edition
you have, up to about eight months.

173
00:09:05.780 --> 00:09:10.910
All right, happens, and then they
roll out some kind of new features.

174
00:09:10.910 --> 00:09:12.910
Well, how does Microsoft do this today?

175
00:09:12.910 --> 00:09:16.720
Well, they take the original installation
media and they take the new features and

176
00:09:16.720 --> 00:09:20.890
they bundle them together, and they
come up I put new installation media and

177
00:09:20.890 --> 00:09:24.820
they rolled that out on Windows Update for
Business.

178
00:09:24.820 --> 00:09:31.600
Now what Windows Update for Business
does is it looks basically it targets.

179
00:09:31.600 --> 00:09:34.790
If you will the devices that
have been flagged for deferment.

180
00:09:34.790 --> 00:09:37.090
And it says, okay, that's their state.

181
00:09:37.090 --> 00:09:40.050
They said defer updates,
that grace period is gone.

182
00:09:40.050 --> 00:09:41.950
That time, that wait period is gone.

183
00:09:41.950 --> 00:09:44.900
We'll take the new installation media,
we'll target those devices that

184
00:09:44.900 --> 00:09:49.330
have deferred the updates and now I'll get
the new installed media and they apply it.

185
00:09:49.330 --> 00:09:54.450
So it gives you a little bit of time
before you do the updated new features.

186
00:09:54.450 --> 00:09:56.860
Now there's some different
branches that web talked about.

187
00:09:56.860 --> 00:10:00.480
These are called the Windows
10 servicing branches.

188
00:10:00.480 --> 00:10:04.390
And with the Windows 10 servicing
branches these are different than

189
00:10:04.390 --> 00:10:07.970
some of your basic editions that
we've talked about in the past.

190
00:10:07.970 --> 00:10:09.220
Right?
We've talked about Windows 10,

191
00:10:09.220 --> 00:10:10.420
the Home Edition.

192
00:10:10.420 --> 00:10:14.140
It's not really Home Edition but
Windows 10 just basic right?

193
00:10:14.140 --> 00:10:16.010
And then we talked about Windows 10 Pro,
and

194
00:10:16.010 --> 00:10:18.100
we've also talked about
Windows 10 Enterprise.

195
00:10:18.100 --> 00:10:23.510
As soon as otherwise models that you have
out there, these servicing branches.

196
00:10:23.510 --> 00:10:26.440
Now maybe some of you have all
ready seen the very first one here,

197
00:10:26.440 --> 00:10:28.820
the Windows Insider Preview.

198
00:10:28.820 --> 00:10:34.660
I know that one of our guys back there
has been on that Windows Insider Preview,

199
00:10:34.660 --> 00:10:37.000
the moment it first was
released to market, right?

200
00:10:37.000 --> 00:10:40.020
We were still on Windows 8 and
Windows 10 Insider preview came out.

201
00:10:40.020 --> 00:10:43.080
Now, what is it about
Windows Insider preview?

202
00:10:43.080 --> 00:10:46.760
Well, the Windows Insider preview, if you
ever messed around with your phones and

203
00:10:46.760 --> 00:10:48.030
stuff like that in the ROMs, right?

204
00:10:48.030 --> 00:10:49.490
They talk about nightly builds, right?

205
00:10:49.490 --> 00:10:51.450
That is the latest and greatest.

206
00:10:51.450 --> 00:10:55.410
All right with all of its
incompatibility that comes with it.

207
00:10:55.410 --> 00:10:58.420
All that loveliness that we have.

208
00:10:58.420 --> 00:11:00.740
It deploys to your machine and
it breaks your machine.

209
00:11:00.740 --> 00:11:03.080
Well that's part of the insider Preview,
right?

210
00:11:03.080 --> 00:11:04.710
You get the newest features and builds and

211
00:11:04.710 --> 00:11:08.370
you get them before anybody else gets
them; before they're checked for

00:11:08.370 --> 00:11:12.190
stability and compatibility, before
they're ever released to the market.

213
00:11:12.190 --> 00:11:12.830
Right?

214
00:11:12.830 --> 00:11:13.890
You get those.

215
00:11:13.890 --> 00:11:15.770
Well, that's the insider preview.

216
00:11:15.770 --> 00:11:20.101
Now I want to talk a little bit about some
of the other branches here that we have.

217
00:11:20.101 --> 00:11:23.369
Now we start getting
into the current branch.

218
00:11:23.369 --> 00:11:28.064
Now, the current branch is an addition,
that yes, you get the newest features and

219
00:11:28.064 --> 00:11:31.767
builds, but that's not until
they're released to the public.

220
00:11:31.767 --> 00:11:32.744
Once they're released, and

00:11:32.744 --> 00:11:35.390
that doesn't mean they're going to

222
00:11:35.390 --> 00:11:40.460
But, current branch servicing model says
the moment we release these to the market,

223
00:11:40.460 --> 00:11:41.250
you're gonna get them.

224
00:11:41.250 --> 00:11:43.822
You're gonna get them just as soon
as they come out to the public.

I really don't have any option.

464
00:22:45.621 --> 00:22:48.264
And you can see that in Pro and
Enterprise, it tells you.

465
00:22:48.264 --> 00:22:52.650
This can defer upgrades until the next
upgrade period, a few months.

466
00:22:52.650 --> 00:22:54.060
So you can defer them for a little bit,

467
00:22:54.060 --> 00:22:56.420
but you really don't have
much control past that.

468
00:22:56.420 --> 00:22:59.120
So how can we control
this a little bit more?

469
00:22:59.120 --> 00:23:02.810
Well, with group policy.

470
00:23:02.810 --> 00:23:06.930
With group policy we can control this, but
there are a few things that we have to do

471
00:23:06.930 --> 00:23:09.930
to get your active directory set up so
that you can control this.

472
00:23:09.930 --> 00:23:12.180
Let me go ahead, I'm gonna switch
over to my domain controller here.

473
00:23:12.180 --> 00:23:15.350
Get loged back in, and
let me show you what you have to do.

474
00:23:15.350 --> 00:23:19.618
You have to browse to Microsoft's website,
and

475
00:23:19.618 --> 00:23:25.670
you're gonna look for
Windows 10_version 1511 admx files.

476
00:23:25.670 --> 00:23:28.366
And you say,
why would I need those admx files?

477
00:23:28.366 --> 00:23:31.092
I've gone ahead and
I've made a little GPO here, and

478
00:23:31.092 --> 00:23:33.647
this GPO's called
Windows Servicing Branches.

479
00:23:33.647 --> 00:23:36.452
If I go ahead, what we're going to
do is I'm going to open that up.

480
00:23:36.452 --> 00:23:40.764
We're going to choose Edit, and I'm going
to go back to those same locations.

481
00:23:40.764 --> 00:23:41.515
That we were before.

482
00:23:41.515 --> 00:23:44.785
Now, remember,
with Group Policy in Active Directory,

483
00:23:44.785 --> 00:23:48.800
we go to Policies > Administrative
Templates > Windows Components.

484
00:23:48.800 --> 00:23:53.830
Scroll all the way down to the bottom,
and you have Windows Update.

485
00:23:53.830 --> 00:23:58.900
Now, Dan, you've seen in
the last Local Group Policy,

486
00:23:58.900 --> 00:24:00.778
that we had a setting in
here that's missing here.

487
00:24:00.778 --> 00:24:04.120
I don't see any defer updates.

488
00:24:04.120 --> 00:24:07.150
All right, that isn't included by default.

489
00:24:07.150 --> 00:24:08.560
Okay, so here's what you have to do.

490
00:24:09.620 --> 00:24:13.210
Once you download the ADMX files,
it will give you an MSI file, and

491
00:24:13.210 --> 00:24:15.109
I've got that MSI file right here.

492
00:24:16.160 --> 00:24:18.850
We can look at the properties so
that you can see what the name is, right,

493
00:24:18.850 --> 00:24:19.800
version 10.

494
00:24:19.800 --> 00:24:24.910
I get Windows10_version_1511,
that's the build that we're looking for.

495
00:24:26.460 --> 00:24:30.110
Now, we're gonna go ahead and
run this and it's just an MSI file so

496
00:24:30.110 --> 00:24:31.769
it's gonna start at
the Windows installer service.

497
00:24:33.530 --> 00:24:36.030
And we'll go ahead,
give this a second, and let it run.

498
00:24:36.030 --> 00:24:39.300
Now, what it's gonna do is it's
gonna create a directory, and

499
00:24:39.300 --> 00:24:43.900
the directory is going to be
inside of your programX86 folder.

500
00:24:43.900 --> 00:24:47.010
So we're gonna choose next.

501
00:24:47.010 --> 00:24:48.790
We'll accept the end
user license agreement.

502
00:24:48.790 --> 00:24:49.910
Of course, we'll scroll through and

503
00:24:49.910 --> 00:24:54.210
read all this really fast, and we'll ask
Dan about it at the end of the show.

504
00:24:54.210 --> 00:24:54.950
And we'll choose next.

505
00:24:54.950 --> 00:24:55.780
No, just kidding.

506
00:24:55.780 --> 00:24:59.580
All right and we're gonna, I'm gonna go
ahead and I'll apply this to everyone,

507
00:24:59.580 --> 00:25:00.540
not just me.

508
00:25:00.540 --> 00:25:03.670
>> You can ask me about it,
I'm not gonna give you the right answers.

509
00:25:03.670 --> 00:25:05.610
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

510
00:25:05.610 --> 00:25:07.070
All right, so
we're gonna choose next here.

511
00:25:07.070 --> 00:25:10.320
And then we'll choose next,
and next, next, next, next.

512
00:25:10.320 --> 00:25:11.470
So, what's next?

513
00:25:11.470 --> 00:25:12.550
More next.

514
00:25:12.550 --> 00:25:13.580
We'll let that go.

515
00:25:13.580 --> 00:25:16.890
And again, I'll go ahead and
we'll be a little proactive here.

516
00:25:16.890 --> 00:25:19.480
I'll get down into local disk C,
program x86 files.

517
00:25:19.480 --> 00:25:21.010
We'll wait a second.

518
00:25:21.010 --> 00:25:25.480
And once this finishes, I'll do
a refresh on our file explorer here.

519
00:25:25.480 --> 00:25:28.380
What it's doing is it's
creating a directory there.

520
00:25:28.380 --> 00:25:30.920
Now when it creates that directory,
what is it doing?

521
00:25:30.920 --> 00:25:34.530
It is dumping in that
directory your ADMX files,

522
00:25:34.530 --> 00:25:37.440
which are your settings that
you see inside a group policy.

523
00:25:37.440 --> 00:25:41.530
And it also has your ADML files,
which are your language files.

524
00:25:41.530 --> 00:25:47.305
You need this to be able to configure
these deferments of upgrades.

525
00:25:47.305 --> 00:25:48.380
We'll go ahead and choose close.

526
00:25:49.470 --> 00:25:51.780
We'll open this up and sure enough,
right there in the middle,

527
00:25:51.780 --> 00:25:53.940
you see Microsoft Group Policy, all right?

528
00:25:55.420 --> 00:25:56.780
Open that up, right?

529
00:25:56.780 --> 00:25:59.360
Notice I have that Policies and
Definitions folder.

530
00:25:59.360 --> 00:26:03.440
Well, let me show you a couple of things
that might make it easier for you.

531
00:26:03.440 --> 00:26:05.890
By default if you try to
put these ADMX files and

532
00:26:05.890 --> 00:26:09.260
you try to overwrite the existing files,
it starts to give you a problem and

533
00:26:09.260 --> 00:26:11.630
it says try this again,
try this again, you need permission.

534
00:26:11.630 --> 00:26:14.590
And before you know it,
you're not really doing anything.

535
00:26:14.590 --> 00:26:18.410
So I'm gonna go into Windows, I'm going
to look for my policies and definitions

536
00:26:18.410 --> 00:26:22.720
folder, and I'm actually going to cut this
and I'm going to copy it to the desktop.

537
00:26:24.010 --> 00:26:24.950
All right, notice it's gone.

538
00:26:26.110 --> 00:26:29.420
If you try to paste over it,
you're not going to have any luck.

539
00:26:29.420 --> 00:26:33.040
So now that I've got that,
I'm going to come back here and

540
00:26:33.040 --> 00:26:36.450
I'm going to copy the policies and
definitions folder and

541
00:26:36.450 --> 00:26:38.480
I'm going to put it right
back in this location.

542
00:26:41.960 --> 00:26:45.230
Believe me,
you want to cut that first one out.

543
00:26:45.230 --> 00:26:49.090
You will get all these warnings that say,
try again, try again, try again.

544
00:26:49.090 --> 00:26:52.090
And then eventually you will hit cancel.

545
00:26:52.090 --> 00:26:56.940
Now if I go back to, and let me, I did
that really quick, let me kind of explain.

546
00:26:56.940 --> 00:27:00.230
Cuz I said, hey, we got ADMX files and
we got ADML files.

547
00:27:00.230 --> 00:27:02.410
Let me show you what I mean, guys,
rather than just tell you and

548
00:27:02.410 --> 00:27:05.180
not actually show you, all right?

549
00:27:05.180 --> 00:27:08.170
So, what it did is it copied
all of our ADMX files, and

550
00:27:08.170 --> 00:27:11.412
these are our settings inside of
a group policy that we configure.

551
00:27:11.412 --> 00:27:14.350
If that seems a little bit foreign to you,
jump over to our group

552
00:27:14.350 --> 00:27:20.080
policy inside of Windows Server 2016 and
you can learn a lot more about that.

553
00:27:20.080 --> 00:27:24.140
The ADML files that we have in here, and
you can see there's a lot more languages

554
00:27:24.140 --> 00:27:29.500
than just English, so
it could be a different region.

555
00:27:29.500 --> 00:27:33.020
Whatever the language is, if it's
appropriate for you, you'll be covered.

556
00:27:33.020 --> 00:27:34.880
I noticed that we have ADML files in here.

557
00:27:34.880 --> 00:27:37.640
These render it in a specific language.

558
00:27:37.640 --> 00:27:39.560
Now that that's done, let me go ahead and

559
00:27:39.560 --> 00:27:42.610
I'll close down this group
policy that we're editing.

560
00:27:42.610 --> 00:27:44.950
And I'm going to go ahead and
I'm going to right click and

561
00:27:44.950 --> 00:27:46.669
I'm going to choose edit again.

562
00:27:48.250 --> 00:27:53.650
Now we're gonna go back to policies, we're
gonna expand out administrative templates

563
00:27:53.650 --> 00:27:55.550
and we're gonna expand
out Window's components.

564
00:27:56.760 --> 00:28:00.220
Again, scrolling all the way down to
the bottom and you'll see Windows update.

565
00:28:00.220 --> 00:28:04.980
Now I want you to check this out.

566
00:28:04.980 --> 00:28:10.460
Notice that now in the middle we
have defer upgrades and updates.

567
00:28:10.460 --> 00:28:14.150
And if I double-click this,
you'll see that we've got some

568
00:28:14.150 --> 00:28:18.120
options that we didn't have in
the long-term service branching.

569
00:28:18.120 --> 00:28:22.100
If I choose enable,
I can say, defer upgrades for

570
00:28:22.100 --> 00:28:24.390
the following duration
of months if I want.

571
00:28:24.390 --> 00:28:25.800
I could pause them, right?

572
00:28:25.800 --> 00:28:28.650
And I believe,
I think this goes up to eight.

573
00:28:28.650 --> 00:28:29.860
Yeah, maximum is eight.

574
00:28:29.860 --> 00:28:33.440
By default, if you don't configure it and
you defer it, it's four months.

575
00:28:33.440 --> 00:28:37.900
But you can actually bump this up
a little bit farther if you want.

576
00:28:37.900 --> 00:28:42.840
If you have an issue that arises during
one of your machines doing an upgrade,

577
00:28:42.840 --> 00:28:43.890
just pause it.

578
00:28:43.890 --> 00:28:45.730
Pause upgrades and updates.

579
00:28:45.730 --> 00:28:47.100
Make it a little bit easier for you.

580
00:28:47.100 --> 00:28:51.220
So Dan, this is a new servicing model.

581
00:28:51.220 --> 00:28:53.230
It's come into Windows, and

582
00:28:53.230 --> 00:28:56.620
it's pretty much shaken up
the whole Windows environment.

583
00:28:56.620 --> 00:29:02.110
We're used to our Windows updates,
we're used to using things like WSUS.

584
00:29:02.110 --> 00:29:04.810
Here, they've kind of launched
us into a new servicing model.

585
00:29:04.810 --> 00:29:06.620
And one of the reasons
we're explaining it,

586
00:29:06.620 --> 00:29:08.520
I know it's not probably the fun stuff.

587
00:29:08.520 --> 00:29:10.560
At least we can get in and
show you some of the things,

588
00:29:10.560 --> 00:29:12.010
rather than just talk about them.

589
00:29:12.010 --> 00:29:14.910
But I do want you to keep this in mind for
the exam.

590
00:29:14.910 --> 00:29:17.750
The other thing that they call
out are the Windows Store apps.

591
00:29:17.750 --> 00:29:18.990
Updating Windows Store apps.

592
00:29:18.990 --> 00:29:22.850
Now I wish I have something fancy to show
you on this, but this is nothing more than

593
00:29:22.850 --> 00:29:26.040
logging in with your Microsoft account,
launching the Windows Store.

594
00:29:26.040 --> 00:29:30.370
And if you have existing Windows apps
installed uou'll see little flags in there

595
00:29:30.370 --> 00:29:34.120
that'll tell you in the upper right-hand
corner hey, you've got two, maybe three,

596
00:29:34.120 --> 00:29:35.370
four updates.

597
00:29:35.370 --> 00:29:39.190
You click Update and it'll go through and
it'll update all of the Windows Store

598
00:29:39.190 --> 00:29:43.220
apps, no different than some of the other
mobile markets that you've probably seen.

599
00:29:43.220 --> 00:29:45.000
>> Yeah, it's an interesting
new model they've got here.

600
00:29:45.000 --> 00:29:52.040
I'll be looking forward to seeing how
well it plays out in the culture of IT.

601
00:29:52.040 --> 00:29:54.912
Cuz you know, a lot of times we
rail against new things, and

602
00:29:54.912 --> 00:29:58.606
then by the time it's five years old,
we don't know how we live without it.

603
00:29:58.606 --> 00:30:02.179
Everybody might be hating it now, but ten
years from now, that's how we do it man.

604
00:30:02.179 --> 00:30:04.905
Don't you change it,
cuz that's the way I like it.

605
00:30:04.905 --> 00:30:06.244
I guarantee that's how it's gonna go.

606
00:30:06.244 --> 00:30:08.627
Wes, we thank you for
explaining it to us so

607
00:30:08.627 --> 00:30:12.813
that we are now up on top of the bleeding
edge of Microsoft and Windows 10.

608
00:30:12.813 --> 00:30:15.568
That being said, it looks like we've come
to the end of another great episode.

609
00:30:15.568 --> 00:30:16.395
We thank you for stopping by.

610
00:30:16.395 --> 00:30:17.686
We thank you for watching.

611
00:30:17.686 --> 00:30:18.610
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

612
00:30:18.610 --> 00:30:20.966
For IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery,

613
00:30:20.966 --> 00:30:21.895
>> And I'm Wes Brian.

614
00:30:21.895 --> 00:30:23.591
And we'll see you next time.

615
00:30:23.591 --> 00:30:29.566
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show how to configure monitoring tools built into Windows 10 and verify that they are working.  The start by demonstrating the different logs found in the Event Viewer and how to verify that the logs are working.  They also show how to configure Event Subscriptions.  They also show the improved task manger tabs and the detailed information it how can show a technician.
episodes.title: Monitoring Windows
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:10.002
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.657 --> 00:00:15.150
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:15.150 --> 00:00:19.070
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today,
we're actually going in to Windows 10.

4
00:00:19.070 --> 00:00:21.635
We're taking a look installing and
configuring, and

5
00:00:21.635 --> 00:00:25.142
what we want to do today of course, is
take a look at how we can monitor some of

6
00:00:25.142 --> 00:00:28.229
the different things that
are happening inside of Windows 10.

7
00:00:28.229 --> 00:00:32.983
And who better to help us other than
well Windows 10 man himself, Wes Brian.

8
00:00:32.983 --> 00:00:34.938
How are you doing?
>> I'm doing okay, thanks Ronnie for

9
00:00:34.938 --> 00:00:35.629
having me here.

10
00:00:35.629 --> 00:00:37.981
As always, great to be with ITPro.TV crew.

11
00:00:37.981 --> 00:00:42.005
That's right, we're probably gonna be
working on a small mini series here when

12
00:00:42.005 --> 00:00:43.670
it comes to monitoring Windows.

13
00:00:43.670 --> 00:00:44.590
Well why is that?

14
00:00:44.590 --> 00:00:47.530
Well when it comes to monitoring Windows,
you have a lot of options.

15
00:00:47.530 --> 00:00:51.556
And we're gonna go through some of the
objectives if you will that they call out.

16
00:00:51.556 --> 00:00:55.452
So you'll know what are some of the
components you'll be required to know when

17
00:00:55.452 --> 00:00:57.705
you get in there and
your gonna take the exam.

18
00:00:57.705 --> 00:01:01.445
So one of the very first ones that we're
gonna look at is we're gonna look at

19
00:01:01.445 --> 00:01:02.226
a Event Viewer log.

20
00:01:02.226 --> 00:01:05.140
One of things is being able to configure
and analyze a Event Viewer logs.

21
00:01:05.140 --> 00:01:08.724
So I'll tell you what rather than just
talk about it why don't we go ahead and

22
00:01:08.724 --> 00:01:10.462
dive in and see what we can find here?

23
00:01:10.462 --> 00:01:11.960
So I'm gonna go ahead and
open Event Viewer.

24
00:01:11.960 --> 00:01:15.973
And from the desktop here we're just gonna
right-click on our little start icon here.

25
00:01:15.973 --> 00:01:18.620
And from the click links we're
just gonna choose Event Viewer.

26
00:01:20.160 --> 00:01:22.710
Now this is the event viewer console here.

27
00:01:22.710 --> 00:01:25.454
You'll see you've got
a couple of panes here.

28
00:01:25.454 --> 00:01:30.280
On the left hand side here we have the
different various logs and subscriptions.

29
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:31.590
We'll get into that here in a second.

30
00:01:31.590 --> 00:01:36.102
We've got the central pane, central
pane here is the summary pane as well as

31
00:01:36.102 --> 00:01:38.514
what's known as the Actions pane here.

32
00:01:38.514 --> 00:01:41.989
Which really can do a lot of the same
things that a right-click can do for you,

33
00:01:41.989 --> 00:01:44.250
in different locations
within Event Viewer.

34
00:01:44.250 --> 00:01:45.799
And really when it comes down to it,

35
00:01:45.799 --> 00:01:49.014
a lot of the other Microsoft management
consoles that you're gonna use.

36
00:01:49.014 --> 00:01:51.047
So one of the first things
I wanna look at for

37
00:01:51.047 --> 00:01:53.430
instance you have what
are known as Custom Views.

38
00:01:53.430 --> 00:01:57.050
And in the Custom Views events
logs you have what are called as

39
00:01:57.050 --> 00:01:58.690
Administrative Events.

40
00:01:58.690 --> 00:02:01.810
And I'm gonna go ahead and just kind
of move this down so you guys can see.

41
00:02:01.810 --> 00:02:05.148
And we've got all different
types of events here.

42
00:02:05.148 --> 00:02:06.920
If I double-click on one of these events,

43
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:09.050
you can get a little
more information on it.

44
00:02:09.050 --> 00:02:13.438
If I want to, I can always filter
the Custom View here from the Action pane,

45
00:02:13.438 --> 00:02:14.356
if I wanted to.

46
00:02:14.356 --> 00:02:17.584
It doesn't look like they give
you too many options there,

47
00:02:17.584 --> 00:02:21.654
but remember that in the Action pane
you always have the Filter Current View

48
00:02:21.654 --> 00:02:24.898
if you're trying to find maybe
one specific type of event.

49
00:02:24.898 --> 00:02:29.548
Now, the ones that we really look at
a lot is the next one on the list here,

50
00:02:29.548 --> 00:02:32.020
and that is well the Windows Logs.

51
00:02:32.020 --> 00:02:36.070
If we expand that out, we've got a common
set of logs that we need to be aware of.

52
00:02:36.070 --> 00:02:40.102
Application, Security, System,
Setup and Forwarded Events.

53
00:02:40.102 --> 00:02:43.685
The Application,
if you click on that, you can see,

54
00:02:43.685 --> 00:02:47.358
give it a second here and
it should show us some events.

55
00:02:47.358 --> 00:02:50.731
Sometimes you'll get some events, if you
don't have any applications installed

56
00:02:50.731 --> 00:02:52.380
which might be the case on this machine.

57
00:02:52.380 --> 00:02:55.034
I don't think I really [LAUGH]
have any applications installed so

58
00:02:55.034 --> 00:02:56.860
you might not see any
information in there.

59
00:02:56.860 --> 00:02:58.660
You also have Security logs.

60
00:02:58.660 --> 00:03:03.340
Now Security logs, keep in mind what they
do is they audit things like file object

61
00:03:03.340 --> 00:03:08.040
access, resource access if you will,
log ons, log offs.

62
00:03:08.040 --> 00:03:12.540
When certain systems services perform
elevated functions even though we're not

63
00:03:12.540 --> 00:03:15.530
really dealing with them too much,
there happen in the background.

64
00:03:15.530 --> 00:03:18.060
We can save this information
right here if we want.

65
00:03:18.060 --> 00:03:22.050
And again, if you'll notice over here on
the right hand side, just above my head

66
00:03:22.050 --> 00:03:27.240
there, there's that Filter Current Log and
we could always do that too depending on

67
00:03:27.240 --> 00:03:30.770
what is available for us,
what kind of logs we're looking at.

68
00:03:30.770 --> 00:03:33.195
We could filter it out
if we wanted as well.

It's got a good look to it.

The only thing I will tell you that I

That's in a component called

Maybe you're on a mobile device or

00:29:32.960 --> 00:29:35.100

So you can see CPU time, you can see

Tile updates, when they refresh,

00:30:09.272 --> 00:30:13.870

This is what we're talking about,

So this is all about

And I could also delete

Now, for me, that would be pretty easy, I

581

All right, we also got the Startup tab,

Because this one did change kind of

Make sure you understand those different

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue to show some other monitoring tools available in Windows 10. They also demonstrate the real time resource usage and realtime performance monitoring Windows 10 can do.  They also show the ability to create data collector sets, this allows for collecting data over time for comparison basis.  The guys also show how to install, monitor and manage printers and print jobs, respectively.   All these tools are not additional tools but built in tools to demonstrate the completeness of Windows 10 to help the technician support this operation system.
episodes.title: Monitoring Windows Part 2

I do want you to know that
Microsoft management console,

543
00:28:01.305 --> 00:28:06.920
I have to find out why that's not actually
working the way we want, lovely Windows.

544
00:28:06.920 --> 00:28:11.700
We'll go to System and
Security > Administrative Tools, and

545
00:28:11.700 --> 00:28:15.480
then somewhere in this list we
should see Print Management.

546
00:28:15.480 --> 00:28:16.270
We'll go ahead and run that.

547
00:28:16.270 --> 00:28:18.930
And that's what it should've done
the first time, [LAUGH] honestly,

548
00:28:18.930 --> 00:28:22.320
I'm not exactly sure why it
wasn't launching the second time.

549
00:28:22.320 --> 00:28:26.000
But anyways, we are there now, all right?

550
00:28:26.000 --> 00:28:30.590
Just took a longer trip,
longer time to get to our destination.

551
00:28:30.590 --> 00:28:36.330
All right, so if I select over here on the
left-hand side, if I select all printers,

552
00:28:36.330 --> 00:28:39.648
notice I have that dev printer,
shows up right away, all right?

553
00:28:39.648 --> 00:28:43.320
If I right-click on that dev printer,

554
00:28:43.320 --> 00:28:46.220
I've got a series of options that
allows me to manage this printer.

555
00:28:46.220 --> 00:28:48.380
Notice I can open the printer queue,
right?

556
00:28:48.380 --> 00:28:50.350
We'll get back to that print
queue here in a second.

557
00:28:50.350 --> 00:28:54.150
Because what I wanna do, is,
I wanna right-click and pause the printer.

558
00:28:54.150 --> 00:28:56.790
Notice that it says that
the queue status is paused.

559
00:28:56.790 --> 00:28:57.790
All right?

560
00:28:57.790 --> 00:29:00.110
Let's show you that we
are managing this printer.

561
00:29:00.110 --> 00:29:03.370
Let's switch back over and
let's print our test page.

562
00:29:03.370 --> 00:29:04.780
Now when I do this,

563
00:29:04.780 --> 00:29:09.590
it's gonna slide out just beneath my
head here on the right-hand side.

564
00:29:09.590 --> 00:29:14.620
When I say print test page, look what
happens here on the lower right-hand side.

565
00:29:14.620 --> 00:29:16.520
Printer's paused All right?

566
00:29:16.520 --> 00:29:20.110
When I say print test page, look what
happens here on the lower right-hand side.

567
00:29:20.110 --> 00:29:22.939
When I say print test page,

568
00:29:22.939 --> 00:29:28.600
look what happens here on
the lower right-hand side.

569
00:29:29.620 --> 00:29:31.590
And what does this give
me the ability to do?

570
00:29:31.590 --> 00:29:35.370
When I say print test page, look what
happens here on the lower right-hand side.

571
00:29:35.370 --> 00:29:40.640
I can right-click on this and if I wanted
to, I could right-click, choose Pause.

572
00:29:40.640 --> 00:29:43.150
It's already paused, ll so
I don't have to worry about that.

573
00:29:43.150 --> 00:29:45.910
I could choose Restart,
I could choose cancel, or

574
00:29:45.910 --> 00:29:47.930
I could even choose properties, right?

575
00:29:47.930 --> 00:29:51.210
If I choose Properties, it'll show me.

576
00:29:51.210 --> 00:29:53.510
Now this isn't the properties
of the printer.

577
00:29:53.510 --> 00:29:56.280
Please understand,
that's a little bit different, all right?

578
00:29:56.280 --> 00:29:59.150
This is the properties of the print job.

579
00:29:59.150 --> 00:30:03.500
And I can see what the data type is,
who the owner was, when it was submitted.

580
00:30:03.500 --> 00:30:06.200
And I can set it to a priority if I want,
right?

581
00:30:06.200 --> 00:30:11.180
I'm not gonna change anything there,
but notice the print queue.

582
00:30:11.180 --> 00:30:15.230
Let's see if we can go back and
we can unpause that, right,

583
00:30:15.230 --> 00:30:17.160
we'll resume printing.

584
00:30:17.160 --> 00:30:21.790
And we'll go back to the print queue and
look at there, it's gone, right?

585
00:30:21.790 --> 00:30:24.930
I also have the ability
if I wanted to as I could

586
00:30:24.930 --> 00:30:28.140
choose the properties from right
here if I wanted to, right?

587
00:30:28.140 --> 00:30:30.790
So there's a couple different things
with this interface that you can do when

588
00:30:30.790 --> 00:30:31.370
you right-click.

589
00:30:31.370 --> 00:30:34.110
Notice the properties there and
if I decide that I wanna right-click and

590
00:30:34.110 --> 00:30:38.450
I wanna manage sharing, [LAUGH] notice
it brings you to the same location.

591
00:30:38.450 --> 00:30:39.370
Just a different tab.

592
00:30:39.370 --> 00:30:42.520
So you get the option here that you
can modify things like your printer

593
00:30:42.520 --> 00:30:44.060
preferences.

594
00:30:44.060 --> 00:30:45.850
Printing test pages.

595
00:30:45.850 --> 00:30:48.940
Remember the port that we
set was the null local port?

596
00:30:48.940 --> 00:30:52.300
Well, I can see that right here and if,
well, Wes, you set the printer up and

597
00:30:52.300 --> 00:30:56.550
you set it up wrong, it needs a COM port,
it needs one of your communication ports

598
00:30:56.550 --> 00:30:59.485
or for whatever reason it needs
one of the old LTP ports.

599
00:30:59.485 --> 00:31:02.670
Well, you have the ability that you
can change that after the fact.

600
00:31:02.670 --> 00:31:05.020
Now, this is the other thing
that's kind of cool too.

601
00:31:05.020 --> 00:31:07.670
I can do time restrictive printing.

602
00:31:07.670 --> 00:31:11.410
I could say, well, this printer is only
gonna be available from this time,

603
00:31:11.410 --> 00:31:12.930
all right, and
I could set a priority on it.

604
00:31:15.650 --> 00:31:17.840
Again, you could add things
like your separator pages here,

605
00:31:17.840 --> 00:31:21.820
you can do full print management
on any one of the printers.

606
00:31:21.820 --> 00:31:24.590
I can do that on any one of
the printers in this list.

607
00:31:24.590 --> 00:31:29.028
So you get the ability to do full
print management from the print

608
00:31:29.028 --> 00:31:32.221
management console inside of Windows 10.

609
00:31:32.221 --> 00:31:34.080
>> All right, Wes, well, thank you for

610
00:31:34.080 --> 00:31:37.687
helping us out again on taking a look
a little bit more about monitoring but

611
00:31:37.687 --> 00:31:39.977
I believe were gonna have
to go to a part three.

612
00:31:39.977 --> 00:31:44.100
Because we still have plenty of
different tools out there to help us.

613
00:31:44.100 --> 00:31:46.590
But remember what you
also saw in this episode.

614
00:31:46.590 --> 00:31:50.600
We took a look at using the resource
monitor as well as the performance monitor

615
00:31:50.600 --> 00:31:52.930
and also using data collector sets.

616
00:31:52.930 --> 00:31:54.380
Resource monitor, performance monitor,

617
00:31:54.380 --> 00:31:58.040
great real time event type of things
that we have to keep track of.

618
00:31:58.040 --> 00:32:00.880
But overall, though, if you need
to actually compare that against

619
00:32:00.880 --> 00:32:05.660
something else using those data collector
sets are gonna be also the key here too.

620
00:32:05.660 --> 00:32:09.450
So make sure you go back and understand
these things before you get into the exam.

621
00:32:09.450 --> 00:32:14.140
Also, of course, printers are usually
a big part of any Windows exam, and so

622
00:32:14.140 --> 00:32:17.590
you wanna make sure that you do
have those concepts down and

623
00:32:17.590 --> 00:32:20.090
make sure that they do
not confuse you at all.

624
00:32:20.090 --> 00:32:24.056
Make sure you know the difference between
managing that print job versus managing

625
00:32:24.056 --> 00:32:26.944
the printer itself in terms of
the printer properties too.

626
00:32:26.944 --> 00:32:30.406
So those are all key elements when
you're actually getting ready for

627
00:32:30.406 --> 00:32:33.757
that 70-698 exam,
cuz it's really gonna help you out too.

628
00:32:33.757 --> 00:32:36.990
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

629
00:32:36.990 --> 00:32:40.160
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

630
00:32:40.160 --> 00:32:41.150
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

631
00:32:41.150 --> 00:32:44.923
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Windows 10 episodes.

632
00:32:44.923 --> 00:32:50.074
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue looking at monitoring features found in Windows 10. Here they explore how to configure the indexing options, Windows Defender, the Reliability Monitor, and the Performance Monitor.
episodes.title: Monitoring Windows Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.062 --> 00:00:13.352
All right, greetings everyone.

3
00:00:13.352 --> 00:00:16.130
And welcome to another
great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.130 --> 00:00:17.120
I'm you host, Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:17.120 --> 00:00:20.670
And in today's episode we continue
with our Windows 10 series.

6
00:00:20.670 --> 00:00:21.900
More of that coming at you.

7
00:00:21.900 --> 00:00:24.920
Joining us in the studio again today
to lend his expertise on that topic,

8
00:00:24.920 --> 00:00:26.150
our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

9
00:00:26.150 --> 00:00:27.050
Wes, welcome back, sir.

10
00:00:27.050 --> 00:00:28.070
So glad to have you.

11
00:00:28.070 --> 00:00:29.270
What are we gonna learn today?

12
00:00:29.270 --> 00:00:30.030
>> That's right.

13
00:00:30.030 --> 00:00:31.210
I have talked a bunch.

14
00:00:31.210 --> 00:00:33.110
We're working on a small miniseries here,
and

15
00:00:33.110 --> 00:00:35.540
we're coming back with
more monitoring Windows.

16
00:00:35.540 --> 00:00:37.650
That's right,
part three in monitoring Windows.

17
00:00:37.650 --> 00:00:41.550
In a couple of the other parts
here that we have, if you will,

18
00:00:41.550 --> 00:00:45.380
we've talked about things like the
performance monitor, the resource monitor.

19
00:00:45.380 --> 00:00:47.090
We've looked at Task Manager.

20
00:00:47.090 --> 00:00:50.550
We've got a few more that we need to
look at so that we can pretty much

21
00:00:50.550 --> 00:00:56.000
wrap up monitoring Windows, if you will,
and so you'll be prepared for the exam.

22
00:00:56.000 --> 00:00:59.180
The next one that we're gonna jump
into is what's known as indexing.

23
00:00:59.180 --> 00:01:03.450
It's one of the things they
call out in the exam objectives

24
00:01:03.450 --> 00:01:06.730
in 7698 is configuring indexing options.

25
00:01:06.730 --> 00:01:08.220
Let me go ahead, let's dive right in here.

26
00:01:08.220 --> 00:01:10.480
And I've got a file on the desktop.

27
00:01:10.480 --> 00:01:12.410
It's just BgInfo from Sysinternals.

28
00:01:12.410 --> 00:01:13.170
We use it all the time.

29
00:01:13.170 --> 00:01:14.640
You've probably seen it before.

30
00:01:14.640 --> 00:01:17.930
And I'm just gonna use it to demonstrate,
well, indexing.

31
00:01:17.930 --> 00:01:19.170
Well, what is indexing?

32
00:01:19.170 --> 00:01:23.558
Well, indexing is actually
an attribute of the file system, and

33
00:01:23.558 --> 00:01:27.480
it isn't turned on on
all files by default.

34
00:01:27.480 --> 00:01:31.280
But if you ever maybe launch up
the Windows Search and it goes through and

35
00:01:31.280 --> 00:01:36.210
it searches and it searches and then it
searches and you get up, you go away,

36
00:01:36.210 --> 00:01:39.260
you grab some coffee, you come back,
and you still haven't found that file.

37
00:01:39.260 --> 00:01:43.420
Well, that's because chances
are the indexing option isn't turned on,

38
00:01:43.420 --> 00:01:44.050
on that file.

39
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:44.870
Let me show you what I mean.

40
00:01:44.870 --> 00:01:48.830
If I right click on this file here,
just choose properties.

41
00:01:48.830 --> 00:01:53.770
And down here at the bottom, we go to
our attributes, we choose advanced,

42
00:01:53.770 --> 00:01:54.930
you'll see that there's an option.

43
00:01:54.930 --> 00:01:56.470
These are some of the extra attributes.

44
00:01:56.470 --> 00:01:58.530
We talked about the basic
ones in other shows?

45
00:01:58.530 --> 00:02:00.580
Read only, archive, system and hidden.

46
00:02:00.580 --> 00:02:02.890
Well, there's some extended attributes,
if you will, here.

47
00:02:02.890 --> 00:02:05.460
In Windows you have the compression
attribute and encryption but

48
00:02:05.460 --> 00:02:07.550
you also have one called indexing.

49
00:02:07.550 --> 00:02:11.320
And notice that it says allow
this file to have the contents

50
00:02:11.320 --> 00:02:14.730
indexed in addition to
the file properties.

51
00:02:14.730 --> 00:02:20.070
Well, that indexing option, what that
does is that it allows me the ability to

52
00:02:20.070 --> 00:02:22.350
find these files a little bit quicker.

53
00:02:22.350 --> 00:02:23.498
So, it improves performance.

54
00:02:23.498 --> 00:02:28.520
But I wanna show you something interesting
because in the context of attributes,

55
00:02:28.520 --> 00:02:33.210
typically when we assign an attribute,
that means that we're applying that

56
00:02:33.210 --> 00:02:37.244
attribute to that file, and for instance,
when we talk about the archive bit.

57
00:02:37.244 --> 00:02:42.310
Let me go ahead and I'll move on over
here to the desktop real quick so

58
00:02:42.310 --> 00:02:49.340
we can look at that attrib command that
we've looked at in other episodes.

59
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:51.500
And we'll get to the desktop here.

60
00:02:51.500 --> 00:02:54.700
If we do a DIR,
there you'll see that Bginfo file.

61
00:02:54.700 --> 00:03:01.620
Well if I do an a-t-t-r-i-b,
you'll notice the archive attributes.

62
00:03:01.620 --> 00:03:07.250
In this case we've got a desktop INI file
that's hidden by default in file explorer,

63
00:03:07.250 --> 00:03:09.560
if you will, or
Windows Explorer as it used to be called.

64
00:03:09.560 --> 00:03:11.640
Because, well, they don't want you
messing with it so it's hidden and

65
00:03:11.640 --> 00:03:12.870
it's a system file.

66
00:03:12.870 --> 00:03:15.390
But remember that the archive
file is also here.

67
00:03:15.390 --> 00:03:19.700
And the archive file tells the Windows
backup subsystem what to do with the file.

68
00:03:19.700 --> 00:03:22.480
If the archive bit is present,
it means if you run this backup,

69
00:03:22.480 --> 00:03:25.180
you'd better include this file
cuz you don't have a copy of it.

70
00:03:25.180 --> 00:03:26.800
But notice, more importantly,

71
00:03:26.800 --> 00:03:32.250
as we compare it to indexing that
the attribute is placed on the file.

72
00:03:32.250 --> 00:03:34.880
It tells the Windows subsystem what to do.

73
00:03:34.880 --> 00:03:35.870
And if I look.

74
00:03:35.870 --> 00:03:40.170
Well, if I do an a-t-t-r-i-b here,
or the attrib command,

75
00:03:40.170 --> 00:03:45.130
and I put a /?, you could see sets
an attribute with a plus symbol, and

76
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:48.340
I can set read only and I can set archive.

77
00:03:48.340 --> 00:03:50.210
Notice I can also set I.

78
00:03:50.210 --> 00:03:53.170
It says indexed file attribute.

79
00:03:53.170 --> 00:03:55.780
But the index attribute isn't on there.

80
00:03:55.780 --> 00:03:58.610
Well, I want you to remember this for the
exam cuz this is a little tricky when you

81
00:03:58.610 --> 00:04:02.090
look at attributes and what indexing is
doing for us and then you come to find out

82
00:04:02.090 --> 00:04:05.550
that when you apply the indexing
attribute, what does it do?

83
00:04:05.550 --> 00:04:06.650
Well, let's show you.

84
00:04:06.650 --> 00:04:09.370
Let's go ahead and,
I'll clear the screen a little bit,

85
00:04:09.370 --> 00:04:11.720
make this a little bit easier to see.

86
00:04:11.720 --> 00:04:15.540
And what we'll do is we'll
do an a-t-t-r-i-b and

87
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:20.080
we will go ahead and do a +i and
then we're gonna go ahead and

88
00:04:20.080 --> 00:04:23.830
we're gonna call out that file Bginfo and
we're gonna set it.

89
00:04:23.830 --> 00:04:25.250
Now it really doesn't
look like it did much.

90
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:29.280
But if I turned around and I run the
attrib command one more time, now you can

91
00:04:29.280 --> 00:04:35.560
see that the indexing attribute is there.

92
00:04:35.560 --> 00:04:41.120
So if you're thinking on the exam,
which would be logical deduction,

93
00:04:41.120 --> 00:04:43.290
logically deducing what the answer is,
I can say, well,

94
00:04:43.290 --> 00:04:46.490
if I've got an archive attribute, and
you're telling me that that allows me, or

95
00:04:46.490 --> 00:04:49.860
the backup subsystem to know, hey,
we need to keep a copy of this,

96
00:04:49.860 --> 00:04:55.590
then well certainly the indexing option
should help Windows search find it better.

97
00:04:56.790 --> 00:04:59.540
Fortunately, it's completely opposite.

98
00:04:59.540 --> 00:05:00.630
Let me show you what I mean.

99
00:05:00.630 --> 00:05:04.860
Notice that we did put, on that file,
we put the index attribute.

100
00:05:06.240 --> 00:05:11.130
Let me go ahead and go back to our GUI
here, for a second and choose advanced.

101
00:05:11.130 --> 00:05:14.719
And I want you to see what happens
when I apply the indexing attribute.

102
00:05:15.770 --> 00:05:18.560
It's the complete opposite
of what you might think.

103
00:05:18.560 --> 00:05:21.790
And that's one of the reasons I
just talk about the command prompt

104
00:05:21.790 --> 00:05:24.810
in relationship to that
indexing attribute.

105
00:05:26.060 --> 00:05:29.200
Because if they give you on the exam, for
instance, they give you a little command

106
00:05:29.200 --> 00:05:34.300
prompt and it says you wanna make
sure that this file is indexed, and

107
00:05:34.300 --> 00:05:39.210
if we go back to our powershell,
if that happens to be what is opened,

108
00:05:39.210 --> 00:05:41.939
I might say, well, you know what?

109
00:05:41.939 --> 00:05:43.301
There's the indexing attribute.

110
00:05:43.301 --> 00:05:46.970
That means that it must be ready,
like the archive bit, it must be ready for

111
00:05:46.970 --> 00:05:48.460
the Windows search.

112
00:05:48.460 --> 00:05:49.860
But I want you to pay attention,

113
00:05:49.860 --> 00:05:54.302
one more time,
to what that says in the switches here.

114
00:05:54.302 --> 00:05:57.940
Not content indexed.

115
00:05:57.940 --> 00:05:59.900
Excuse me, if I could speak right.

116
00:05:59.900 --> 00:06:03.200
What this is doing is
saying don't index it.

117
00:06:03.200 --> 00:06:07.680
So it's out of all of these
attributes that we have when we apply

118
00:06:07.680 --> 00:06:10.880
the attribute the R that
makes it read-only.

119
00:06:10.880 --> 00:06:14.210
When we apply the archive bit,
that says back it up.

120
00:06:14.210 --> 00:06:18.730
When we apply the system file,
it means Windows file protection,

121
00:06:18.730 --> 00:06:21.910
protect this,
this is part of your integrity.

122
00:06:21.910 --> 00:06:24.400
So, this is one that does
exactly the opposite.

123
00:06:24.400 --> 00:06:27.110
You apply the bit, and

124
00:06:27.110 --> 00:06:30.980
when you apply the bit it actually clears
it and doesn't allow it to be indexed.

125
00:06:30.980 --> 00:06:32.090
>> Well, that's intuitive, Wes.

126
00:06:32.090 --> 00:06:33.047
>> Yeah.
Absolutely.

127
00:06:33.047 --> 00:06:37.350
So you know, on is off and off is on, so

128
00:06:37.350 --> 00:06:41.770
I just kind of preface indexing with
that just because you never know.

129
00:06:41.770 --> 00:06:43.400
It might be something that
comes up on the exam.

130
00:06:43.400 --> 00:06:45.160
Now, there's other ways
that we can do indexing.

131
00:06:45.160 --> 00:06:48.535
We don't have to do the opposite
of what you might think here.

132
00:06:48.535 --> 00:06:49.780
[LAUGH]
>> With that in mind,

133
00:06:49.780 --> 00:06:52.570
I'm fully convinced at this point
that Microsoft is building their

134
00:06:52.570 --> 00:06:55.010
operating systems with
test questions in mind.

135

which is kinda interesting that that link
takes me back to the new interface, but

366
00:17:57.250 --> 00:18:01.190
the new interface doesn't take me
to the old so figure that one out.

367
00:18:01.190 --> 00:18:02.930
Now, I can customize our scans, right?

368
00:18:02.930 --> 00:18:06.799
I can do a quick scan and it scans,
I was gonna say very quickly,

369
00:18:06.799 --> 00:18:09.120
but that would be obvious, right?

370
00:18:09.120 --> 00:18:13.954
It scans common locations where files,
where malware is known to reside.

371
00:18:13.954 --> 00:18:18.430
All right, full scan guys, you know what
a full scan does, it scans everything.

372
00:18:18.430 --> 00:18:22.990
Now the custom scan is essentially
nothing more than a quick scan

373
00:18:22.990 --> 00:18:25.730
plus whatever you tell it to include.

374
00:18:25.730 --> 00:18:29.490
So no too big a problem there.

375
00:18:29.490 --> 00:18:33.830
Update again, that same information,
I can see virus definition.

376
00:18:33.830 --> 00:18:35.190
Databases here.

377
00:18:35.190 --> 00:18:40.620
I can do an update if I want to and
then history, all right?

378
00:18:40.620 --> 00:18:45.708
Now, this is another exam alert
I want you to be aware of.

379
00:18:45.708 --> 00:18:48.960
Notice that we have quarantine items,
allow items, and all detected items.

380
00:18:48.960 --> 00:18:51.090
Well, all detected items.

381
00:18:51.090 --> 00:18:53.700
So it's not really showing me anything.

382
00:18:53.700 --> 00:18:54.980
You have to be an administrator.

383
00:18:54.980 --> 00:18:57.370
Notice the View details
has a little shield on it.

384
00:18:57.370 --> 00:18:58.340
That's because,

385
00:18:58.340 --> 00:19:01.660
and according to Microsoft,
one of the reasons they explained that

386
00:19:01.660 --> 00:19:04.935
they require administrative level
privileges is because the information

387
00:19:04.935 --> 00:19:08.320
that's shown here about other users
could be sensitive information, right?

388
00:19:08.320 --> 00:19:09.410
They may not want you to know that.

389
00:19:09.410 --> 00:19:12.230
So they figure if you
are the administrator,

390
00:19:12.230 --> 00:19:14.910
doesn't matter if it's sensitive or
not, you should have access to it.

391
00:19:14.910 --> 00:19:18.580
So we don't have anything
detected here but

392
00:19:18.580 --> 00:19:22.870
if I did have something here
I could certainly remove it.

393
00:19:22.870 --> 00:19:24.850
I could apply a default
action to it as well.

394
00:19:24.850 --> 00:19:27.820
Wes, really quickly, are you able to
right-click on a folder or file and

395
00:19:27.820 --> 00:19:32.540
say scan with Windows Defender,
unlike many other types of anti-virus?

396
00:19:32.540 --> 00:19:33.790
>> Not really.

397
00:19:33.790 --> 00:19:38.260
I've seen some registry modifications
that you could do to put

00:19:38.260 --> 00:19:42.240
pretty much any application
in your right-click.

399
00:19:42.240 --> 00:19:43.050
I've done it before.

400
00:19:43.050 --> 00:19:45.770
I've actually right-clicked the desktop
and I've got PowerShell in there and

401
00:19:45.770 --> 00:19:47.420
I can just launch PowerShell.

402
00:19:47.420 --> 00:19:51.055
But not by default,
you have to unbreak it, if you will.

403
00:19:51.055 --> 00:19:54.724
[LAUGH] So
that's a little bit about your indexing,

404
00:19:54.724 --> 00:19:58.640
not your indexing options,
but Windows Defender.

405
00:19:58.640 --> 00:20:02.375
The next one I want to go to is what's
known as the Reliability Monitor.

406
00:20:02.375 --> 00:20:06.325
Now the Reliability Monitor is another one
you've got to kind of go walkabout for.

407
00:20:06.325 --> 00:20:10.315
And I'm going to go back to category view,
just so

408
00:20:10.315 --> 00:20:12.505
you guys can see what I mean
by a door in front of a door.

409
00:20:12.505 --> 00:20:13.755
So here's our utilities.

410
00:20:13.755 --> 00:20:14.415
Right?

411
00:20:14.415 --> 00:20:16.725
So I click, I open this door.

412
00:20:16.725 --> 00:20:18.150
And I go to this door.

413
00:20:18.150 --> 00:20:20.198
And then I open another door.

414
00:20:20.198 --> 00:20:21.738
And then I open another door.

415
00:20:21.738 --> 00:20:26.240
And then I finally can click
this reliability history.

416
00:20:26.240 --> 00:20:28.900
When it comes to reliability history,
guys, this is actually a really,

00:20:28.900 --> 00:20:29.690
really cool chart.

00:20:29.690 --> 00:20:31.330
It's been around for awhile.

419
00:20:31.330 --> 00:20:34.120
Back in the days of Vista,
it used to be called the performance and

420
00:20:34.120 --> 00:20:37.350
reliability monitor, and they used
to all be in computer management.

421
00:20:37.350 --> 00:20:39.610
When Windows 7 came out,
they decided, you know what?

422
00:20:39.610 --> 00:20:41.299
We're going to separate these and

423
00:20:41.299 --> 00:20:44.921
we're going to put them in the
Reliability Monitor in the Action Center.

424
00:20:44.921 --> 00:20:47.790
We'll keep Performance Monitor
where it's always been.

425
00:20:47.790 --> 00:20:50.640
Now, why do I make mention of those paths?

426
00:20:50.640 --> 00:20:55.490
Well, Microsoft loves text based answers
that have those paths in them, so

427
00:20:55.490 --> 00:21:00.450
you can prove to them or on the exam,
that your way around the operating system.

428
00:21:00.450 --> 00:21:03.950
So let me just say really quick here,
with Control Panel,

429
00:21:03.950 --> 00:21:05.270
I wanna show you this one more time.

430
00:21:05.270 --> 00:21:07.050
I'll open up a separate Control Panel.

431
00:21:07.050 --> 00:21:08.720
Notice we have System and Security.

432
00:21:08.720 --> 00:21:10.280
That didn't change.

433
00:21:10.280 --> 00:21:15.880
But what does change is it no longer says
the Action Center like it has in the past,

434
00:21:15.880 --> 00:21:17.850
going up to Windows 8.1.

435
00:21:17.850 --> 00:21:22.850
Now, the Action Center is
what we see right here.

436
00:21:22.850 --> 00:21:25.620
So it's no longer called
the Action Center.

437
00:21:25.620 --> 00:21:27.390
It's called Security and Maintenance.

438
00:21:27.390 --> 00:21:30.130
So please remember that on the exam.

439
00:21:30.130 --> 00:21:33.340
It's just a little tidbit
that I want you to know so

440
00:21:33.340 --> 00:21:36.720
that they don't try to slip
that in on you and confuse you.

441
00:21:36.720 --> 00:21:38.760
So back to the Reliability Monitor.

442
00:21:38.760 --> 00:21:42.250
We've got quite a few different
things that we could look at, right?

443
00:21:42.250 --> 00:21:44.960
If we look over here
on the right-hand side

444
00:21:44.960 --> 00:21:47.810
we've got things like
Application Failures, right?

445
00:21:47.810 --> 00:21:48.870
And I've got this information,

446
00:21:48.870 --> 00:21:51.290
we'll talk about this information
coming up here in a second.

447
00:21:51.290 --> 00:21:53.890
By the way, you can also see this
information inside of Event Viewer, but

448
00:21:53.890 --> 00:21:57.230
this gives you a really
good quick way to look at

449
00:21:57.230 --> 00:22:02.170
a specific amount of time
the reliability of your machine.

450
00:22:02.170 --> 00:22:06.450
We've got Windows failures, Miscellaneous
failures, Warning, and Information.

451
00:22:06.450 --> 00:22:11.040
Now, notice that down here
this is a context pane, right?

452
00:22:11.040 --> 00:22:13.920
It isn't populated yet
cuz I haven't selected anything.

453
00:22:13.920 --> 00:22:15.120
We will do that in just a second,

454
00:22:15.120 --> 00:22:19.242
the other thing I want you to see is
when this graph, this is a bar graph,

455
00:22:19.242 --> 00:22:24.710
all right I'm sorry, a line graph [LAUGH]
and what it does is shows the reliability.

456
00:22:24.710 --> 00:22:29.540
The longer you go on with just these
information level events going.

457
00:22:29.540 --> 00:22:31.560
That graph will stay all
the way up to the top.

458
00:22:31.560 --> 00:22:35.350
The moment you have errors, warning,
critical events it starts to lower.

459
00:22:35.350 --> 00:22:36.900
Right?
It's called a stability index and

460
00:22:36.900 --> 00:22:42.745
it lowers the stability index, any time
you have some kind of instability, right?

461
00:22:42.745 --> 00:22:46.225
Now pay attention to the context pane
when I select one of these issues.

462
00:22:46.225 --> 00:22:52.950
Notice that the moment I select it,
I now have information down here, right?

463
00:22:52.950 --> 00:22:54.300
I have critical events.

464
00:22:54.300 --> 00:22:55.980
I have information events.

465
00:22:55.980 --> 00:22:59.910
I can see that this was Microsoft Edge
that stopped responding and was closed.

466
00:22:59.910 --> 00:23:02.630
And this also gives me the ability

467
00:23:02.630 --> 00:23:07.580
This is called the Problem Reports and
Solution Center that when I click that,

00:23:07.580 --> 00:23:09.820
it'll send the information
out to Microsoft and

469
00:23:09.820 --> 00:23:11.740
see if they've come across this issue.

470
00:23:11.740 --> 00:23:13.130
And if they resolved it.

471
00:23:13.130 --> 00:23:15.520
Now I can tell you,
a lot of times when I send it it says, no.

472
00:23:15.520 --> 00:23:18.910
There's not a resolution yet,
you need to try it again later.

473
00:23:18.910 --> 00:23:20.560
All right?
Well, how do we try it again later?

474
00:23:20.560 --> 00:23:23.460
Well, down here at the bottom,
you have a few options here.

475
00:23:23.460 --> 00:23:27.770
Save reliability history,
view all problem reports, and check for

476
00:23:27.770 --> 00:23:28.990
solutions to all problems.

477
00:23:28.990 --> 00:23:30.400
So I can view,

478
00:23:30.400 --> 00:23:35.450
if I want to get out of the Reliability
Monitor, we'll just view all problems.

479
00:23:35.450 --> 00:23:38.720
Now it drops me down, and it tells me,
have these things been reported?

480
00:23:39.840 --> 00:23:43.270
And has there been a solution to them?

481
00:23:43.270 --> 00:23:46.400
Notice [LAUGH] they all say report sent,
but

482
00:23:46.400 --> 00:23:48.110
I certainly don't see
a solution to any of these.

483
00:23:48.110 --> 00:23:52.128
So we could that again and you can see,
it's the Problem Reports up there.

484
00:23:52.128 --> 00:23:54.035
All right.

485
00:23:54.035 --> 00:23:58.540
Now, tell you what Dan, I don't see
anything in Windows failures, right?

486
00:23:58.540 --> 00:24:00.600
Notice that the Windows failure is blank.

487
00:24:00.600 --> 00:24:02.680
Let's see here on screen.

488
00:24:02.680 --> 00:24:04.890
We're gonna create a blue screen.

489
00:24:04.890 --> 00:24:05.777
Let's go ahead and do that.

490
00:24:05.777 --> 00:24:08.446
We're gonna use a little cis internals and
let's go ahead and

491
00:24:08.446 --> 00:24:09.841
see if we can crash the machine.

492
00:24:09.841 --> 00:24:10.849
We'll give it a second.

493
00:24:10.849 --> 00:24:12.699
We'll let it run its memory dump and

00:24:12.699 --> 00:24:15.114
hopefully it's not doing
a full memory dump.

495
00:24:15.114 --> 00:24:17.320
That's going to take a little bit.

496
00:24:17.320 --> 00:24:20.760
We might end up having to use
the magic of TV time out.

497
00:24:20.760 --> 00:24:23.360
Right?
So we've created a blue screen and

498
00:24:23.360 --> 00:24:28.050
hopefully what we'll see is when we

00:24:28.050 --> 00:24:31.940
we now have another critical event, and it
should be right there in Windows failures,

500
00:24:31.940 --> 00:24:33.310
at least that's what we're hoping.

501
00:24:33.310 --> 00:24:35.790
It might log in application failure,

502
00:24:35.790 --> 00:24:37.790
cuz it was technically
an application that caused it.

503
00:24:37.790 --> 00:24:40.460
But we'll see if we can
find one here in real time.

504
00:24:40.460 --> 00:24:44.110
So let me go ahead and get logged back
in with our super secret password here.

505
00:24:47.370 --> 00:24:48.670
And when we get to log back in,

506
00:24:48.670 --> 00:24:51.850
again remember we're going to
basically right-click the Start icon.

507
00:24:51.850 --> 00:24:55.350
We're gonna go to Control Panel,
then from System and Security, System and

508
00:24:55.350 --> 00:24:58.750
Maintenance, and then we're
gonna expand out Maintenance and

509
00:24:58.750 --> 00:25:02.100
click that View Reliability link.

510
00:25:02.100 --> 00:25:07.450
There we go, Control Panel,
System and Security, Security and

511
00:25:07.450 --> 00:25:12.880
Maintenance, and as we wait for
it to think about it.

512
00:25:12.880 --> 00:25:16.100
We'll expand that out and
go back to the review reliability history.

513
00:25:16.100 --> 00:25:16.810
There we go.

514
00:25:16.810 --> 00:25:18.800
Actually we've got a couple of failures.

515
00:25:18.800 --> 00:25:20.490
Sometimes it's hard to get that,

516
00:25:20.490 --> 00:25:24.740
I almost said millennial,
miscellaneous failure to happen.

517
00:25:24.740 --> 00:25:29.120
Well I've scored today I can break
Windows with the best of them apparently.

518
00:25:29.120 --> 00:25:32.220
So notice here that we've
got a Windows failure and

519
00:25:32.220 --> 00:25:34.200
we've got a miscellaneous failure

520
00:25:34.200 --> 00:25:36.890
Well that's what I was

00:25:36.890 --> 00:25:42.340
if I look, I can see technical details.

00:25:42.340 --> 00:25:43.050
Right?
It says

00:25:43.050 --> 00:25:44.920
Windows was not shut down properly.

00:25:44.920 --> 00:25:49.470
I would almost venture to say that

00:25:49.470 --> 00:25:53.340
kernel power failure,
regardless of what the error is.

526
00:25:53.340 --> 00:25:54.129
Let's go ahead and see.

527
00:25:55.310 --> 00:25:56.710
Shut down, yep.

528
00:25:56.710 --> 00:25:59.140
Wasn't properly shut down and

00:25:59.140 --> 00:26:02.240
So it's a critical kernel power failure.

530
00:26:02.240 --> 00:26:05.520
All right, now the other one here,
we've got Windows stopped working.

531
00:26:05.520 --> 00:26:07.830
There we go, rebooted from a bug check.

00:26:07.830 --> 00:26:09.380
That's what I wanted to see.

533
00:26:09.380 --> 00:26:13.060
And we can look and we can see

00:26:13.060 --> 00:26:16.120
Now what's interesting is this is the

00:26:16.120 --> 00:26:19.370
screen that I'm sure you had

00:26:19.370 --> 00:26:23.760
With all these zeros in here,
as well as the memory dump right?

537
00:26:23.760 --> 00:26:25.850
And we can see where
the memory dump was saved.

538
00:26:25.850 --> 00:26:28.820
And if we got something like

00:26:28.820 --> 00:26:31.060
we can throw that in

540
00:26:31.060 --> 00:26:32.470
And kinda find out what the problem is.

541
00:26:32.470 --> 00:26:36.230
Know what the problem is, it's
an application called, it's not my fault.

542
00:26:36.230 --> 00:26:39.730
So, Dan, when it comes down to it
that's pretty much what we have.

543
00:26:39.730 --> 00:26:41.590
We've looked at the indexing options.

544
00:26:41.590 --> 00:26:45.530
We've looked at the managing your clients
security through Windows Defender and

545
00:26:45.530 --> 00:26:48.620
we also took a second to look

546
00:26:48.620 --> 00:26:51.510
Remember these on the exam

547
00:26:51.510 --> 00:26:52.470
>> Pretty cool stuff, though Wes.

548
00:26:52.470 --> 00:26:55.330
They've got a lot of nice new features
in our Windows operating systems.

549
00:26:55.330 --> 00:26:59.420
And they continually refine them to

550
00:26:59.420 --> 00:27:04.050
Making it more useful for us as
workstation support, desktop support,

551
00:27:04.050 --> 00:27:04.860
whatever the case may be.

552
00:27:04.860 --> 00:27:07.910
Whatever you get into as

553
00:27:07.910 --> 00:27:11.320
Wes, that being said, it looks like
we've come to yet another great episode.

554
00:27:11.320 --> 00:27:12.160
The end is here.

555
00:27:12.160 --> 00:27:14.050
I hope you guys enjoyed it.

556
00:27:14.050 --> 00:27:15.310
Wes, thank you for stopping by.

557
00:27:15.310 --> 00:27:18.960
But signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

558
00:27:18.960 --> 00:27:19.600
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

559
00:27:19.600 --> 00:27:20.310
>> And we'll see you next time.

560
00:27:20.310 --> 00:27:29.780

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes demonstrate using some of the advanced management tools available in Windows 10. They begin by showing you how to manage system services using the GUI as well as the Command Prompt and/or Powershell.
episodes.title: Advanced Management Tools
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.472 --> 00:00:16.690
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:17.850
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4

And in today's episode, I hope you're
ready for it, cuz it's more Windows 10.

5
00:00:21.470 --> 00:00:25.680
Joining us back in the studio again today,
our good friend Mr. Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:25.680 --> 00:00:26.530
Wes, welcome back, sir.

7
00:00:26.530 --> 00:00:27.255
So glad to have you.

8

9

10
00:00:29.360 --> 00:00:31.020
It's great to be here, as always.

11

That's right, we're gonna get into

By the exam objectives,

And you're gonna know a little bit more

00:00:42.490 --> 00:00:44.995

One of the first things that we're gonna
be looking at is something known as

00:00:49.546 --> 00:00:53.875
Now, I'm gonna go ahead for a second here,

00:00:53.875 --> 00:00:58.426
launch the graphical user interface, cuz

00:00:58.426 --> 00:01:01.676
But as we know, or maybe you don't,

a lot of times they don't ask you all the

they do ask you about the command line.

00:01:08.375 --> 00:01:10.224
So we're gonna get into those as well.

24
00:01:10.224 --> 00:01:13.314
So services, services.msc.

25
00:01:13.314 --> 00:01:15.075
It's also in Computer Management,
by the way.

26
00:01:15.075 --> 00:01:17.679
And again, just kind of throwing these
out there just in case they say, okay,

27
00:01:17.679 --> 00:01:19.350
which of these allows you
to configure services?

28
00:01:19.350 --> 00:01:21.763
Choose three.

They like to do stuff like that.

00:01:23.045 --> 00:01:26.575
Maybe they say choose four, and

Services console, and Computer Management.

32
00:01:29.250 --> 00:01:31.431
Well, we want you to be able
to be ready for the exam.

33
00:01:31.431 --> 00:01:34.401
However I will tell you that if
I was in Computer Management,

notice that they're identical.
