00:01:36.098 --> 00:01:37.990
So we're not gonna spend
too much time there.

36
00:01:37.990 --> 00:01:39.760
No real need to.

37
00:01:39.760 --> 00:01:41.590
Now, what can I do with these services?

38
00:01:41.590 --> 00:01:44.470
Well, services, let's define
what a service is first, right.

39
00:01:44.470 --> 00:01:48.940
Services are typically background
processes that happen, and

40
00:01:48.940 --> 00:01:51.000
a lot of times we don't
interact with them.

41
00:01:51.000 --> 00:01:54.510
Like a lot of these services here,
you can see, their status is Running.

42
00:01:54.510 --> 00:01:57.700
Now, I didn't turn any of
these services on, right?

43
00:01:57.700 --> 00:01:59.190
I started the computer up, and

44
00:01:59.190 --> 00:02:01.110
when I start the computer up,
they're running in the background.

45
00:02:01.110 --> 00:02:03.630
In other systems, you'll see,
they're called by different things.

46
00:02:03.630 --> 00:02:07.600
Like in Novell, I think they called
them NLMs, Novell Loadable Modules.

47
00:02:07.600 --> 00:02:10.100
In the *nix based systems,
I believe they call them daemons, right?

48
00:02:10.100 --> 00:02:13.050
They're just the processes that
typically run in the background and

49
00:02:13.050 --> 00:02:14.830
we don't have any interaction with them.

50
00:02:14.830 --> 00:02:17.460
Except sometimes you do
have to configure them.

51
00:02:17.460 --> 00:02:20.600
Sometimes you have services
that are supposed to run, but

52
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:21.940
by default they are disabled.

53
00:02:21.940 --> 00:02:23.960
I'll give you the classic example of one.

54
00:02:23.960 --> 00:02:27.960
Up here at the top, there is
an Application Identity Service, right?

55
00:02:27.960 --> 00:02:31.690
I love to use this one, because if
you're ever configuring AppLocker, this

56
00:02:31.690 --> 00:02:35.510
is one of the services that you need to
turn on in order to make AppLocker work.

57
00:02:35.510 --> 00:02:38.720
You can configure all of your AppLocker
rules, do everything that you need to do,

58
00:02:38.720 --> 00:02:42.860
and if you don't turn this service on,
AppLocker does absolutely nothing for you.

59
00:02:42.860 --> 00:02:48.230
So it is good to know a little bit about
the graphical user interface here.

60
00:02:48.230 --> 00:02:48.969
All right, so what do we have?

61
00:02:48.969 --> 00:02:52.770
When we talk about services, these
processes have different startup types.

62
00:02:52.770 --> 00:02:57.590
They have three that have been around
Windows for a long time, right?

63
00:02:57.590 --> 00:02:59.538
This is the Automatic,
Manual, and Disabled.

64
00:02:59.538 --> 00:03:01.434
Automatic (Delayed Start),

65
00:03:01.434 --> 00:03:06.217
I believe this started [LAUGH] a little
redundancy there, started in Windows 7.

66
00:03:06.217 --> 00:03:10.716
Some of you guys might remember how much
of a resource hog Windows Vista was, so

67
00:03:10.716 --> 00:03:14.124
in Windows 7, they tried to
optimize it a little bit more,

68
00:03:14.124 --> 00:03:16.460
make it a little easier on your machine.

69
00:03:16.460 --> 00:03:18.890
So let's talk about the three oldies but
goodies.

70
00:03:18.890 --> 00:03:21.080
Automatic, automatic means
exactly what it says.

71
00:03:21.080 --> 00:03:24.490
The moment I push the start button or
power button, I should say,

72
00:03:24.490 --> 00:03:27.540
on the computer,
it's going to start this service.

73
00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:31.050
And that's where we get this,
if you can see in the background here,

74
00:03:31.050 --> 00:03:33.850
where the status is running, right?

75
00:03:33.850 --> 00:03:37.970
Now, the other one that we have here is,

76
00:03:37.970 --> 00:03:40.150
let me get back to it,
is Manual, all right?

77
00:03:40.150 --> 00:03:41.580
Well, what does Manual process mean?

78
00:03:41.580 --> 00:03:42.930
Does that mean it isn't gonna start?

79
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:44.000
No, that's not what it means.

80
00:03:44.000 --> 00:03:47.390
It means this service stays shut
down until an application or

81
00:03:47.390 --> 00:03:51.444
another dependency, which we'll look
at in a second, calls on it, and

82
00:03:51.444 --> 00:03:54.717
says, okay, let's go ahead and
start the service then.

83
00:03:54.717 --> 00:03:58.373
That's why you can see, and let me go
ahead and close this down one more time,

84
00:03:58.373 --> 00:04:01.185
in the background, this one,
if I expand this column out,

85
00:04:01.185 --> 00:04:03.290
says Manual (Triggered Start), right?

86
00:04:03.290 --> 00:04:06.280
Now, the last one that we have,
if you can see,

87
00:04:06.280 --> 00:04:08.490
is probably pretty obvious on this one.

88
00:04:08.490 --> 00:04:10.840
And this is where you might need
to configure these services.

89
00:04:10.840 --> 00:04:11.939
Notice it says Disabled.

90
00:04:11.939 --> 00:04:14.566
All right, Disabled means I
don't care if an application or

91
00:04:14.566 --> 00:04:16.017
a component in Windows needs it.

92
00:04:16.017 --> 00:04:20.448
Let's say AppLocker, in that case, it uses
the Application Identity Service here to

93
00:04:20.448 --> 00:04:24.029
look at the application, compare it
back to the AppLocker rules, and

94
00:04:24.029 --> 00:04:28.300
either restrict it or allow it to run,
based on what rules you've got configured.

95
00:04:28.300 --> 00:04:31.320
However, if I have it disabled,
it doesn't matter that AppLocker needs it.

96
00:04:31.320 --> 00:04:33.989
It says, well, you told me it's disabled,

97
00:04:33.989 --> 00:04:38.350
I'm not gonna run regardless of what
component in the operating system or

98
00:04:38.350 --> 00:04:42.090
maybe whatever other service
might need this, right?

99
00:04:42.090 --> 00:04:47.102
Now, I can also, the other important tab
I wanna show you is the Dependencies tab.

100
00:04:47.102 --> 00:04:50.390
All right, you can see, at the first one,
the first dialog box here,

101
00:04:50.390 --> 00:04:55.690
is the dependencies that
this service needs, right.

102
00:04:55.690 --> 00:05:00.386
So this service will require these
other services to be running.

103
00:05:00.386 --> 00:05:02.840
And you can see sometimes
when you expand these out,

104
00:05:02.840 --> 00:05:07.340
there are a lot of additional services
that need to be available and running for

105
00:05:07.340 --> 00:05:09.460
the Application Identity Service
to be running.

106
00:05:09.460 --> 00:05:11.360
For instance, Remote Procedure Call.

107
00:05:11.360 --> 00:05:13.100
When you look at Remote Procedure Call,

108
00:05:13.100 --> 00:05:16.840
just about everything in your Windows
operating system relies on that.

109
00:05:16.840 --> 00:05:19.471
So you can't disable it.

110
00:05:19.471 --> 00:05:22.718
If you could disable it,
it'd end up being a bad day at the office.

111
00:05:22.718 --> 00:05:26.370
It'd pretty much crash your
entire computer, all right.

112
00:05:26.370 --> 00:05:29.050
Now, the other thing that we can do is,
we can start, and I'll go ahead and

113
00:05:29.050 --> 00:05:29.620
start this.

114
00:05:29.620 --> 00:05:33.570
And as it starts up,
you can see that it says Start, right.

115
00:05:33.570 --> 00:05:35.090
Now it say that it's running.

116
00:05:35.090 --> 00:05:40.710
And if I come back here to
the Services console, right, I can see

117
00:05:40.710 --> 00:05:45.770
now that it says it's a running process or
a running background service, if you will.

118
00:05:45.770 --> 00:05:47.920
Now, I'm gonna go ahead and
I'm gonna stop this one.

119
00:05:49.130 --> 00:05:51.630
And again,
I want you to know that for the exam.

120
00:05:51.630 --> 00:05:53.420
Services console, Computer Management.

121
00:05:53.420 --> 00:05:57.650
But we also wanna focus a little bit
on Command Prompt or PowerShell.

122
00:05:57.650 --> 00:05:59.560
Now, the next options
that we're gonna run,

123
00:05:59.560 --> 00:06:02.220
let me go ahead and clear the screen here.

124
00:06:02.220 --> 00:06:05.270
We're gonna run another oldie
that's been around for a bit.

125
00:06:05.270 --> 00:06:06.550
And you know what, let me go ahead.

126
00:06:06.550 --> 00:06:09.150
I kind of forgot something here,
and I don't want to do that.

127
00:06:09.150 --> 00:06:13.160
Cuz I didn't explain the other
option that we have, and

128
00:06:13.160 --> 00:06:14.980
that was the automatic delayed start.

129
00:06:14.980 --> 00:06:16.901
I kind of skipped over that one.

130
00:06:16.901 --> 00:06:20.173
The automatic delayed start,
this is kind of optimized,

131
00:06:20.173 --> 00:06:24.970
an optimized start-up type that says,
keep it out of my boot process.

132
00:06:24.970 --> 00:06:26.110
You need the service, that's fine.

133
00:06:26.110 --> 00:06:29.540
But it's not a critical
boot start service.

134
00:06:29.540 --> 00:06:30.550
I don't need it.

135
00:06:30.550 --> 00:06:33.890
So wait till that's done,
and then start the service.

136
00:06:33.890 --> 00:06:35.340
Now that we've looked at that,
let's go ahead and

137
00:06:35.340 --> 00:06:37.960
we're gonna drop down to
our command-line interface.

138
00:06:37.960 --> 00:06:42.870
And what we're gonna do here is,
let me get in to my PowerShell here,

139
00:06:42.870 --> 00:06:45.260
and I'll clear the screen up here for you.

140
00:06:45.260 --> 00:06:49.610
Now, there are times when you need
to configure your services, right?

141
00:06:49.610 --> 00:06:50.710
We've got a couple of options.

142
00:06:50.710 --> 00:06:53.397
So we've got some that have been
traditionally in the Command Prompt.

143
00:06:53.397 --> 00:06:55.429
We've got some that
will run in PowerShell,

144
00:06:55.429 --> 00:06:58.380
even though they've traditionally
been in the Command Prompt.

145
00:06:58.380 --> 00:07:00.030
Let's talk about that first one here.

146
00:07:00.030 --> 00:07:01.630
And that's the net option.

147
00:07:01.630 --> 00:07:06.650
Now, net is a program you can
use if you want to start,

148
00:07:06.650 --> 00:07:09.690
stop, pause, and resume your services.

149
00:07:09.690 --> 00:07:12.612
For instance, we have the print spooler
that runs within Windows, right,

150
00:07:12.612 --> 00:07:16.260
it's the service that controls the print
process from the moment that use you use

151
00:07:16.260 --> 00:07:19.370
your little Ctrl+P shortcut
to bring up the print screen,

152
00:07:19.370 --> 00:07:23.190
to the moment you see the printed
output on the print device itself.

153
00:07:23.190 --> 00:07:25.870
If I want, I can do a net, and

154
00:07:25.870 --> 00:07:31.100
I can do stop, and
then I can name the service.

155
00:07:31.100 --> 00:07:33.330
So in this case,
we'll do a net stop spooler.

156
00:07:33.330 --> 00:07:37.010
Notice that it tells me the principle or
service is stopping.

157
00:07:37.010 --> 00:07:40.740
All right, and if I want to,
I can start it up again.

158
00:07:40.740 --> 00:07:45.230
Just replace stop with start,
net start, space, spooler.

159
00:07:47.490 --> 00:07:50.170
All you gotta do is be able to spell,
and we'll choose start.

160
00:07:50.170 --> 00:07:52.160
And notice that the service is starting.

161
00:07:52.160 --> 00:07:54.310
Now, notice that I'm in PowerShell.

162
00:07:54.310 --> 00:08:00.510
If I was in Command Prompt,
I could do the same thing, all right,

163
00:08:00.510 --> 00:08:06.520
and I could do a net stop spooler.

164
00:08:06.520 --> 00:08:09.080
Notice how it's stopping
here in Command Prompt.

165
00:08:09.080 --> 00:08:13.510
And then if I decide to, I could always
change this around a little bit, and

166
00:08:13.510 --> 00:08:15.210
I could do net start.

167
00:08:15.210 --> 00:08:16.540
All right, so what do we do?

168
00:08:16.540 --> 00:08:19.220
We just basically stopped and
restarted a service.

169
00:08:19.220 --> 00:08:21.660
In this case,
there's times when people say, you know,

170
00:08:21.660 --> 00:08:25.190
I've been trying to print and
print's not happening.

171
00:08:25.190 --> 00:08:27.140
Right?
Well, you can connect to their computer,

172
00:08:27.140 --> 00:08:31.190
you can fire up a Command Prompt, and
you can end up running the net option.

173
00:08:31.190 --> 00:08:33.330
Remember, net start, net stop.

174
00:08:33.330 --> 00:08:36.660
Now, there are other options that
are available with net stop or

175
00:08:36.660 --> 00:08:39.420
net in general if you will,
and that's pause.

176
00:08:39.420 --> 00:08:44.030
Now, not every service is gonna
allow the pause functionality, and

177
00:08:44.030 --> 00:08:45.190
let me show you that.

178
00:08:45.190 --> 00:08:46.378
Spooler is one that doesn't.

179
00:08:46.378 --> 00:08:47.769
So you have to do your research and

180
00:08:47.769 --> 00:08:51.010
figure out if the service itself will
allow you to pause the service, right?

181
00:08:51.010 --> 00:08:54.129
So if I do a net pause and spooler,

182
00:08:56.440 --> 00:09:00.860
notice that it says, pause, continue,
or stop is not valid for this service.

183
00:09:00.860 --> 00:09:04.170
Now, technically,
stop is valid for this service.

184
00:09:04.170 --> 00:09:05.270
I've just shown you.

185
00:09:05.270 --> 00:09:08.665
All right, so this is a generic output.

186
00:09:08.665 --> 00:09:11.555
I make mention of that cuz you guys
just see, well, what did I do?

187
00:09:11.555 --> 00:09:13.435
I ran the net stop, and what did it do?

188
00:09:13.435 --> 00:09:16.975
It said the service is stopping, but down
here, it tells you, stop is not valid for

189
00:09:16.975 --> 00:09:17.995
the spooler service.

190
00:09:19.485 --> 00:09:20.060
What do you mean?

191
00:09:20.060 --> 00:09:21.610
Well, this is a generic warning,

192
00:09:21.610 --> 00:09:25.990
it goes out for all of the services
that don't support pause or continue.

193
00:09:25.990 --> 00:09:28.428
You also get the stop option
in there as well, but

194
00:09:28.428 --> 00:09:32.610
it technically isn't true in this case,
all right, so we can't pause a service.

195
00:09:32.610 --> 00:09:35.360
There might be a situation in
which you need to do that, and

196
00:09:35.360 --> 00:09:39.190
then you can turn around and
you would run net resume.

197
00:09:39.190 --> 00:09:40.540
Well, of course not.

198
00:09:40.540 --> 00:09:42.460
You actually run continue, all right.

199
00:09:42.460 --> 00:09:45.670
So net pause and
then the service name pauses the service,

200
00:09:45.670 --> 00:09:46.770
just kind of freezes it.

201
00:09:46.770 --> 00:09:51.245
And net continue and
the service name will basically resume it.

202
00:09:51.245 --> 00:09:53.783
The next command that we're gonna look
at is the Service Control Manager.

203
00:09:53.783 --> 00:09:58.235
And for the most part, I haven't really
had too many problems running traditional

204
00:09:58.235 --> 00:10:01.225
Command Prompt commands
inside of PowerShell.

205
00:10:01.225 --> 00:10:04.198
There was one time,
netsh with a certificate thumbprint,

00:10:04.198 --> 00:10:07.780
it didn't like PowerShell and
I had to drop down to the Command Prompt.

00:10:07.780 --> 00:10:11.965
Let me show you that this is one that it
doesn't really work too well inside of

208
00:10:11.965 --> 00:10:12.730
PowerShell.

209
00:10:12.730 --> 00:10:17.180
So if I do an sc and
I do a query, it looks and

210
00:10:17.180 --> 00:10:21.410
it says, well, wait a second, I'm

00:10:21.410 --> 00:10:23.930
So let me go ahead and I'll Ctrl+C that.

00:10:23.930 --> 00:10:26.770
So, we'll get out of that there and

00:10:26.770 --> 00:10:29.025
And what I'm gonna do is drop

00:10:29.025 --> 00:10:33.927
And if I run the same exact command and I
do sc for the service control manager and

00:10:33.927 --> 00:10:35.570
I do query.

00:10:35.570 --> 00:10:37.830
I run that, and then what do we see here?

217
00:10:37.830 --> 00:10:41.790
Well, you see all of
the services that are running.

218
00:10:41.790 --> 00:10:44.640
Now, that doesn't stop me right there.

219
00:10:44.640 --> 00:10:46.630
I can look at more information if I want.

220
00:10:46.630 --> 00:10:52.030
For instance, if I wanted to see maybe all
the drivers that are currently being used,

221
00:10:52.030 --> 00:10:54.490
that are running, well,
we could do something like this.

222
00:10:54.490 --> 00:10:59.720
We can do an sc,
we can do a space and a query.

223
00:10:59.720 --> 00:11:02.790
And what I can do is state equals.

224
00:11:02.790 --> 00:11:04.730
Now, let me show you an error here.

225
00:11:04.730 --> 00:11:09.230
A lot of times, when you do like
an equals, you'll have where the, whatever

226
00:11:09.230 --> 00:11:14.360
the variable is after that, or the option
will be butted up next to the equal sign.

227
00:11:14.360 --> 00:11:19.690
If I did that right here and I ran it,

00:11:19.690 --> 00:11:22.980
So what it's actually looking for

229
00:11:22.980 --> 00:11:24.780
And I said start.

230
00:11:24.780 --> 00:11:25.974
I'm gonna type that right there.

231
00:11:25.974 --> 00:11:28.676
And we're gonna do state= all.

00:11:28.676 --> 00:11:31.210
And when I run this,
you'll notice that the information,

00:11:31.210 --> 00:11:32.689
there was a lot more information.

00:11:32.689 --> 00:11:35.187
Now, I know it scrolled by really,

00:11:35.187 --> 00:11:38.457
but what's happening now is it's

00:11:38.457 --> 00:11:42.660

00:11:42.660 --> 00:11:44.040
Well, maybe that's not what you want.

Maybe you wanna just stay

00:11:46.970 --> 00:11:50.301
Let me clear our screen out

00:11:50.301 --> 00:11:51.985
And we'll go ahead and

00:11:51.985 --> 00:11:57.161
We'll do an sc, again, Service Control

00:11:57.161 --> 00:12:01.256
And the next thing we'll do is type

00:12:01.256 --> 00:12:04.051

00:12:04.051 --> 00:12:07.274
Now, when we run this, again,

00:12:07.274 --> 00:12:08.790

00:12:08.790 --> 00:12:12.510
So remember the sc command, again,

00:12:12.510 --> 00:12:15.678
on the exam as a way to be

00:12:15.678 --> 00:12:18.449
Again, we're not worried too

00:12:18.449 --> 00:12:21.453
cuz we're really talking about

00:12:21.453 --> 00:12:22.920
And we've seen it in Command Prompt.

251
00:12:22.920 --> 00:12:26.910
Let's go ahead and see if we can do

252
00:12:26.910 --> 00:12:28.830
Now, we've got the PowerShell going here.

253
00:12:28.830 --> 00:12:32.590
And if you wanna find out what

00:12:32.590 --> 00:12:36.710
including what their current state is,

255
00:12:36.710 --> 00:12:41.510
And if I do a Get-Service here,

Now, this is important,

And you have a display name, which you

00:12:54.170 --> 00:12:58.467
We're gonna go ahead and, I'll tell you
what, we'll start and stop a service.

00:12:58.467 --> 00:13:03.930
One that I know is typically

We'll do a Start-Service.

262
00:13:06.568 --> 00:13:10.116
We're gonna do a name, all right,
and I'll tell you what,

263
00:13:10.116 --> 00:13:12.700
let me just kind of
format that a little bit.

264
00:13:12.700 --> 00:13:14.054
There you go,
now you can see it a little bit better.

265
00:13:14.054 --> 00:13:16.438
Let's go ahead and do Start-Service.

266
00:13:16.438 --> 00:13:21.279
We'll do name, and then for
m, e it's gonna be WinRM.

267
00:13:21.279 --> 00:13:25.010
And, well, what did that really do?

268
00:13:25.010 --> 00:13:27.330
That really didn't do much,
so now what do I have to do?

269
00:13:27.330 --> 00:13:30.574
Do I have to do a Get-Service and
scroll through that entire list?

270
00:13:30.574 --> 00:13:31.320
Well, no.

271
00:13:31.320 --> 00:13:33.014
I can do a Get-Service and

272
00:13:33.014 --> 00:13:37.946
I can actually filter it as long as I
know a little bit about its name, right.

273
00:13:37.946 --> 00:13:41.750
So I can do, for instance,
I can do a Get-Service.

274
00:13:41.750 --> 00:13:43.958
>> Yeah, Wes,
the good thing about PowerShell, though,

275
00:13:43.958 --> 00:13:46.994
is that as long as you don't have a bunch
of red text on the screen, typically,

276
00:13:46.994 --> 00:13:48.387
you're pretty safe at that point.

277
00:13:48.387 --> 00:13:50.540
But it never hurts to verify, right?

278
00:13:50.540 --> 00:13:52.220
>> That's exactly it, and
that's what we're gonna do.

279
00:13:52.220 --> 00:13:53.840
Because it really didn't show me anything.

280
00:13:53.840 --> 00:13:56.190
I know that I didn't get a red line here,
right?

281
00:13:56.190 --> 00:13:59.498
If I would have done something
where it came up like that, well,

282
00:13:59.498 --> 00:14:00.860
I know that's not right.

283
00:14:00.860 --> 00:14:02.390
So how do we do that, right?

284
00:14:02.390 --> 00:14:04.130
And also, let's go a little bit farther,

285
00:14:04.130 --> 00:14:10.440
how do we find the service without
scrolling through everything in the list?

286
00:14:10.440 --> 00:14:12.900
Well, I can go ahead and
I can do a wildcard here.

287
00:14:12.900 --> 00:14:16.150
I could say name, and
in this case, I can do a win for

288
00:14:16.150 --> 00:14:19.850
the first three letters, then an asterisk
symbol, right, for a wildcard.

289
00:14:19.850 --> 00:14:24.830
And it tells me now
the Windows Remote Management has started.

290
00:14:24.830 --> 00:14:25.590
All right.

291
00:14:25.590 --> 00:14:29.090
Now, there's some other things
that we can do as well.

292
00:14:29.090 --> 00:14:32.070
Notice that it outputted
all of the services.

293
00:14:32.070 --> 00:14:34.770
Well, maybe I just wanna find out
what services are running currently.

294
00:14:34.770 --> 00:14:35.850
Well, you can do that too.

295
00:14:35.850 --> 00:14:39.180
So we'll go ahead and
we'll clear our screen here.

296
00:14:39.180 --> 00:14:42.680
And we're gonna run a Get-Service.

297
00:14:42.680 --> 00:14:48.960
And then what we're gonna do is we're
gonna pipe this out to Where-Object.

298
00:14:48.960 --> 00:14:50.500
And we'll put a variable in there.

299
00:14:52.160 --> 00:14:56.618
All right, we'll do our underscore,
our dot, we'll do status.

300
00:14:56.618 --> 00:15:01.123
And then eq, that's equals,

301
00:15:01.123 --> 00:15:05.975
and we'll put some quotes here,

302
00:15:05.975 --> 00:15:09.454
and we'll do running.

303
00:15:09.454 --> 00:15:13.450
We'll close that off with the quotes,
and then close everything off here.

304
00:15:14.650 --> 00:15:15.790
And we'll run this.

305
00:15:15.790 --> 00:15:21.510
Now, what this did is it didn't
show me every single service,

306
00:15:21.510 --> 00:15:23.360
only the services that
are currently running.

307
00:15:23.360 --> 00:15:26.870
So you do have a way that you can
filter through it if you need to.

308
00:15:26.870 --> 00:15:29.463
The other thing that we can do is
we can sort this a little bit too.

309
00:15:29.463 --> 00:15:34.140
So for instance,
if I do a Get-Service, all right, and

310
00:15:34.140 --> 00:15:39.219
then I pipe this out to a Sort-Object,
and then I say status.

311
00:15:40.590 --> 00:15:44.540
Now the output is gonna make them
a little bit easier to find, right.

312
00:15:44.540 --> 00:15:48.260
I can see that nice, easy dividing line
between what's stopped and started.

313
00:15:48.260 --> 00:15:52.790
So you also have that
ability to do that as well.

314
00:15:52.790 --> 00:15:57.758
So, when we look at this, Dan, we can
control all aspects of the services.

315
00:15:57.758 --> 00:16:01.446
We've shown you, in this episode so far,
we've shown you how to do this through

316
00:16:01.446 --> 00:16:04.919
the graphical user interface as well
as defining some of the startup types,

317
00:16:04.919 --> 00:16:06.980
showing you start and stopping it.

318
00:16:06.980 --> 00:16:10.610
But also showing you that net option
inside of the traditional Command Prompt.

319
00:16:10.610 --> 00:16:12.503
You can also run it inside of PowerShell.

320
00:16:12.503 --> 00:16:17.095
Remember that the sc command that we ran,
the Service Control Manager, that command

321
00:16:17.095 --> 00:16:21.451
likes to run inside of Command Prompt,
it doesn't do too well with PowerShell.

322
00:16:21.451 --> 00:16:26.080
And then the last one, we showed you some
of the ways that PowerShell has native

323
00:16:26.080 --> 00:16:29.602
cmdlets in them that you can
use to start and stop services.

324
00:16:29.602 --> 00:16:32.796
Again, know some of those cmdlets,
be aware of them, and be

325
00:16:32.796 --> 00:16:36.945
aware of some of the things that you can
do as far as configuring your services.

326
00:16:36.945 --> 00:16:40.670
Now, Dan, I got a lot more to go, but
I can see Dan over here is telling me we

327
00:16:40.670 --> 00:16:44.543
might have to go into a part two on this
one, because you let me talk too much.

328
00:16:44.543 --> 00:16:45.271
>> That's right.

329
00:16:45.271 --> 00:16:47.645
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just, enough, already, all right?

330
00:16:47.645 --> 00:16:48.855
The man loves to run his yammer.

331
00:16:48.855 --> 00:16:50.255
But it's for a good reason, right?

332
00:16:50.255 --> 00:16:51.445
We have to learn these things so

333
00:16:51.445 --> 00:16:56.180
that we can effectively administrate our
Windows environments and pass an exam so

334
00:16:56.180 --> 00:16:59.420
that we can become administrators
of Windows environments.

335
00:16:59.420 --> 00:17:01.700
That being said, Wes,
we look forward to seeing you in part two.

336
00:17:01.700 --> 00:17:03.320
We do thank you stopping by today.

337
00:17:03.320 --> 00:17:04.696
We thank you guys for
stopping by, as well.

338
00:17:04.696 --> 00:17:05.872
Hopefully, you've enjoyed this episode.

339
00:17:05.872 --> 00:17:09.975
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

340
00:17:09.975 --> 00:17:10.646
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

341
00:17:10.646 --> 00:17:11.443
>> And we'll see you next time.

342
00:17:11.443 --> 00:17:20.348
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes finish their exploration of some of the Advanced Management Tools in Windows 10. Here they demonstrate working with the Device Manager to upgrade or change a device driver. Then they show you how to create a custom Microsoft Management Console(MMC) and automate tasks with the Task Scheduler and Powershell.
episodes.title: Advanced Management Tools Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.937 --> 00:00:16.510
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another fantastic episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:16.510 --> 00:00:19.184
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

4
00:00:19.184 --> 00:00:21.160
we continue our Windows 10 series.

5
00:00:21.160 --> 00:00:23.150
Joining us back in
the studio today again for

6
00:00:23.150 --> 00:00:28.000
a part two on advance configuration
is our good friend Mr. West Bryan.

7
00:00:28.000 --> 00:00:30.100
West, welcome back, Sir,
so glad to have you.

8
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:33.220
>> Man, it's great to be here with
ITProTV staff, and you're right.

9
00:00:33.220 --> 00:00:34.560
I talk way too much of.

10
00:00:34.560 --> 00:00:37.570
We're coming back with a part
two in advance management tools.

11
00:00:37.570 --> 00:00:40.480
We did have a few other things that
we kind of wanted to wrap up, so

12
00:00:40.480 --> 00:00:42.200
that you'll be prepared for the exam.

13
00:00:42.200 --> 00:00:45.310
One of the things that we're
going to look at is an oldie, but

14
00:00:45.310 --> 00:00:46.850
goodie, it's been around for a while.

15
00:00:46.850 --> 00:00:49.360
And that is something
known as device manager.

16
00:00:49.360 --> 00:00:50.430
So, tell you what?

17
00:00:50.430 --> 00:00:54.070
But rather than get into a whole bunch
of lecture, let's dive right in.

18
00:00:54.070 --> 00:00:56.440
I'm going to log into my
Windows machine here.

19
00:00:56.440 --> 00:00:57.610
Now, device manager.

20
00:00:57.610 --> 00:00:59.927
I'm just going to go ahead and
right-click on our start icon,

21
00:00:59.927 --> 00:01:00.940
launch up device manager.

22
00:01:00.940 --> 00:01:03.455
So what is it that the device
manager does for us?

23
00:01:03.455 --> 00:01:07.145
Well, as you might know, and if not,
we'll go ahead and tell you,

24
00:01:07.145 --> 00:01:11.125
operating systems are typically written in
high level programming languages, right?

25
00:01:11.125 --> 00:01:15.015
Our hardware, it doesn't understand
that lingo if you will, right?

26
00:01:15.015 --> 00:01:20.980
It only understands the low-level
machine code, as far as interacting.

27
00:01:20.980 --> 00:01:25.350
So imagine that maybe I'm talking
to somebody that speaks Spanish.

28
00:01:25.350 --> 00:01:28.000
I would love to be able to
speak Spanish fluently.

29
00:01:28.000 --> 00:01:28.550
But I don't.

30
00:01:28.550 --> 00:01:31.050
So if we're going to have
a conversation between two people,

31
00:01:31.050 --> 00:01:33.280
myself speaking English, and
somebody speaking Spanish,

32
00:01:33.280 --> 00:01:34.980
I'm going to have to have
a translator in the middle.

33
00:01:34.980 --> 00:01:37.670
And then that allows us
to have a conversation.

34
00:01:37.670 --> 00:01:41.060
Well, that's much the way a driver
works inside of your operating system.

35
00:01:41.060 --> 00:01:44.430
The high level programming languages
that operating systems are written in,

36
00:01:44.430 --> 00:01:45.560
the driver sits in the middle, and

37
00:01:45.560 --> 00:01:49.390
it translates calls that come down
from it, basically from the user, and

38
00:01:49.390 --> 00:01:53.580
translates it into the machine lingo
that our hardware can react to.

39
00:01:53.580 --> 00:01:55.440
Well, that's what
Device Manager allows us to do.

40
00:01:55.440 --> 00:01:58.230
And the fact that it allows us to
view the state of our hardware and

41
00:01:58.230 --> 00:02:00.350
whether our operating system recognizes,
analyzes it,

42
00:02:00.350 --> 00:02:03.120
and can communicate
with it via the driver.

43
00:02:03.120 --> 00:02:04.400
So let me show you what I mean here.

44
00:02:04.400 --> 00:02:05.720
If I expand out, for instance,

45
00:02:05.720 --> 00:02:11.660
the keyboard, you can see that it says
the classic Standard PS/2 Keyboard.

46
00:02:11.660 --> 00:02:15.340
Well, how does it know that it's
a classic Standard PS/2 Keyboard?

47
00:02:15.340 --> 00:02:18.310
Well, that's because of
the driver that's installed.

48
00:02:18.310 --> 00:02:20.530
So one of the things that I can do
is I can right click on it, and

49
00:02:20.530 --> 00:02:21.500
you can see a couple of options.

50
00:02:21.500 --> 00:02:24.010
Options that you have here, and
we're going to look at these, but notice

51
00:02:24.010 --> 00:02:28.360
the update driver software, install,
scan for hardware changes, and properties.

52
00:02:28.360 --> 00:02:31.210
All right, if I go ahead and take a look
at the properties dialog box, and

53
00:02:31.210 --> 00:02:32.470
I would know this on the exam,

54
00:02:32.470 --> 00:02:37.220
this is what this device status lets me
know is the driver doing its job, right?

55
00:02:37.220 --> 00:02:39.680
We know that the operating system's
working because I'm in it, right?

56
00:02:39.680 --> 00:02:42.740
I know that I have a keyboard here
because I'm typing on it, but

57
00:02:42.740 --> 00:02:44.740
I need to know is it functioning properly?

58
00:02:44.740 --> 00:02:46.150
Well, and we can see that it is.

59
00:02:46.150 --> 00:02:48.350
It says that it's working properly here.

60
00:02:48.350 --> 00:02:50.760
The other thing,
being able to manage your drivers.

61
00:02:50.760 --> 00:02:53.090
We've got quite a few
different buttons here.

62
00:02:53.090 --> 00:02:54.790
We'll talk about each one
of these individually.

63
00:02:54.790 --> 00:02:58.770
Driver details is a good place to go,
especially for

64
00:02:58.770 --> 00:03:01.990
the exam because what is shows
you is where the drivers located.

65
00:03:01.990 --> 00:03:04.010
And I really want you guys
to know this for the exam.

66
00:03:04.010 --> 00:03:09.561
If they ask where the drivers are located,
C:/Windows/32 32\DRIVERS.

67
00:03:09.561 --> 00:03:13.640
Know that for the exam, because that's
where your driver repository is.

68
00:03:13.640 --> 00:03:15.290
>> Least it's short, right?

69
00:03:15.290 --> 00:03:17.772
>> It is.
It rolls right off the tongue for sure.

70
00:03:17.772 --> 00:03:20.050
Notice that I can also
see who the provider is.

71
00:03:20.050 --> 00:03:21.090
In this case, it's built in.

72
00:03:21.090 --> 00:03:22.640
It's a built in driver, it's Microsoft.

73
00:03:22.640 --> 00:03:25.460
I can see the file version, which let's
me know the version of the driver.

74
00:03:25.460 --> 00:03:30.310
So video drivers, if any of you guys have
some nice video cards out there, you know

75
00:03:30.310 --> 00:03:34.430
that video card drivers are always being
updated because the manufacturers realize

76
00:03:34.430 --> 00:03:38.160
that hey, we can add functionality,
we can add improvements to it.

77
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:41.480
So as drivers update,
they'll put versioning numbers on here.

78
00:03:41.480 --> 00:03:44.170
And if you want to find out, well,
do you have the current driver?

79
00:03:44.170 --> 00:03:46.590
Well, look at this information and
go to the manufacturer's website, and

80
00:03:46.590 --> 00:03:50.570
compare the two and if they match, well,
you know you have the latest and greatest.

81
00:03:50.570 --> 00:03:53.520
If not, you get the ability,
you can download and install the driver.

82
00:03:53.520 --> 00:03:55.710
We'll show you where that's
at here in a second.

83
00:03:55.710 --> 00:03:57.750
Next thing is updating the driver.

84
00:03:57.750 --> 00:04:00.300
Now if I choose, update driver,
it takes me to this screen.

85
00:04:00.300 --> 00:04:01.160
Let me show you another way.

86
00:04:01.160 --> 00:04:03.490
There's always six one half dozen or
the other.

87
00:04:03.490 --> 00:04:06.760
In Windows here, if I right-click,
I can choose, update drive, and

88
00:04:06.760 --> 00:04:09.270
notice it takes me pretty
much to the same location.

89
00:04:09.270 --> 00:04:10.600
We'll come back to that here in a second.

90
00:04:10.600 --> 00:04:14.200
All right,
getting back to that property screen.

91
00:04:14.200 --> 00:04:15.890
All right, notice I have some details.

92
00:04:15.890 --> 00:04:18.480
All right, now you say well,
the details, they don't,

93
00:04:18.480 --> 00:04:22.820
this big old long laundry list of stuff,
and I don't really care about that.

94
00:04:22.820 --> 00:04:25.950
Let me give you a little hint,
a little tip that's kind of cool.

95
00:04:25.950 --> 00:04:30.110
When you want to control the class of
driver devices that can be deployed,

96
00:04:30.110 --> 00:04:33.910
let's say inside a group
policy in active directory.

97
00:04:33.910 --> 00:04:35.290
You need what's known as a class ID.

98
00:04:35.290 --> 00:04:36.770
And we'll check it out here.

99
00:04:36.770 --> 00:04:41.510
You've got hardware IDs, or class GUIT's,
the globally unique identifier.

100
00:04:41.510 --> 00:04:44.540
Well, if I don't know what the GUIT is,
check it out.

101
00:04:44.540 --> 00:04:46.180
I can find it right here, all right?

102
00:04:46.180 --> 00:04:48.030
And that is actually
saves you a little bit.

103
00:04:48.030 --> 00:04:51.550
The other thing you can do is to dig
down in and find the INF file and

104
00:04:51.550 --> 00:04:53.610
do a Ctrl f and find the GUIT that way.

105
00:04:53.610 --> 00:04:55.040
That's it's a little bit easier here.

106
00:04:55.040 --> 00:04:57.760
You can get some information
related to the hardware.

107
00:04:57.760 --> 00:05:03.620
The other thing we have are events
surrounding the keyboard here.

108
00:05:03.620 --> 00:05:04.920
You can see some INF files.

109
00:05:04.920 --> 00:05:07.290
Again, these are drivers, if you will.

110
00:05:07.290 --> 00:05:11.040
I can see that class goo it, and
I can also see the driver date here.

111
00:05:11.040 --> 00:05:14.010
We can see the device ID, and you can
see it's a P and P, it's a plug and

112
00:05:14.010 --> 00:05:15.230
play driver.

113
00:05:15.230 --> 00:05:17.220
All right, and
we can view additional events here.

114
00:05:17.220 --> 00:05:19.370
We don't have to worry
too much about that, and

115
00:05:19.370 --> 00:05:21.840
I'm going to mention a very bad word here.

116
00:05:21.840 --> 00:05:23.550
Thank goodness we don't have to
deal with these anymore, but

117
00:05:23.550 --> 00:05:26.630
I can also see things like IRQs, right?

118
00:05:26.630 --> 00:05:28.840
And IO input output ranges.

119
00:05:28.840 --> 00:05:32.460
Thank goodness we got plug and play today,
and we don't have to mess with these.

120
00:05:32.460 --> 00:05:34.000
Dan, did you ever have
to mess with those IRQs?

121
00:05:34.000 --> 00:05:35.030
>> Yeah, Westat's going to give me.

122
00:05:35.030 --> 00:05:37.751
I'm going to have to start talking to
a qualified, like, for psychiatrist or

123
00:05:37.751 --> 00:05:38.698
something at this point.

124
00:05:38.698 --> 00:05:41.910
>> [LAUGH] So Dan, that's absolutely
correct because it was the bane of

125
00:05:41.910 --> 00:05:45.780
existence having the manually configured
armor resources you have in the system.

126
00:05:45.780 --> 00:05:46.480
So we'll go ahead and

127
00:05:46.480 --> 00:05:51.130
get out of there before we had to get
some psychiatric help there for Dan here.

128
00:05:51.130 --> 00:05:52.810
Now, what about, let's go ahead and

129
00:05:52.810 --> 00:05:55.860
let's talk a little bit about
the driver software itself.

130
00:05:55.860 --> 00:05:57.635
And we'll come back to
some of those buttons,

131
00:05:57.635 --> 00:06:01.430
because I do want to talk a little bit
about the driver tab within properties

132
00:06:01.430 --> 00:06:03.360
that you might have to know for the exam.

133
00:06:03.360 --> 00:06:07.270
So when we talk about driver software, we
get the ability to update driver software.

134
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:09.960
If you'll see,
it says search automatically.

135
00:06:09.960 --> 00:06:12.670
And I know you guys can read this, but let
me kind of tell you what's going on here.

136
00:06:12.670 --> 00:06:15.280
Notice it says Windows will search
your computer and the Internet.

137
00:06:15.280 --> 00:06:16.260
Let's stop right there, right?

138
00:06:16.260 --> 00:06:18.000
So what's it doing when
it searches Windows?

139
00:06:18.000 --> 00:06:19.680
Remember the driver store
that I told you about?

140
00:06:19.680 --> 00:06:21.470
I said I want you guys
to know where it is?

141
00:06:21.470 --> 00:06:23.650
We've seen it from the Properties tab,
right?

142
00:06:23.650 --> 00:06:27.270

when it gets wrong, when you got it wrong,

00:28:09.120 --> 00:28:10.640
it shows you everything under the sun.

599
00:28:10.640 --> 00:28:13.300
>> It takes out a full page ad in
the New York Times, doesn't it?

600
00:28:13.300 --> 00:28:16.671
>> That's right, it gives you a doctoral
dissertation or thesis, if you will,

601
00:28:16.671 --> 00:28:17.650
on why you're wrong.

602
00:28:17.650 --> 00:28:19.250
So now we've set that.

603
00:28:19.250 --> 00:28:22.060
Let's see if we can call
on that script again.

604
00:28:23.200 --> 00:28:25.410
All right, now it's telling me,

605
00:28:25.410 --> 00:28:29.000
well wait a second here,
you've got something you've missed.

606
00:28:29.000 --> 00:28:31.230
Well, it knows that it's
missing a parameter.

607
00:28:31.230 --> 00:28:35.084
It didn't give me this option
when it was restricted, right?

608
00:28:35.084 --> 00:28:38.869
So what I have to do is
I have to do logfile,

609
00:28:38.869 --> 00:28:44.067
that's what it's looking for,
and then I'm gonna tell

610
00:28:44.067 --> 00:28:49.080
it logfile and
we'll just do psscript.log, right?

611
00:28:49.080 --> 00:28:51.510
The other thing I want you to pay
attention that I didn't mention then and

612
00:28:51.510 --> 00:28:54.450
I do need to mention is
this file extension .ps1.

613
00:28:54.450 --> 00:28:56.548
Sorry, you PlayStation fanatics out there.

614
00:28:56.548 --> 00:28:58.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> That is not the first PlayStation.

615
00:28:58.700 --> 00:29:02.170
That's the format of a PowerShell script.

616
00:29:02.170 --> 00:29:04.503
All right, and let me spell log right.

617
00:29:05.664 --> 00:29:06.780
And we'll run it.

618
00:29:06.780 --> 00:29:09.310
And notice that it's automating
the process, it's saying

619
00:29:09.310 --> 00:29:12.520
I'm retrieving a list of folders,
right, and it's going to go through.

620
00:29:12.520 --> 00:29:16.370
It's going to find the folders in
this case that are thirty days old,

621
00:29:16.370 --> 00:29:19.020
right, and it says old files.

622
00:29:19.020 --> 00:29:20.440
It's found a whole bunch, all right.

623
00:29:20.440 --> 00:29:24.869
I can tell you on this script you really
shouldn't be running it on the users

624
00:29:24.869 --> 00:29:29.808
profiles unless you've confirmed with
them that those files aren't important.

625
00:29:29.808 --> 00:29:31.971
Because what this thing does,
you can see right here,

626
00:29:31.971 --> 00:29:33.582
it's starting to remove the old files.

627
00:29:33.582 --> 00:29:35.950
Now what's going on, right?

628
00:29:35.950 --> 00:29:37.630
I don't have to do anything.

629
00:29:37.630 --> 00:29:39.150
I don't have to open, right?

630
00:29:39.150 --> 00:29:41.690
Dan calls me up says, hey Wes,
I need you to look for

631
00:29:41.690 --> 00:29:45.720
3634 files and I need them deleted.

632
00:29:45.720 --> 00:29:49.600
And you don't get paid hourly, so you're
gonna be here tonight, all night long.

633
00:29:49.600 --> 00:29:51.190
Well, no, I can say sure, no problem.

634
00:29:51.190 --> 00:29:54.790
Delete.ps1, this script in case,
run it, say Dan,

635
00:29:54.790 --> 00:29:57.440
I'll be on the golf course by noon, right?

636
00:29:57.440 --> 00:30:00.720
So, the automated task is a lot better.

637
00:30:00.720 --> 00:30:04.000
And that's essentially some of
the things that you can do.

638
00:30:04.000 --> 00:30:06.720
Remember you can automate
tasks with Task Scheduler, but

639
00:30:06.720 --> 00:30:10.960
you can also dig down deep and
you can grab a ps1 file.

640
00:30:10.960 --> 00:30:13.610
If you know the scripting language,
you can build them yourself.

641
00:30:13.610 --> 00:30:16.080
If not, jump on over to Scripting Guy and

642
00:30:16.080 --> 00:30:19.740
there's tons of them that people
that do create these scripts.

643
00:30:19.740 --> 00:30:24.650
Make sure you set your execution policy
to remote signed, if you wanna make

644
00:30:24.650 --> 00:30:28.210
sure that it's locally, all signed,
if you wanna go the securest route.

645
00:30:28.210 --> 00:30:30.660
Unrestricted, again,
I would be careful with it.

646
00:30:30.660 --> 00:30:32.870
In a test environment, might be okay, but

647
00:30:32.870 --> 00:30:36.082
other than that it will cause
a pretty good security vulnerability.

648
00:30:36.082 --> 00:30:39.290
So, Dan, that's a little bit
about our advanced tools.

649
00:30:39.290 --> 00:30:41.210
>> Really, really cool stuff today, Wes.

650
00:30:41.210 --> 00:30:43.050
I enjoyed this episode quite a bit.

651
00:30:43.050 --> 00:30:44.640
Hopefully you guys did as well.

652
00:30:44.640 --> 00:30:48.510
But unfortunately the arts clock
has ticked away, time has ended.

653
00:30:48.510 --> 00:30:49.770
But we do appreciate you guys showing up.

654
00:30:49.770 --> 00:30:53.000
And Wes, we appreciate you for
showing us these things, so

655
00:30:53.000 --> 00:30:55.090
that we can increase
our Windows knowledge.

656
00:30:55.090 --> 00:30:56.100
Pass that exam.

657
00:30:56.100 --> 00:30:58.450
That being said,
it is time to sign off for ITProTV.

658
00:30:58.450 --> 00:31:00.440
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

659
00:31:00.440 --> 00:31:01.205
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

660
00:31:01.205 --> 00:31:03.493
>> We'll see you next time.

661
00:31:03.493 --> 00:31:12.130
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes discuss the need and show how to run a complete file system backup in Windows 10.  The guys show that Windows 10 doesn’t have a native application for backing up the file system through the GUI.  Instead, Windows 10 provides the Backup and Recovery tool from Windows 7 to provide a complete backup and create a system image so that even a full bare metal recovery could be accomplished.  The guys show how to create a backup using WBAdmin and using the System Backup and Recovery from Windows 7.
episodes.title: Configure System and Data Recovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.038 --> 00:00:10.038
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.408 --> 00:00:14.953
Welcome to another exciting
episode right here on ITPRO TV.

3
00:00:14.953 --> 00:00:18.837
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and today,
you're actually watching the Windows 10

4
00:00:18.837 --> 00:00:21.909
show, taking a look at installing and
configuring Windows 10.

5
00:00:21.909 --> 00:00:25.852
Specifically talking about the 70-698
exam, and who better to help us out on

6
00:00:25.852 --> 00:00:29.025
some of the different topics there,
than Mr. Wes Bryan himself.

7
00:00:29.025 --> 00:00:30.229
Wes, welcome back to our studios.

8
00:00:30.229 --> 00:00:31.136
>> Thanks Ronnie for having me here.

9
00:00:31.136 --> 00:00:32.589
As always, great to be here.

10
00:00:32.589 --> 00:00:36.177
That's right,
we're moving through our 7698 exam.

11
00:00:36.177 --> 00:00:40.664
One of the things that we're gonna look
at today is configuring system recovery,

12
00:00:40.664 --> 00:00:42.560
if you will, backup and restore.

13
00:00:42.560 --> 00:00:45.117
We're going to look at a couple
of technologies that we want you

14
00:00:45.117 --> 00:00:46.380
to be prepared for on the exam.

15
00:00:46.380 --> 00:00:49.645
Now there are a handful of technologies
that can help you backup and

16
00:00:49.645 --> 00:00:50.644
recover your data.

17
00:00:50.644 --> 00:00:54.795
In the 7697 exam, they took care
of things like your PC refresh,

18
00:00:54.795 --> 00:00:59.684
your PC reset, the Windows recovery
environment and creating a recovery disk.

19
00:00:59.684 --> 00:01:01.484
So we definitely encourage
you to jump back over.

20
00:01:01.484 --> 00:01:03.080
If any of those seem foreign to you,

21
00:01:03.080 --> 00:01:06.393
you're gonna want to watch them
regardless of what exam you're taking.

22
00:01:06.393 --> 00:01:09.537
Here today what we're going to be looking
at is a little bit on the command line and

23
00:01:09.537 --> 00:01:10.383
an oldie but goodie.

24
00:01:10.383 --> 00:01:14.231
One that was taken out in Windows 8 Or
8.1 completely, and

25
00:01:14.231 --> 00:01:19.192
there must have been enough uproar that
they brought it back into Windows 10.

26
00:01:19.192 --> 00:01:22.497
So let's talk about one that's been
in Windows for a very long time, and

27
00:01:22.497 --> 00:01:24.241
that's something known as Wbadmin.

28
00:01:24.241 --> 00:01:27.510
That's the Windows Backup
Administration Utility, and

29
00:01:27.510 --> 00:01:30.511
I wanna talk about a few of the switches,
and also make

30
00:01:30.511 --> 00:01:34.932
you aware of some of the changes just in
case they might catch you up on the exam.

31
00:01:34.932 --> 00:01:36.300
I went ahead and
made a little diagram here.

32
00:01:36.300 --> 00:01:39.292
Let's talk a little bit about WBADMIN,
all right.

33
00:01:39.292 --> 00:01:44.144
When we start a backup inside
of the command prompt,

34
00:01:44.144 --> 00:01:48.345
we typically run WBADMIN_start_backup.

35
00:01:48.345 --> 00:01:51.324
Now there are a couple of switches that
I want you to be aware of for the exam.

36
00:01:51.324 --> 00:01:54.522
And then there are again a couple of
things that we'll mention that I don't

37
00:01:54.522 --> 00:01:55.602
want them to trip you up.

38
00:01:55.602 --> 00:01:57.179
The first one is the backup target.

39
00:01:57.179 --> 00:01:58.962
Now when we look at backup target,

40
00:01:58.962 --> 00:02:02.961
I want you to understand that you're
telling the program, you're saying,

41
00:02:02.961 --> 00:02:06.737
this is where I want you to send that
information that we're backing up.

42
00:02:06.737 --> 00:02:12.283
Now, I went ahead and put this
little warning here, not -addTarget,

43
00:02:12.283 --> 00:02:17.468
because when you are scheduling
a backup the switch is addTarget.

44
00:02:17.468 --> 00:02:20.821
And it says okay if I've got
multiple drives in the system and

45
00:02:20.821 --> 00:02:25.030
I don't wanna just include C: which
is typically your Windows directory,

46
00:02:25.030 --> 00:02:26.890
add the D drive, add the E drive.

47
00:02:26.890 --> 00:02:29.408
So you're adding a target, if you will.

48
00:02:29.408 --> 00:02:32.721
Notice that when you're running start
backup it's a little bit different.

49
00:02:32.721 --> 00:02:36.687
You choose backupTarget and that just
says, okay Windows back up administration

50
00:02:36.687 --> 00:02:40.740
utility, I want you to put all of
our backup data in this location.

51
00:02:40.740 --> 00:02:43.948
Now, include, you can exclude items,
you can include items.

52
00:02:43.948 --> 00:02:46.820
For us, we're gonna use this,
we're gonna use include.

53
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:52.326
We're gonna say C: here so that we
can include the drive C, if you will.

54
00:02:52.326 --> 00:02:55.824
Now here's another one for the exam
that I want you to pay attention to.

55
00:02:55.824 --> 00:03:00.308
And this has changed a little bit
from what it was in previous versions

56
00:03:00.308 --> 00:03:01.780
of the WB admin.

57
00:03:01.780 --> 00:03:04.370
When you wanted to capture
your system state, well,

58
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:07.810
if you don't know what system state data
is, let's kind of talk about that right?

59
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:13.162
System state data is things like your
.com, registration objects, your registry.

60
00:03:13.162 --> 00:03:17.134
And it's the crucial set of system files
that your operation system needs in

61
00:03:17.134 --> 00:03:17.889
order to run.

62
00:03:17.889 --> 00:03:21.454
Well, if you want to back up that system
state data, should you get a virus or

63
00:03:21.454 --> 00:03:25.194
something that starts to corrupt your
critical files, those operating system

64
00:03:25.194 --> 00:03:28.290
files, you need to make sure that
you have a system state backup.

65
00:03:28.290 --> 00:03:33.999
In earlier versions, you used to
run systemstatebackup as a switch.

66
00:03:33.999 --> 00:03:38.638
Today we run -allCritical.

67
00:03:38.638 --> 00:03:40.360
So please keep that in mind.

68
00:03:40.360 --> 00:03:45.229
But if you want to not only backup user
data, but you want to backup those crucial

69
00:03:45.229 --> 00:03:48.862
files that the operating system
needs to stay functional,

70
00:03:48.862 --> 00:03:53.164
you're gonna go ahead and
you’re gonna use the allCritical switch.

71
00:03:53.164 --> 00:03:57.062
Now, there are a couple other options
that I want you to look at as well here.

72
00:03:57.062 --> 00:04:00.267
And this is the get option with WBADMIN.

73
00:04:00.267 --> 00:04:04.120
And what this allows you to do is,
it allows you to find some information,

74
00:04:04.120 --> 00:04:05.190
hence the term get.

75
00:04:05.190 --> 00:04:10.407
All right, if I have multiple
versions of a backup, right.

76
00:04:10.407 --> 00:04:13.959
Let's say I take a backup and
let's say at 12 noon.

77
00:04:13.959 --> 00:04:16.178
And then I run a backup at 8 o'clock.

78
00:04:16.178 --> 00:04:18.626
Maybe you're running
a backup every other day.

79
00:04:18.626 --> 00:04:21.593
And I decide that I wanna go
to the recovery operation.

80
00:04:21.593 --> 00:04:22.803
I wanna recover.

81
00:04:22.803 --> 00:04:27.251
Well, I need to know what the backup
version is in order to recover it.

82
00:04:27.251 --> 00:04:31.905
So you can get the version numbers from
the various backups that you have.

83
00:04:31.905 --> 00:04:37.722
Again, keep in mind I don't
believe we need this one here.

84
00:04:37.722 --> 00:04:40.057
Yeah, you don't need the backup target,
which is great.

85
00:04:40.057 --> 00:04:42.155
You don't need to point it to it.

86
00:04:42.155 --> 00:04:47.397
Status, if I run a backup job or I have
a backup job that's currently running.

87
00:04:47.397 --> 00:04:51.912
Maybe it's being scripted and I wanna find
out Where is it in the back up operation?

88
00:04:51.912 --> 00:04:56.467
Well I can run a WBADMIN get dash status,
and

89
00:04:56.467 --> 00:05:02.758
it'll show me the running status
of incurring backup jobs.

90
00:05:02.758 --> 00:05:08.192
Now another one that's in here,
that's not supported in Windows 10,

91
00:05:08.192 --> 00:05:11.609
and we're gonna demonstrate
this coming up,

92
00:05:11.609 --> 00:05:16.355
is the fact that when I do a get-disks,
it doesn't support it.

93
00:05:16.355 --> 00:05:19.347
And it will tell you,
not supported in this version so

94
00:05:19.347 --> 00:05:21.217
please keep that in mind as well.

95
00:05:21.217 --> 00:05:23.370
I can also look for the volumes.

96
00:05:23.370 --> 00:05:27.135
What can I backup or what can I
recover inside of a Windows backup?

97
00:05:27.135 --> 00:05:31.595
Well, I can do get items and
I can find out is it just a drive letter?

98
00:05:31.595 --> 00:05:36.659
Is it a folder that we can backup or
we can recover or is it an entire volume?

99
00:05:36.659 --> 00:05:38.213
And that's with the get-items.

100
00:05:38.213 --> 00:05:42.570
And you also have to use
the version number, as well.

101
00:05:42.570 --> 00:05:45.557
Finally, and again, like I said,
we're going to demonstrate some of these.

102
00:05:45.557 --> 00:05:47.925
We also have the enable backup.

103
00:05:47.925 --> 00:05:51.105
WBADMIN allows you the ability
to schedule a backup,

104
00:05:51.105 --> 00:05:54.438
just like you can do from
the graphical user interface.

105
00:05:54.438 --> 00:05:57.471
Now understand that we use and

106
00:05:57.471 --> 00:06:02.329
run WBADMIN enable backup and
then -include.

107
00:06:02.329 --> 00:06:05.277
Again, what do we wanna include
when we're gonna schedule this?

108
00:06:05.277 --> 00:06:09.658
-addTarget if you have additional
drives that you wanna include, and then

109
00:06:09.658 --> 00:06:15.310
the -schedule, and the schedule, when you
add the time, it's hour and minute format.

110
00:06:15.310 --> 00:06:20.030
So, those are a few of the options that
I want you to be aware of for this exam.

111
00:06:20.030 --> 00:06:21.805
Now, that's enough talking about it.

112
00:06:21.805 --> 00:06:24.228
Let's go ahead switch
over to our machine and

113
00:06:24.228 --> 00:06:28.130
let's show you how you would back up
all the critical files on a machine.

114
00:06:28.130 --> 00:06:31.005
Now, we'll go ahead and
we'll run one here, and

115
00:06:31.005 --> 00:06:34.374
then we'll see what it looks
like after it's completed.

116
00:06:34.374 --> 00:06:35.773
So I'm gonna drop down to my Powershell.

117
00:06:35.773 --> 00:06:38.008
Keep in mind guys,
you can do this in Powershell,

118
00:06:38.008 --> 00:06:41.510
you can do it in command prompt,
WBadmin is it's own utility.

119
00:06:41.510 --> 00:06:46.310
So it's not tied to any
one of the command lines.

120
00:06:46.310 --> 00:06:47.353
All right now.

121
00:06:47.353 --> 00:06:50.861
To do this, what we're going to
do is we're going to run WBADMIN.

122
00:06:54.446 --> 00:06:59.113
All right and
we're going to say start, backup.

123
00:06:59.113 --> 00:06:59.615
All right.

124
00:06:59.615 --> 00:07:03.759
And now keep in mind that when running
the backup, we do backup target.

125
00:07:03.759 --> 00:07:06.535
Not add target,
that's in the scheduling of it.

126
00:07:06.535 --> 00:07:11.440
So we're gonna do backup Target and

127
00:07:11.440 --> 00:07:17.008
you're going to include one of
two things here, all right?

128
00:07:17.008 --> 00:07:20.851
If you've got a file server on your
network, you can include the UNC path to

129
00:07:20.851 --> 00:07:24.952
the file, or the share, that you've
shared out, that you've got access to.

130
00:07:24.952 --> 00:07:26.764
Or you can type in a local drive.

131
00:07:26.764 --> 00:07:29.310
For us, here,
we're going to type a local drive.

132
00:07:29.310 --> 00:07:31.196
And I've got a couple
of drives on this PC.

133
00:07:31.196 --> 00:07:34.884
Now, one of the things to keep in
mind it doesn't like is when you try

134
00:07:34.884 --> 00:07:37.695
to include a backup on
the drive you are backing up.

135
00:07:37.695 --> 00:07:40.034
So please keep that in mind.

136
00:07:40.034 --> 00:07:43.810
So I've got this E drive here, and
we'll go ahead, we'll run that.

137
00:07:43.810 --> 00:07:47.117
We'll run our backup and we'll tell
the Windows Backup Administration Utility

138
00:07:47.117 --> 00:07:48.875
yeah, go ahead and put it on the E: drive.

139
00:07:48.875 --> 00:07:51.065
So I'll say backup target.

140
00:07:51.065 --> 00:07:57.260
And then :e : all right, next thing we're
gonna do is we're gonna say include.

141
00:07:57.260 --> 00:08:03.100
And we're going to say, c : all right.

142
00:08:03.100 --> 00:08:06.790
Now remember that if I want the system
state to be backed up, I don't do,

143
00:08:06.790 --> 00:08:09.390
like we used to do,
when we'd say system state backup.

144
00:08:09.390 --> 00:08:14.920
Keep in mind we're gonna
do a dash all Critical, and

145
00:08:14.920 --> 00:08:19.400
since this is not a Linux system we might
want to take that double dash out of there

146
00:08:20.940 --> 00:08:22.510
or it won't work.

147
00:08:22.510 --> 00:08:25.770
If you get any errors,
it could pause your backup state.

148
00:08:25.770 --> 00:08:28.770
One of the things that you can
do is you can run it quietly, so

149
00:08:28.770 --> 00:08:30.630
it just runs the back-up.

150
00:08:30.630 --> 00:08:33.100
So we'll go ahead and
we'll just put quiet.

151
00:08:33.100 --> 00:08:34.130
And we'll go ahead and run this.

152
00:08:34.130 --> 00:08:36.700
Now, and we zoom in here,
we'll see a little bit of this.

153
00:08:36.700 --> 00:08:38.090
It could take some time here and

154
00:08:38.090 --> 00:08:41.120
I won't torture you guys by
making you watch the whole thing.

155
00:08:41.120 --> 00:08:44.050
But I do want you to see at
least the initial start of it.

156
00:08:44.050 --> 00:08:45.940
All right.
What it does is it's going to backup

157
00:08:45.940 --> 00:08:47.310

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike discuss supporting device security. They start by explaining Device Guard and how it controls the applications that are allowed to run. Then they look at Credential Guard, and talk about how it keeps user credentials safe. They finish with a discussion on Device Health Attestation, and how Secure Boot and Measured Boot work to protect the system.
episodes.title: Supporting Device Security

00:21:54.135 --> 00:21:55.595

00:21:55.595 --> 00:21:59.630
Well, there's a couple of

00:21:59.630 --> 00:22:03.570
