404
00:22:03.570 --> 00:22:07.240
We've talked a little bit about Secure
Boot, when we talk about Secure Boot,

405
00:22:07.240 --> 00:22:08.270
what is it doing for us?

406
00:22:08.270 --> 00:22:09.787
What is it verifying?

407
00:22:09.787 --> 00:22:11.583
Well health attestation.

408
00:22:11.583 --> 00:22:15.524
In earlier implementations of server,
we can do this through

409
00:22:15.524 --> 00:22:20.013
things like network access protection,
says does your firewall on?

410
00:22:20.013 --> 00:22:21.174
Do you have your updates?

411
00:22:21.174 --> 00:22:24.956
If you have this then you're in
compliance with the network policy,

412
00:22:24.956 --> 00:22:26.335
we can grant you access.

413
00:22:26.335 --> 00:22:31.240
Well, that's also after
the operating system is launched,

414
00:22:31.240 --> 00:22:35.308
how about antivirus and
anti-malware software?

415
00:22:35.308 --> 00:22:36.620
Typically what do we have to do?

416
00:22:36.620 --> 00:22:38.900
We have to wait till this
software comes online for

417
00:22:38.900 --> 00:22:40.720
it to start protecting our machines.

418
00:22:40.720 --> 00:22:43.640
Well, we've go a whole boot
process that does need to

419
00:22:43.640 --> 00:22:46.640
be protected against things like rootkits.

420
00:22:46.640 --> 00:22:49.510
They're getting very crafty at
slipping these rootkits in, and

421
00:22:49.510 --> 00:22:53.350
they come online before your any
malware software is ever even awake.

422
00:22:53.350 --> 00:22:56.680
So what Secure Boot does is
the first thing it goes through,

423
00:22:56.680 --> 00:23:02.700
is it looks at the TPM and a few
processes here, looks at your firmware.

424
00:23:02.700 --> 00:23:05.130
And it says, is the firmware valid?

425
00:23:05.130 --> 00:23:07.810
Has it been modified or
hasn't it been modified?

426
00:23:07.810 --> 00:23:10.920
If it's been modified,
then a boot process is gonna fail.

427
00:23:10.920 --> 00:23:12.978
If it hasn't been modified then
it goes through the next step.

428
00:23:12.978 --> 00:23:16.010
It looks at for instance,
for a signed boot loader.

429
00:23:16.010 --> 00:23:19.624
A digital signature for the boot
loader that's stored within that TPM.

430
00:23:19.624 --> 00:23:23.026
If it finds it and the boot loader
that's currently launching,

431
00:23:23.026 --> 00:23:25.925
trying to bootstrap
the operating system as trusted.

432
00:23:25.925 --> 00:23:30.050
It'll go through the next process, then
it looks for a digitally signed kernel.

433
00:23:30.050 --> 00:23:31.330
Do we trust the kernel?

434
00:23:31.330 --> 00:23:32.664
Has it maintained its integrity?

435
00:23:32.664 --> 00:23:34.787
Are we looking at that and
verifying that it's good?

436
00:23:34.787 --> 00:23:39.690
And once that happens,
that's where the next process comes in.

437
00:23:39.690 --> 00:23:42.406
So as part of this,
this is what is known as ELAM and

438
00:23:42.406 --> 00:23:45.272
that's the Early Launch Anti-malware
software.

439
00:23:45.272 --> 00:23:49.943
Now this is all in the boot process
to verify that your system has

440
00:23:49.943 --> 00:23:51.804
maintained its health.

441
00:23:51.804 --> 00:23:53.064
All right, so what happens?

442
00:23:53.064 --> 00:23:57.818
Well when ELAM comes on on the scene what
it does is it loads something known as

443
00:23:57.818 --> 00:24:02.356
an initialization policy and
initialization policy essentially tells

444
00:24:02.356 --> 00:24:07.200
elam here's how you start the boot
drivers, the early boot start drivers.

445
00:24:07.200 --> 00:24:10.150
This is the order that we
want them to be booted in.

446
00:24:10.150 --> 00:24:12.550
Alright?
So what does it do?

447
00:24:12.550 --> 00:24:17.180
It only loads drivers that are in
that initialization policy.

448
00:24:17.180 --> 00:24:20.790
Right?
It only loads the known, good drivers.

449
00:24:20.790 --> 00:24:22.370
How do we know that the drivers are good,
right?

450
00:24:22.370 --> 00:24:22.930
Remember?

451
00:24:22.930 --> 00:24:24.780
Remember that kernel mode integrity code.

452
00:24:24.780 --> 00:24:26.690
They have to be digitally signed.

453
00:24:26.690 --> 00:24:31.280
Alright, The other thing it doesn't do,
it doesn't load unknown drivers.

454
00:24:31.280 --> 00:24:32.740
If the drivers are digitally signed

455
00:24:32.740 --> 00:24:35.000
they're not going to run at boot start,
right?

456
00:24:35.000 --> 00:24:39.260
The other thing it does is if it finds
corrupted drivers, and this is where

457
00:24:39.260 --> 00:24:42.600
another place that ELAM maintains the
integrity of the boot process because if

458
00:24:42.600 --> 00:24:47.150
the drivers themselves are corrupted
it isn't going to load a bad driver.

459
00:24:47.150 --> 00:24:49.800
All right.
So this is the first part of if you will,

460
00:24:49.800 --> 00:24:51.460
device health attestation.

461
00:24:52.770 --> 00:24:55.460
More so
than that is something called measureboot.

462
00:24:55.460 --> 00:24:59.490
Now measureboot and secureboot a lot
of times are considered to be close to

463
00:24:59.490 --> 00:25:02.730
the same thing, but
it is slightly different, right?

464
00:25:02.730 --> 00:25:06.310
In a measured boot we're going
through a lot of the same process.

465
00:25:06.310 --> 00:25:10.920
But what we're doing here is we're
actually now using a third party,

466
00:25:10.920 --> 00:25:15.230
all that process we talked about,
secure boot, checking the TPM, and ELAM.

467
00:25:17.030 --> 00:25:20.420
This is gonna say, okay,
this is what we expect to happen.

468
00:25:20.420 --> 00:25:25.730
And we're gonna send what we find in
the operating system out to a third party.

469
00:25:25.730 --> 00:25:26.948
And see if they agree with it.

470
00:25:26.948 --> 00:25:29.170
That's why they call it measured boot.

471
00:25:29.170 --> 00:25:33.090
I need to know if the boot files

472
00:25:33.090 --> 00:25:36.420
have maintained their integrity
according to my company's policy.

473
00:25:36.420 --> 00:25:41.610
Secure boot is a UAFI based
implementation right,

474
00:25:41.610 --> 00:25:46.800
and it's maintained by the UAFI council,
I would guess.

475
00:25:46.800 --> 00:25:49.720
So what this says is,
I know what Secure Boot says.

476
00:25:49.720 --> 00:25:51.590
Secure boot is going to be
part of this process but

477
00:25:51.590 --> 00:25:56.380
I am going to send this whole
boot process out to this server.

478
00:25:56.380 --> 00:25:57.420
What is this server doing?

479
00:25:57.420 --> 00:25:59.010
What is it actually sending?

480
00:25:59.010 --> 00:26:02.380
It is really only looking at
hash values of the firmware,

481
00:26:02.380 --> 00:26:06.870
the kernel, secure boot, e lamb,
and the boot start drivers.

482
00:26:06.870 --> 00:26:11.420
What it does is it says okay, here's what
I found, it's sends that information

483
00:26:11.420 --> 00:26:15.080
over to the server and the server
stores what the expected values are.

484
00:26:15.080 --> 00:26:17.510
This is what we expect to find and again,

485
00:26:17.510 --> 00:26:19.970
because we're measuring
the whole entire process.

486
00:26:19.970 --> 00:26:23.600
And if it finds that it has, it is

487
00:26:23.600 --> 00:26:28.610
in compliance with the database and
it proceeds to boot the process.

488
00:26:28.610 --> 00:26:30.640
And it proceeds with the boot
process if you will.

489
00:26:30.640 --> 00:26:35.420
So very close to the same thing, the
difference is the whole entire process is

490
00:26:35.420 --> 00:26:40.050
all measured from beginning to end and
there's a certain expected values and

491
00:26:40.050 --> 00:26:43.720
it does require a third party
in order to implement it.

492
00:26:43.720 --> 00:26:44.890
Alright so.

493
00:26:44.890 --> 00:26:48.110
those are a couple of things that
you can keep in mind for the exam.

494
00:26:48.110 --> 00:26:49.870
Remember secureboot,

495
00:26:49.870 --> 00:26:54.280
do remember the fact that measureboot
is a little bit different.

496
00:26:54.280 --> 00:26:57.910
One of the differences is that it
doesn't stop the boot process,

497
00:26:57.910 --> 00:27:02.500
unlike secureboot if secureboot
finds processes that don't match.

498
00:27:02.500 --> 00:27:07.120
This doesn't really stop the process, it's
just a way to measure the boot environment

499
00:27:07.120 --> 00:27:09.690
against a third-party to see if
you're in compliance with it.

500
00:27:09.690 --> 00:27:14.910
So this is another one of those things
that also requires a UFEI platform.

501
00:27:14.910 --> 00:27:18.250
And the TPM in order to be in the system,
so

502
00:27:18.250 --> 00:27:21.350
definitely keep in mind those extra
components, but that essentially is some

503
00:27:21.350 --> 00:27:25.260
of the things you can support when it
comes to authentication and authorization.

504
00:27:25.260 --> 00:27:28.200
>> Fantastic Wes, great explanation there,
looking at some of these

505
00:27:28.200 --> 00:27:32.600
new technologies that Microsoft and
Windows 10 is bringing to play.

506
00:27:32.600 --> 00:27:38.000
Big push into the virtualization security
taking advantage of virtualization

507
00:27:38.000 --> 00:27:43.300
leveraging that isolation that we can get
from virtualization to make a more secure

508
00:27:43.300 --> 00:27:47.220
computing environment with things like
device guard, credential guard and

509
00:27:47.220 --> 00:27:50.150
then that last one that
device health attestation.

510
00:27:50.150 --> 00:27:54.130
So fantastic, hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching Signing off for

511
00:27:54.130 --> 00:27:56.200
IT Pro TV I'm Mike Roderick.

512
00:27:56.200 --> 00:27:56.900
>> And I'm Wes Bryant.

513
00:27:56.900 --> 00:27:59.115
>> And we'll see you next time.

514
00:27:59.115 --> 00:28:04.900
[NOISE]

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike look at how to join devices to Azure AD. They demonstrate performing an Azure AD Domain Join on a Windows 10 PC.
episodes.title: Azure AD Domain Join
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITPRO.TV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:03.513
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:03.513 --> 00:00:06.223
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.223 --> 00:00:08.478
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.478 --> 00:00:13.095
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.
>> Welcome, ladies and

6
00:00:13.095 --> 00:00:15.758
gentleman, to your Installing and
Configuring Windows 10.

7
00:00:15.758 --> 00:00:20.420
For the exam preparations series
taking a look at the 70-698.

8
00:00:20.420 --> 00:00:22.540
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

9
00:00:22.540 --> 00:00:25.890
In this episode we'll be taking a look at,
well, joining a user to a domain.

10
00:00:25.890 --> 00:00:28.370
But this is going to be special because
we're gonna be looking at it from

11
00:00:28.370 --> 00:00:32.940
a perspective of configuring and
utilizing Azure in this process.

12
00:00:32.940 --> 00:00:34.530
Azure with Active Directory.

13
00:00:34.530 --> 00:00:36.600
And with us today we have Mr.
Mike Roderick.

14
00:00:36.600 --> 00:00:38.370
How's it going, Mike?
>> It's going great, Cherokee.

15
00:00:38.370 --> 00:00:39.230
Thanks for having me back.

16
00:00:39.230 --> 00:00:41.630
And yeah,
we've got to do a little Azure AD

17
00:00:41.630 --> 00:00:42.370
join, right?

18
00:00:42.370 --> 00:00:43.380
>> Yep.
>> All right.

19
00:00:43.380 --> 00:00:45.410
Cuz they specifically call
this out on the objective.

20
00:00:45.410 --> 00:00:47.730
I wanna make sure you're familiar
with concepts, the topics and

21
00:00:47.730 --> 00:00:49.580
what they are talking about.

22
00:00:49.580 --> 00:00:53.252
And a lot of these at this point is some
of you might be studying preparing for

23
00:00:53.252 --> 00:00:56.300
this exam or might be in the field
working with these devices.

24
00:00:56.300 --> 00:00:59.901
And you probably at this point at
least familiar with traditional

25
00:00:59.901 --> 00:01:01.060
Active Directory.

26
00:01:01.060 --> 00:01:03.780
What we would call
on-premises Active Directory,

27
00:01:03.780 --> 00:01:05.930
where we run our domain
controller locally.

28
00:01:05.930 --> 00:01:11.190
When we have our corporate-owned devices,
we join them to the domain.

29
00:01:11.190 --> 00:01:15.030
So we go through that process of creating
that trust relationship with the domain

30
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:16.100
controller.

31
00:01:16.100 --> 00:01:19.730
And then you can log onto that machine
with a domain name account, and

32
00:01:19.730 --> 00:01:22.600
we can manage that demand through
group policy and other things.

33
00:01:22.600 --> 00:01:24.320
So it's considered part of our domain.

34
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:28.260
But when we think about why you're
joining the computer to the domain in

35
00:01:28.260 --> 00:01:29.000
the first place.

36
00:01:29.000 --> 00:01:30.400
And there's a couple of reasons, right?

37
00:01:30.400 --> 00:01:31.790
We wanna be able to.

38
00:01:31.790 --> 00:01:32.820
Manage the device.

39
00:01:32.820 --> 00:01:36.452
That's one of the primary
reasons we join the domain is so

40
00:01:36.452 --> 00:01:40.099
that we can manage it through
group policy and auditing.

41
00:01:40.099 --> 00:01:43.532
Being able to track what machine
you're at when you logged on and

42
00:01:43.532 --> 00:01:47.040
when you accessed a certain resource,
things like that.

43
00:01:47.040 --> 00:01:52.200
As we shift out to the cloud we can host
what we call Azure Active Directory, and

44
00:01:52.200 --> 00:01:55.040
it's very similar to our
on-premise Active Directory,

45
00:01:55.040 --> 00:01:59.630
with a few differences, group policy
being a big one we don't have.

46
00:01:59.630 --> 00:02:02.850
But computer accounts are another
big difference between

47
00:02:02.850 --> 00:02:06.790
Azure Active Directory and what we think
of as traditional Active Directory.

48
00:02:06.790 --> 00:02:10.940
And the fact that we really don't
have computer accounts in Azure AD.

49
00:02:10.940 --> 00:02:14.860
When we go in and look,
we don't create new computer accounts.

50
00:02:14.860 --> 00:02:19.690
But we still wanna be able to
join those devices to Azure AD so

51
00:02:19.690 --> 00:02:23.900
that they can use, or users can use
those devices to access resources.

52
00:02:23.900 --> 00:02:27.670
But when we look at the devices, it's
not like traditional Active Directory,

53
00:02:27.670 --> 00:02:32.550
where they were desktops or laptops or
tablets that were company issued, they're

54
00:02:32.550 --> 00:02:36.860
connected to the corporate network,
we manage them through group policy.

55
00:02:36.860 --> 00:02:40.950
We're talking about Azure and
moving things out of the cloud, it shifts.

56
00:02:40.950 --> 00:02:44.760
Now all of a sudden, we're dealing
with some company issued devices, but

57
00:02:44.760 --> 00:02:46.920
a lot of BYOD type stuff.

58
00:02:46.920 --> 00:02:50.180
Laptops that you own that
you want to use at home and

59
00:02:50.180 --> 00:02:52.970
you want to be able to access
work resources or your tablets or

60
00:02:52.970 --> 00:02:58.580
your phones and your other devices.
>> Okay, so Mike we're looking at I guess

61
00:02:58.580 --> 00:03:03.970
the traditional domain join
utilizing that corporate network we

62
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:08.390
were seeing our administrators being the
ones to perform these duties and tasks.

63
00:03:08.390 --> 00:03:13.340
And with a lot of the advent of our Azure
Cloud services, we're seeing a lot of

64
00:03:13.340 --> 00:03:17.935
those responsibilities even something
as password reset being handed off and

65
00:03:17.935 --> 00:03:19.405
delegated to the client.

66
00:03:19.405 --> 00:03:23.365
What are we talking about here when
we're using the domain join with Azure?

67
00:03:23.365 --> 00:03:27.105
Are we still going to to be utilizing that
from an administrative perspective, or

68
00:03:27.105 --> 00:03:29.485
do end users get that
opportunity now as well?

69
00:03:29.485 --> 00:03:30.525
>> That's a great question, and

70
00:03:30.525 --> 00:03:33.075
the answers we're going to be
shifting it off to the end user.

71
00:03:33.075 --> 00:03:36.635
We're going to let them do it, because
they're going to be, again, their laptops,

72
00:03:36.635 --> 00:03:39.410
their tablets, their phones,
their home computers.

73
00:03:39.410 --> 00:03:43.460
Whatever they're using to connect to our
resources because we're seeing the shift

74
00:03:43.460 --> 00:03:44.560
in the way we do things.

75
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:46.990
We want to be able to do
our job from any device.

76
00:03:46.990 --> 00:03:51.950
Not just my corporate owned desktop
that's part of my work domain.

77
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:55.040
But I still want to be able to
control what devices are connecting,

78
00:03:55.040 --> 00:03:56.600
what they're allowed to connect.

79
00:03:56.600 --> 00:03:59.870
Maybe doing health checks on them,
things like that.

80
00:03:59.870 --> 00:04:01.970
But we are gonna as your question or

81
00:04:01.970 --> 00:04:05.020
to your question there,
we are gonna let the end-users do this.

82
00:04:05.020 --> 00:04:08.050
Cuz I'm not going out to their house and
logging in and

83
00:04:08.050 --> 00:04:10.200
joining their machine to the domain,
or their phone, or

84
00:04:10.200 --> 00:04:13.010
they don't have to bring them into
work before they can start using them.

85
00:04:13.010 --> 00:04:13.750
We can let them do it.

86
00:04:13.750 --> 00:04:16.360
So let me show you that part first.

87
00:04:16.360 --> 00:04:18.335
I'm gonna log into my Azure here.

88
00:04:18.335 --> 00:04:24.640
portal.azure.com and to allow my users
to join their devices to Azure AD.

89
00:04:24.640 --> 00:04:29.071
I'm gonna click on Azure Active Directory
in my navigation tree over here on

90
00:04:29.071 --> 00:04:29.704
the left.

91
00:04:29.704 --> 00:04:34.580
And once that loads up I'm gonna click
on devices in that Azure Blade or

92
00:04:34.580 --> 00:04:36.140
IT Pro Blade.

93
00:04:36.140 --> 00:04:39.570
And then I'm going to
go to Device Settings.

94
00:04:39.570 --> 00:04:42.250
And this is where I can
control their behavior.

95
00:04:42.250 --> 00:04:44.750
As soon as my options load up,
there we go.

96
00:04:44.750 --> 00:04:49.865
We should see right here, the first one
users may join devices to Azure AD.

97
00:04:49.865 --> 00:04:52.215
So this is what's going
to control whether or

98
00:04:52.215 --> 00:04:56.545
not they're allowed to take that iPhone,
or that laptop at home, and

99
00:04:56.545 --> 00:04:57.975
connect it to Azure AD.
>> So

100
00:04:57.975 --> 00:05:02.105
you're still maintaining that control,
that administrative duty per say, but

101
00:05:02.105 --> 00:05:04.445
from this console.
>> Exactly.

102
00:05:04.445 --> 00:05:06.885
And so our choices here, all selected, or

103
00:05:06.885 --> 00:05:10.590
none, All means anybody
could join their device.

104
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:11.960
They would still have to have an account.

105
00:05:11.960 --> 00:05:16.838
It's not like Joe Stranger can
get [CROSSTALK] can connect and

106
00:05:16.838 --> 00:05:18.469
join their device.

107
00:05:18.469 --> 00:05:19.850
They're gonna have to have an account.

108
00:05:19.850 --> 00:05:22.290
They're gonna have to know the password,
that kind of thing,

109
00:05:22.290 --> 00:05:24.270
if you do multi factor authentication.

110
00:05:24.270 --> 00:05:26.590
So it's secured in that respect.

111
00:05:26.590 --> 00:05:28.610
But when I say all, so we should clarify.

112
00:05:28.610 --> 00:05:32.140
When I say all,
anybody that's part of my Azure AD,

113
00:05:32.140 --> 00:05:35.170
can join a device to our
Azure active directory.

114
00:05:35.170 --> 00:05:36.595
None would mean, nobody can.

115
00:05:36.595 --> 00:05:41.130
I'd have to do with manually or
not at all, and then selected and

116
00:05:41.130 --> 00:05:42.290
this option here lights up.

117
00:05:42.290 --> 00:05:47.350
Maybe I only wanna allow a certain
group of users, like my sales people,

118
00:05:47.350 --> 00:05:47.970
that travel.

119
00:05:47.970 --> 00:05:51.370
They have a need to join
their devices to AzureAD.

120
00:05:51.370 --> 00:05:53.590
But my host side only, them doing it,

121
00:05:53.590 --> 00:05:55.280
they're not doing any
work from home anyway.

122
00:05:55.280 --> 00:05:56.720
Right or whatever the case may be.

123
00:05:56.720 --> 00:06:01.780
So if you wanna pick and choose,
who was allowed to join those devices.

124
00:06:01.780 --> 00:06:02.760
Or maybe you do set it up.

125
00:06:02.760 --> 00:06:04.340
So that only IT can do it.

126
00:06:04.340 --> 00:06:07.140
And they have to bring their
devices in get approved or

127
00:06:07.140 --> 00:06:08.750
something like that before they're joined.

128
00:06:08.750 --> 00:06:15.110
So this is where you control who is
allowed to join a device to Azure AD.

129
00:06:15.110 --> 00:06:16.530
I'm gonna leave it on all for now.

130
00:06:17.930 --> 00:06:23.330
Right below that additional local
administrator on Azure AD join devices.

131
00:06:23.330 --> 00:06:24.730
Default is None.

132
00:06:24.730 --> 00:06:26.990
This would allow me to add
an administrative account.

133
00:06:26.990 --> 00:06:31.400
If I want to let's say for example my end
users, they're using their home laptops or

134
00:06:31.400 --> 00:06:35.120
their home desktops to work from home or
while they travel.

135
00:06:35.120 --> 00:06:37.430
Now they've joined their
device to Azure AD.

136
00:06:37.430 --> 00:06:39.140
They're out there on the road.

137
00:06:39.140 --> 00:06:40.640
They hit a stumbling block.

138
00:06:40.640 --> 00:06:43.710
They call up IT and they need help.

139
00:06:43.710 --> 00:06:47.910
Well, now the problem is that's not
a corporate device where my helpdesk is

140
00:06:47.910 --> 00:06:49.880
the admin on those machines.

141
00:06:49.880 --> 00:06:50.810
So how do I help them.

142
00:06:50.810 --> 00:06:52.200
I don't have any administrative access.

143
00:06:52.200 --> 00:06:56.140
I going to have to try to trouble shoot by
walking them through it over the phone or

144
00:06:56.140 --> 00:06:57.310
something like that.

145
00:06:57.310 --> 00:06:58.300
Here I could add.

146
00:06:58.300 --> 00:06:59.790
I could say Selected.

147
00:06:59.790 --> 00:07:01.780
And I could go and find one of my groups.

148
00:07:01.780 --> 00:07:04.600
I don't know if I have a group
that I called helpdesk.

149
00:07:07.080 --> 00:07:11.000
But anyway, I don't know what, I can't
remember what groups I've created, but

150
00:07:11.000 --> 00:07:12.590
I would add them here.

151
00:07:12.590 --> 00:07:16.700
And this would, kind of like we do with
restrictive groups and group policy,

152
00:07:16.700 --> 00:07:21.610
this would allow me to add a local
administrator to those BYOD type devices.

153
00:07:22.810 --> 00:07:25.550
Users may register
the devices with Azure AD.

154
00:07:26.880 --> 00:07:35.330
This one is if we are going to enroll for
MDM, or Mobile Device Management.

155
00:07:35.330 --> 00:07:37.740
Require multi factor
authentication to join devices.

156
00:07:37.740 --> 00:07:40.490
I would say this is not
turned on by default.

157
00:07:40.490 --> 00:07:42.791
Microsoft highly recommends it-
>> Good idea.

158
00:07:42.791 --> 00:07:45.590
>> Yeah, definitely a good idea.

159
00:07:45.590 --> 00:07:47.100
Maximum number of devices.

160
00:07:47.100 --> 00:07:52.110
I might want to set a limit on how many
devices each user is allowed to enroll.

161
00:07:52.110 --> 00:07:55.360
Users may sync settings and
app data across devices.

162
00:07:55.360 --> 00:07:59.070
So we can choose to allow them to sync,
like Internet Explorer favorites or

163
00:07:59.070 --> 00:08:03.140
I should say Edge favorites,
things like that across their devices.

164
00:08:03.140 --> 00:08:09.700
So this is where we would configure
that Azure AD join in the Azure portal.

165
00:08:09.700 --> 00:08:13.080
And I'm not going to
save any changes to that.

166
00:08:13.080 --> 00:08:19.520
I do want to make sure that I left
that on all for the rest of our demo.

167
00:08:19.520 --> 00:08:21.370
Let's double check that, all good to go.

168
00:08:21.370 --> 00:08:24.010
All right, so
once you've got that set up in Azure,

169
00:08:24.010 --> 00:08:26.260
now your users should be able to join.

170
00:08:26.260 --> 00:08:27.480

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike configure Dynamic Lock. They demonstrate how you can use a Bluetooth paired device to lock your Windows 10 PC when the paired device is out of range.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Mike look at the MDM Migration and Analysis tool. They demonstrate how it can be used to help migrate from using GPO's to manage devices to using MDM platforms like Intune. They show how to install and run the tool, as well as look at the reports generated.
episodes.title: MDM Migration and Analysis Tool
